I haven't had any bad experinces with them in fact I'd like to thank them for such wonderful customer service. I go to alot of places to eat and Piquoes is the only place I don't mind tipping. In over 20 years of living in sf I'd put them as number 1 for food places. They offer a good variety of latin american and peruvian food which tastes homemade like my mothers cooking. Also there drinks are very delicious I've tried almost everything.
author: Keevin O.

description: I really like the ceviche and the sangria here, but none of the hot dishes I've tried have been particularly good. The waitstaff is friendly but the hostesses are consistently rude... I'm not sure why. They really don't like walk-ins, so I definitely recommend reservations.
author: Diana G.

description: Every dish was simply amazing here.  I was a in a group of 4 and we shared about 6 or 7 items.  Most outstanding were the seared scallops and quinoa encrusted shrimp.  The beef ribs were braised perfectly and couldn't have been more tender.  Some of the more ethnic items are the purple mashed potatoes and the yucca fries which have always been favorites.  Definite thumbs up for the food and cute location in Bernal Heights.
author: Max G.

description:
So this place won me over Destino in SF. And Destino is one of my favorite restaurants!

Three of us came here on a Saturday and I am SO glad we decided to order several tapas to share. Here's what we got and I still can't tell you which one was the most delicious, but I have made a note next to the ceviche and lomo saltado since those are a given that I have to order at Peruvian restaurants: 

We started with some deliciously seasoned (and free) corn snacks.
 
Tapas: 
-Cebiche de Pescado** (AMAZING, perfectly marinated flavors)
-Bolitas de Yucca
-Crab Cake Peruano
-Tequeños
-Pastel de Choclo

Entree: 
-Lomito al Jugo** (the meat was so tender and the sauce so well-seasoned)

Desserts:
-Alfajores
-Suspiro a la Limeña
-Chocolate lava cake

EVERYTHING was amazing! So incredibly flavorful. The service great as well. If I have to pick anything that I wasn't crazy about, it was the chocolate cake. But we learned that it was the only thing that wasn't made in-house. That explains it! Also, Mochica (which I still need to try) and La Costanera (in Half Moon Bay, another 5 star) have the same owner as Piqueos. 

Highly recommended!
author: Karen G.

description: Great neighborhood find. True Peruvian cuisine with a well versed and friendly wait staff. Off the beaten path on the south side of San Francisco but worth the trip.
author: Jonathan L.

description: Delicious! Awesome vibe. Really authentic food. Absolutely loved the lomo salted, ceviche and empanadas.
author: Ashley K.

description: Service was bad. The waiter came over at the beginning to take our orders. After that we had two different people who brought over the food without letting us know what each item was. We had never eaten there before and my friend is vegetarian. We had told the waiter. One would think they would be careful not to mix up the orders and let us know what each item was. Well no, not here because they served the steak plate in front of my vegetarian friend as well as two other meat containing items. We were disappointed with the service because we had to ask what each item was and felt they did not care. The waiter came back at the end of the meal to ask if we wanted dessert. The dessert was very good as was the food. The service was terrible.
author: Gaby O.

description: We made a reservation for 2 people on Friday at 8:00 pm, when we arrived, immediately we got our table. Couple minutes late the Server Called Andre, which I know, yield at me, saying: If you don't leave the restaurant right now I'm going call the cops saying that you're causing problems. I felt really bad, because I really like they're food and he was super rude and Disrespectful.  If he had some kind of problem with me he should talk out of the restaurant, he is unprofessional. I recommend this restaurant, the chef is really good, but unfortunately they have bad servers.
author: Tierry J.

description: I was surprised when they lead us past the very nice and cozy dining room, past the kitchen, past the bathrooms to a drafty space that must have been a patio but was now covered. The chairs were metal garden chairs, not at all comfortable. The service was friendly but not attentive. The waiter probably had tables to wait on in the real part of the restaurant and couldn't come back too often. I had the New York steak. The flavor was good but it was very tough. My dog enjoyed it. It came with yucca fries which were tasteless and a small salad that was over powered by onions. Parking was easy.
author: Stephen O.

description: My girlfriend and I decided to try this place because we lived so close by. It looked like a good restaurant as we passed by so we went in. The place is a little small and cramped but everything else about it was good. The service was great, servers were attentive and the food was great. Will definitely come back in the future.
author: Vernon B.

description: I am traveling the area on business and decided to stop by here during my walk to grab dinner as I saw it had good reviews on Yelp.  The waiter Keith was awesome and made some good recommendations.  I ordered the mixed seafood cebiche and while I was waiting for that he brought me a small dish of fried garbanzos which were delicious!  The cebiche was very tasty.  I believe the dessert was suspiro a la limena which was heavenly.  The bottle of Pellegrino was $7 which was a bit pricey but oh well, overall I had a great dinner and would definitely come back.
author: Maria P.

description:
Really a pretty good Peruvian place, but I had a bit of higher expectation given the stellar Yelp review. 3.5 stars

The food is fresh, the place is cozy, service is good. A good neighborhood joint.
author: Alice C.

description:
+ Cebiche de Pescado - fresh fish with good flavor; i wish there were some plaintains or something to add a bit of a crunch

- Tequeños: fried wontons with shrimp inside; wontons are covered in sugar so there's a sweet & salty flavor; also eat the wontons with a sweet sauce + gauc. I thought the dish was good, but I couldn't taste the shrimp so I consider this dish a miss. The wonton was more like a sweet fried donut.

- Quesadilla de Pato: the meat was a little dry; I think there should have been some kind of sauce

OTHER:
+ friendly service
+ nice ambiance - date friendly
+ no wait despite it being a friday night
author: Margaret R.

description:
Climbing up Bernal Heights in San Francisco is like navigating through the Andes Mountains in Peru.  In our San Francisco "adaptation" of the Andes, you'll run into narrow a$$ streets and numerous one ways.  To the inexperienced eye, streets appear like spitting images of each other.  Electing to hike up from Mission Street will leave you sweaty en route to your destination resulting in wobbly legs.  The extra minutes driving in circles lost, like in my case, will be worth it.  

Piqueo's is a Peruvian restaurant.  Very trendy and chic, all of things I don't really know much about.  Foolishly, I find myself gravitating towards this place.  Finally seeing the little sign on the corner restaurant, the trek felt like finding that pot of gold at the end of the rainbow.     

"Any wine or sangria?" the waitress asked.  Any normal person would order wine or sangria at a tapas BAR.  Oh no, not me.  I inquired about iced tea.  Our waitress probably thought "You serious?"  Since I'm a light weight (alcohol tolerance wise), I just stuck with water.  The sangria sounded good (next time!) when I looked over at the other table.  I could see myself bumper car-ring my way out of Bernal Heights drunk on sangria.  That wouldn't be good for my insurance.  

With so many tapas choices, we only chose one, the papa rellena.  Think an egg fashioned deep fried potato ball with meat inside.  Sitting in a decorative pond of mole-like green sauce, it was accompanied with a mix of greens and salsa.  Meat on the inside kept the potato from being too dry as the surrounding sauce also became an excellent dip.  I wish we had another.  

If our main dishes weren't as good, I would have regretted not getting more tapas.  With meat on our minds, we got the lomito al jugo and the churrasco.  The lomito al jugo (their lomo saltado) is loaded with chunks of beef tenderloin topped with skinny fries with a yellow drizzly sauce carried a soy sauce flavor light accented in the meat.  What's churrasco?  I don't know, but apparently, it's what they coin as a New York steak.  It was perfectly cooked medium upon request.  Picture this: meat so clean, a butter knife could cut through it.  Those yucca fries partnered with the steak weren't too bad themselves.  Smothered in very decorative and delectable sauces, it was an ideal starch to the meat.      

Piqueo's modern picture of Peruvian food is a framework masterpiece.  High five to the owner and chefs on a well executed operation and a job well done.  I doubt I'll ever get a chance to explore the Andes Mountains, but I will definitely come back here.
author: Arnold T.

description: Good good food. Service was okay, it does get packed, environment was so-so, intimate style casual dining. Solid local joint
author: Juls C.

description: Delicious food! Cozy, nice place. Good service. Can't complain about anything I would totally recommend it and would definitely come back
author: Priscilla S.

description:
It was a spectacular girls-day out at the ballpark. Our team had won and we went exploring. My friend, Louisa had heard about a bar on the same street as Piqueo's and we had a drink, then sought out a place to eat. Well, silly us. It was after all Saturday night and the place we originally tried to go to was booked up for the entire evening. Luckily for us, we happened into Piqueo's. They had room for us before a group with a reservation was to come in if we ate in a timely manner. 

The great thing was coming with a group of friends who all love to try new things, have great taste in food and wine ( and friends) and we all love to share! We ordered-

Duck quesadilla-fantastic
Paella-wonderful
Cebiche-fresh and tangy-delicioso.
Short ribs-succulent

I loved each dish more than the nex,t although in my mind, the duck quesadilla was a standout. I have to say though-my all time favorite thing wasn't even something we had to order-it was the starter that is provided as an appetizer...the garbanzos with a sort of salsa fresca. The garbanzos are fried and tossed with tomato and other fresh ingredients and I couldn't get enough of them!

My friends and I were totally satiated and want to go back to try all the items we missed. This might take many trip to the City. Darn-a tough job, but someone's got to do it!!
author: Andrea K.

description: Had a nice experience here several years ago, so we came back. The place is noisy and you are crammed next to the other tables. To make it even worse, they were playing loud music, making it impossible to have a conversation across the table. When we asked if they could turn down the music, we were told that the owner liked it that way. So we left, and found a great, quiet sushi place up the street. I will Never return to this facility.
author: Robert K.

description: Wow wow wow! Seriously one of the best meals I've had in SF and that's saying a lot. Each dish we got was delectable. My favorites were the ceviche mixto, the beef empanadas and the yucca fries.  Wine and ambiance are delicious too.  Go for a date or any other special meal.
author: Annie N.

description:
Bernal Heights is tucked away from the hubbub of SF and it looks a bit rough around the edges at first glance, but nevertheless, it's family-friendly. Piqueo's brings a bit downtown aura to this area.

This restaurant labels itself as a tapas place but the portions are actually pretty generous. The menu is dizzyingly extensive, with probably about 40 dishes being offered from appetizers, tapas plates, entrees, sides, salads, etc.  Given the offerings on the menu, it took us awhile to choose. Also, quite a few tweaks are needed on the chef's part taste-wise. The presentation looks nice on the plate, albeit heavy handed on the sauces. 

I was excited to start the evening with a nice chilled glass of sangria.  Fruity enough for my taste, but at $8 a glass, I was only given a half full one.  (or half-empty, you decide). Either way, I was not pleased with the serving.

The complimentary fried chickpeas is # 82 on the Big Eats SF list. Crunchy chickpeas mixed with white corn, salty feta, finely chopped red onions and lime. You won't miss bread and butter with this healthy starter.

The ceviche mixto ($16) had mussels, octopus, shrimp and halibut, served with white corn and roasted sweet pepper on the side. The lime juice and red onions make for a sour-slightly spicy taste that I liked. Ingredients were fresh but for really good ceviche, try La Mar. 

The grilled NY steak ($28) needed more seasoning. It was also tough to cut and the adobo sauce it was served on was lackluster. 

The fried plantains ($6) were sauteed in brown sugar and butter, topped with powdered sugar. This is more soft than crispy but still good.

I was curious about the Tequenos ($12) which is pastry dough filled with shrimp and mozz cheese, fried and topped with powdered sugar and honey. Crispy and honestly, not too sweet, but you know what? the sauce they used on this was the exact same one for the next dish! Our empanditas de mi abuela were filled with slices of tender beef and melted cheese. Very good, but having this dish right after the tequenos, it kinda tasted the same. 

Camarones al ajo had succulent shrimp brimming with garlic flavor, thanks to the sofrito garlic paste it was cooked in.  Served with baguettes topped with mild salsa.

The duck quesadilla with goat cheese was probably the favorite of the night. At this point, we were already full, but I couldn't stop eating this!

Service was inconsistent but we didn't have to wait long for our dishes. Our waiter who started us off with our meal was probably on the end of his shift, he brought out the first couple of dishes and disappeared. A second server took over for him. But there wasn't any transition between the two which was kinda confusing.

Overall, Piqueo's has room for improvements. If they scale down their menu to focus more on select dishes and improve on their service, this could be a really great neighborhood restaurant.
author: Janice C.

description: I live a few blocks away. Have frequented this location a lot.  Unfortunately, I am NEVER going back!  My husband and I made an OpenTable reservation for 5 pm. We were the only ones there. It took 15 minutes to get acknowledged. We weren't offered water, bread etc. a "waiter" finally decided to walk over to us just to aggressively demand our order. Service was poor, waiter was so rude we left.  Poor service, high prices and not kid friendly!!!!!
author: marimar s.

description:
A very nice surprise!

Peruvian food has become one of my favorite cuisines recently. Meat, fish and more meat? Yes please.

Piqueo's really hit the spot. Great service (i.e. quick and friendly), romantic atmosphere (i.e. cozy and dimly-lit) and delicious food. We started off with the Ceviche Mixto and were not disappointed as it was very tasty and sizable.

Next up were the beef heart anticuchos and seared tuna, both succulent. The sides were especially plentiful and flavorful, including the sauces, tacu tacu, fried banana & potatoes.

I will definitely be back!
author: Teiki K.

description:
Location: this place is well located away from the heart of the city. So easy street parking and less crowded.
Reservation: I took reservation for 11 people through Open Table. We were seated not in the main restaurant but way at the back. It seemed like a storage turned into a seating area. It was very dimly lit and even on a cold SF day, we were all feeling extremely warm there. There was no air conditioning in that area. 
Service: It was flaky. The server came to take our orders once and forgot us for a long time. We literally had to call out for him. Finally, after much wait, we could go ahead with our order. Over the course of the evening, service was not that great. It was okay. 
Drinks: We had sangria, wine, beer and so on. Sangria was a little diluted and was not the best. It seemed like I was having a glass of red juice with fruits. The wine collection was definitely better.
Food: This was the best part of the restaurant and deserved all stars for it. We ordered calamaris, crab cakes, pork adobo, pulled pork, some chicken, mushrooms, ahi tuna fish dish, ceviche, yucca balls, plantain, lamb chop, seafood paellas and so much more. Every dish was delicious and was simply mouthwatering good. I loved the pulled pork and the crab cake and the seafood paellas was to die for. 
Our bill was a freaking $700 + dollars, but was worth it with such amazing food. 
So overall, go there for the food, not the service. Its a small place and look into the seating arrangements before taking reservations.
author: Lisa H.

description:
This is more a Latin fusion restaurant - they have things on the menu like "fried wonton shrimp." I wouldn't go here if you're looking for an authentic Peruvian meal. The food is okay but generally everything is over-sauced. As in drenched and dripping, which makes it difficult to figure out if the actual food is good quality, cooked/flavored well, etc because all you can taste is sauce. Some things are also oddly sweet, and not in a good way - for example, powdered sugar dusted on some of the savory dishes, typically savory meat dishes in sweet marinade. Very limited wine list.

Service isn't great - we waited for about 10 minutes before anyone came by to give us water, another 15 minutes before someone took our order. I thought plate service was strange too - they brought out the dishes one by one, as if each one were its own course. If this is how tapas is supposed to be served, please excuse my ignorance, but when it's small plates and you're with a party of five, it is annoying for everyone to get a bite then wait, get a bite then wait, get a bite then wait 12 times over. And it takes forever. I think a few dishes at a time would've made more sense and the meal more enjoyable. Plus it would've turned the tables faster and the restaurant could accommodate more customers.

It's a cute, small space and the ambiance is nice; tables are a little too close together. Food is fine, nothing worth making a special trip to. Overpriced for what you get - if prices were more reasonable, I'd give it three *s.
author: Janice J.

description: I visited Piqueo's last weekend with my boyfriend while we were in town. It was a great experience. We had Sangria which was pretty good and we ordered the Lomo Saltado and the Aji de Gallina. The food was really flavorful and the service was great! We will definitely be coming back here. :)
author: Marlene B.

description:
I had heard for years about how excellent the food is at Piqueo's, but hadn't made it until last night. I was pleased to be able to make a reservation for 2 on a Saturday afternoon for that evening; I wanted to take a friend out for her birthday dinner, and this seemed the perfect opportunity to try Piqueo's. Indeed, the food was delicious, but I will never go back, and here is why:

At 7 pm (our reservation) our table was not ready, which was fine as my friend was running a few minutes late. She arrived, and we waited for a larger party to be seated, and then were shown to our table at 7:15. The service was prompt; we took the waiter's recommendations and ordered 4 items off the tapas menu, which were all excellent, along with a couple of beers. We had a nice meal, and declined dessert, as we were pretty full from the rich tapas, and then paid the check which had arrived immediately after declining dessert.

My friend still had about a third of her beer left in her glass when the hostess leaned over and told us that she was sorry, but our table was needed for another reservation so we had to leave. Startled, we started gathering our things and my friend guzzled the rest of her beer. I checked my watch: 8:07. We had occupied the table for less than an hour and we were already being hustled out the door. At that point the crowd had actually thinned and there didn't appear to be anyone waiting for a table, and in fact there were other empty tables.

Way to ruin an evening! Needless to say, we felt like crap having been so summarily tossed out and made to feel so unwelcome.  What had started out as such a nice evening ended very abruptly and badly. I have never been treated this way by any restaurant staff in SF or elsewhere and still can't believe that this is acceptable treatment anywhere. It left an unpleasant taste that completely replaced the pleasure we had taken in the food itself. I doubt I will ever be moved to return for a second try.
author: Wanda S.

description: My partner & I really love this place! The food is so fresh & full of flavor. We got a few of the tapas to share - Palta Rellena, Bolitas de Yucca; shared an entree Seco de Cordero and chocolate lava cake as dessert...left very full and satisfied! This place is better suited for small groups, and perfect for date nights
author: Sarah S.

description: First taste of Bernal Heights as a new resident and this is already a top in SF! Ceviche was fresh, clean, and savory. The crab cake was hands down the best in my life. Limo soltado...forgetaboutit! Great place, great service, delicious food!
author: Laura P.

description: I had given Piqueos 5 stars on my past visits. My partner and I went with my daughter and her new BF for dinner there . We weren't given the table we requested and had been promised but they did call us a bit before to inform us. The food was interesting and excellent as usual but when we finished our meal the server came over and told us we had to leave bc they needed the table for the next party. Mind you we had been there for 1 hr and 40 minutes and spent $200. We felt like garbage being thrown out of the place. No way to treat return customers who give them 5 star reviews on Yelp. We were all shocked and embarrassed. Will not return!!!
author: Maria R.

description:
I'm picky about Peruvian food for no reason other than having had delicious home cooked meals from a Peruvian friend.  I loved her causa so I tend to order it whenever I see it on a menu.  We got the causa, tuna tartare, sanguchon, pobrecito and the yucca fries to go.  Tintin loved the pobrecito, so for that alone, we'll probably be back.  I liked the tuna tartare the best.  The causa was not exactly what I was expecting.  The potato part was great, but the shrimp and chicken salad like mixture was runny.  I thought the sanguchon was too sweet, but Tintin liked the sweet and salty balance.

I want to try the empanadas and lomo before I make my final decision on the place, but I know already that I liked it much better than another restaurant owned by the same people, La Constanera.
author: Seong P.

description: Food was epic, but the timing was a little fast. We went here for our anniversary dinner and they seated us right away. We ordered a ton of food, but were done in under an hour. Ideally when we're not with the kids, I'd prefer for things to be a little slower. This is funny given that one recent review (about the same time we went on 8/7) complained of slow service. I guess you can't win for losing, eh?
author: carli m.

description:
I went here last night with my bestie, who I traveled to Peru with a couple of years ago.  We wanted to reminisce about our trip there and the amazing, out of this world, ceviche that we had there.  I thought that nothing could compare to those acidic pieces of fish, washed down by a nice cold and crisp bottle of cusequena.  That was until I had the seafood ceviche at Piqueo's.  

Though it wasn't exactly the same, it was still amazing.  From the first bite, I felt as though I was back in Peru experiencing the culture, tastes and sounds.  It was acidic and heavenly.  And the cusequena was perfect.  I highly recommend the ceviche.  HIGHLY.  You cannot come here without getting it.

We also shared the Camarones al Ajo, which was waaaaaay too sweet for us.  Tasted a bit like a shrimp dessert.  It was a recommendation from our waiter and was supposed to be one of the highlights of the menu.  But, it was not a favorite.  

Our last shared plate was the Humita Dulce, which was very tasty.  Especially since I never thought that I was one to enjoy sweet corn.  But, it was very tasty.  I was pleasantly surprised.

This was a great restaurant and has become one of my favorites in the city.  I will definitely come back.  I just added it to my rotation.
author: Jenn S.

description:
I will start off by saying that the food is pretty decent, albeit WAY overpriced. The service however, was some of the most horrendous I've ever had (and I'm from philly).  

We arrived 30 minutes after the restaurant opened there were only two other people in the restaurant. The hostess was incredibly rude, sat us down. It took the waiter 15 MINUTES to come over to ask what we wanted to drink.

I couldn't get out of this place fast enough. If I'm paying $13 for one "empanada" (really just stewed beef in puff pastry - that's not an empanada) I at least expect the waiters pretend for a whole 5 seconds of interaction like they don't actually wanna kill themselves. 

Awful
author: Carmen J.

description: SO AMAZING! Came for my 31st birthday and literally not a single bite disappointed. We got 8 shared plates and a paella, and I can't even decide which was my favorite because each dish was so good. I'd come back in a heartbeat. Get everything-I don't think it's possible to go wrong.
author: Courtney W.

description: Wonderful experience! Service is charming, ambience is lovely, food is excellent. We got the Lomo Saltado and Arroz Con Pato. Both were delicious - perfectly seasoned, tender meat, beautiful vegetables. And then we ordered the Passion Fruit Panna Cotta and everything around us melted away, the room was silent and the only thing I knew was that I had just taken the best bite of anything in my entire life. Luscious, aromatic and decadent. Please go! Please order the Panna cotta! My girlfriend actually had tears in her eyes, she loved it so much.
author: Hanna H.

description:
Peruvian food in Bernal heights? Bernal heights is an upcoming small community located by Glen park. My friend and I were driving around the neighborhood and decided to grab a bite to eat. Inside the restaurant has a modern lay out of white linen & candles surround the venue. When we walked in, the host asked if we had reservations? umm the restaurant was completely empty! lol My next question was do you have a happy hour menu? her response was what's that? LOL *le sigh* 

Any who, for starters they brought out their complimentary fried chickpeas-results? it was cool, I know this is on the 7x7 sf list but I wasn't thrilled about it. We ordered the Chino-Peruano aka Ahi tuna with aji rocoto-tamarindo, leche de tigre & crispy wontons. -Flavors were good, dish was filing and the tamarind sauce went well with the tuna. Our next dish was the Emapandas hmmmmmm filled with beef. The presentation of our empanada looked like a croissant, drizzled with their special sauce. Results? I liked it! The empanada has the same exact taste as a croissant but baked with meat inside-flavors? like BBQ sauce inside weird huh? Our last meal consisted of Yucca and sausages-I'm not quite sure of the name because I can't find it on the menu. I was not impressed by this item-extract? like a hot dog with potatoes minus the bread! The dressing smothered on top was ketchup, mustard and a mystery sauce. 

Overall-Meh. I've experienced better.
author: Kathy V.

description:
This restaurant is now my favorite, the food is just amazing, watching the Chefs cook was a cool experience, the service was good as well, they were nice and always had a smile on their face, gave us water whenever they seen our glasses was 
empty. 

I would definitely come back, everything about this Restaurant is Worth it (:
author: Sanet A.

description:
Groupon deal brought me here. Glad we tried it, but not rushing to go back.

The ambiance is very "mission"-y , dark walls with candle-lit intimate sized tables.  This was a plus.  Lots of different food options, I went for my default lomo saltado.  I thought it was good, but not as good as rotisserie or fresca.

The service was a bit odd. The hostess asked us to wait for a table despite the fact that there were 2 open tables and I could clearly see on the reservation screen that there were 2 other reservations for 15 minutes after us.  Servers also took a good 15-20 minutes to clear our entrees despite walking by several times and the place not being full.

Overall food was good, but not spectacular for the price.  $70 for party of 2, 2 appetizers, 2 entrees and no wine.
author: Melody T.

description:
This really should be 4.5 stars. This review is for dinner on a Tuesday night. Like much of Peruvian cuisine, it's all about the sauce. I read some review saying there was little differentiation between the sauces. I could not disagree more. In fact, the progression from one dish to the next is what will bring me back to this outstanding little restaurant. 

Service was quite good. Wine list was small, but solid. Among other items, we had the Aji de Gallina and it was incredible. Really a stand out. Also good - the Quinoa salad, the short ribs, and the Bolitas de Yucca. I'm definitely coming back.
author: Jay N.

description:
On a cold and windy Monday night, the gf and I decided to walk around Bernal Heights to grab a bite to eat. After being outside in the cold and reading the menu on the window, we were sold with the heavenly-sounding entrees. 

Because there were two of us, we were seated right away near the entrance and began perusing the menu, unsure of what to choose - everything sounded amazing...from causas to cebiche to octopus and more, we had to have the waiter come over to help us decide. After selecting the paella clasica and slow-braised lamb (seco cordero), we then began inspecting the funny-looking circular appetizers in front of us. Apparently they are chickpeas, but it was almost like crack popcorn, and we couldn't stop eating them...a sign that we couldn't wait to eat our meal.

After waiting for a while, the entrees came out looking and smelling fantastic. The lamb was very tender, falling off the bone, and also came with white beans that were nice and soft. I was surprised b/c I actually got more lamb than I initially thought. My lovely date ordered the paella, which had just the right amount of spice that gives that peppery taste at the end, and it was pretty populated with different kinds of seafood, which we appreciated. AND we ended up with leftovers. Nice.

Overall, a fair-priced and delicious meal that I cannot wait to go back to so as to try some of the tapas!
author: Brandon Y.

description: My favorite restaurant in the world!  Everything is fresh, innovative, beautifully prepared, and delicious. The staff is very helpful, but not at all intrusive- my only regret is that I live 400 miles away.
author: Mary P.

description:
Incredible Peruvian food but the absolute best thing on the menu is the desert-Suspiro.  It is to die for.  Each bite is like heaven.  The only bad thing about it is when it's gone!!!
Good service, people are patient and friendly.  They accidentally put In our order wrong and gave us another version of what we ordered. But they ended up not charging us for the dish.  A very professional thing to do and much appreciated. I bring friends and family in from out of town and try to go at least 1x a month.
I look forward to the next visit and suspiro!!
author: Jennifer L.

description: Came here to celebrate my birthday we were seated fast. The Lomo saltado was delicious with tender pieces of meat and crispy fries. Had a passion fruit panna cotta was made to perfect just threw me off with the arroz con leche on the plate. It didn't go well together but separately amazing. I will be back to see what else is on the menu.
author: Daisy R.

description: what a great experience I've had every time I come to eat here. phenomenal food, service , and atmosphere of the restaurant. Highly recommend piqueos.
author: Quinlan N.

description: Made a reservation through open table arrived a little bit early and our table was ready. The fried garbanzos were ssooooo goood!!! We ordered a Lomo Saltado, Aji de Gallina, Scallops ficho,Tequeños, Yucca Balls and a pitcher of sangría. Service was outstanding and our food arrived accordingly. All of the food was so delicious!! We came here for a girl's night and then fact that the service and food were great we were able to have a nice reunion. Coming back soon!
author: Brillit S.

description:
Absolutely the best Peruvian restaurant I've found in the city thus far. I took several friends visiting from out of town here for their last night. They were in awe. Every dish was fantastic and the sangria was excellent. My third time here and it never ceases to amaze me. 

Great place for foodies, dates, or really any occasion.
author: Rich L.

description: I cannot give negative stars for the crazy amount of food poisoning from a chicken dish there. My ex wife, my mother, and I went there and my son skipped the meal. Three out of four of us spent 24 hours pouring fluids from front and back debating which end to do first. I prayed for death but did not receive it so I instead get to remember the pain and share how awful that food experience was to my family with all of you. It might be worth mentioning the service was okay at best. I will probably never return.
author: David B.

description: We went here for B-day & anniversary dinner with friends. It was convenience for us to make a reservation through Round-table. Yet, This little nice place won't make the dinner special unfortunately... Having said that, all dishes we ordered were delicious. Apparently, there were 2 cooks in the open kitchen yet only one guy was cooking all orders. Pretty amazing with frequent fire going up. My minus points are for noise, which we could barely hear access the table.. and slightly slow servers, who did not bring saving spoons a fee times even though we said we share all dishes with 4 of us... But we will be definitely going back for good dishes.
author: K T.

description: We really enjoyed everything about this restaurant, the food, the service and the ambience. We ordered Lomito al Jugo which was amazing the French fries really make this dish. We also ordered the Chino Peruano which had some much flavor. We accidentally ordered Pulpito Beb which is baby octopus this turned out to be really great. We will definitely be back.
author: Paul D.

description: Unbelievably delicious, every single dish! The scallops and the salmon with squid ink were amazing! Sangria is great too! Scallops were the favorite of the evening!
author: Liza P.

description: Very good food with a nice creative touch which shows that the kitchen cares and aren't just going through the motions...service needs tightening,some of the staff seemed like they wanted to be elsewhere and the service in general could have been a little more professional.
author: james m.

description:
This place never fails! I have been here several times since 2011, and every time I leave wondering what took me so long to come back (eh may have to do with the fact that the restaurant is in Bernal).

The ambiance is very romantic and intimate - cool drop lights, a central kitchen, and they play great Peruvian music that might make you want to dance after a few glasses of wine.

To start the give you complimentary fried garbanzo beans with spices and onions. Delicious, and a welcome change from the standard bread and butter. 

Every tapas dish I have had here is amazing. I always get the cevice de pescado- so spicy and citrusy, the fried plantains are sweet and flavorful, and the pork ribs are decadent and a must order. 

I will definitely be back!
author: Kerry M.

description:
Charming, cozy spot that completely exceeded my expectations (which were pretty high given that my friend was already talking the place up). 

I really enjoyed the ahi tuna ceviche and the spinach & queso empanada - plus some other starter they threw in there (some kind of hominy / fried chickpeas mixture - yum!). We also ordered the quinoa encrusted prawns which I wasn't AS big a fan of (the sauce was ok) but was still pretty great - just paled in comparison to the rest of the food. 

Service was fantastic and I was able to make pretty last minute reservations on a Saturday night (I love you, Bernal). Can't wait to go back!
author: Richa A.

description:
I could fall in love with Peruvian cuisine after dining at both Mochica and Piqueos.  Similar menus with slight variations.  

My favorites included the beef empanada.  People always tell me they love empanadas.  I never understand why.  Everytime I get them, it's always dry on the inside.  This wasn't like that.  Oh wow!!!  Nice outer crust and beautiful meat inside.  Yum!!!

Ceviche with shrimp, mussels, and snapper.  I think I've become a ceviche fan.  Just perfection!  Really.  Perfect acidity balanced with flavor while showcasing the proteins themselves.  

These were my top two of the eight dishes that we ate that evening.  Honestly, it's hard to find any fault with any of the dishes.  I'm not sure there is a bad one in the house.  Terrific service and great food.  What more can you ask for?
author: Chrys S.

description:
I don't know what it is with Peruvian food that makes me like it so but I love it.  Piqueo's, like it's sister restaurant, Mochica, just offers the best possible Peruvian dishes I have experienced.

Piqueo's plating of dishes is different from that of Mochica's but it still delivers the same great taste.  

The dishes that captivated me the most were:
Creamy Mushroom Potato Soup - $8
Pulpito Bebe - Complimentary
Beef Empanada Peruana - $8
Churrasco A La Parilla - $24
Cebiche Mixto - $16
Suspiro A La Limena - $8

The dishes that were good but just OK to me were:
Chicharronnes De Pollo - $12
Calamar Relleno - $19

The Creamy Mushroom Soup was just fantastic.  It was rich, thick, and had an overpowering taste of mushroom and potato that just had me wanting more and more.  It could be that my love for mushrooms and potatoes superseded an unbiased thought from me, but who cares.  It tasted good to me!

My table was later introduced to the Beef Empanada Peruana, Cebiche Mixto, and Churrasco A La Parilla.  The beef empanada was good.  The outer crust was crunchy.  The beef was tender and hinted a bit of sweetness in it that reminded me of my grandmother's empanadas from long ago.  The Cebiche Mixto was extraordinary.  And, the Churrasco A La Parilla was classic.  The strip of beef was just done perfectly and the yucca fries that came with it were just incredible.

We were later given a complimentary order of Pulpito Bebe that we humbly accepted.  I love octopus!  I definitely appreciated their gesture of kindness since octopus is one of my favorite dishes.  That gesture of kindness though led us to loosen our belts just a little as the meal progressed.

We finished our meal with the Chicharronnes De Pollo and Calamar Relleno.  The Calamar Relleno is a giant squid filled with Spanish chorizo.  I'm not a big fan of giant squids.  They usually taste rubbery and tough to me.  Fortunately, Piqueo's delivered something pretty edible that tasted decent.  I don't know how we did it, as stuffed as we were, but we managed to finish a flavorful Chicharronnes De Pollo.  It had a bit of kick to it, I have to admit.  It could have knocked me out since I was so full.

As full as the three of us were, we still managed to share a dessert, the Suspiro A La Limena.  It was nothing original but it tasted wonderful.

Piqueo's, to me, is what small San Francisco restaurants have always been - an intense environment that caters to adventurous palates.  Piqueo's is a great place to take a date, enjoy a meal with friends or family, or dine alone at the counter as you overlook your meal being cooked by the chef.  Piqueo's epitomizes what Bernal Heights has become.  Simply, cool!
author: Jules S.

description:
My Second Visit, this time with my hubby who is SO PICKY!! Very clean eater (we own a fitness center).  He only eats organic veges and free range (both of which Piqueos serves) whew!

We first ordered the Quinoa salad the veges were organic and fresh with ingredients of mixed greens, peruvian corn, red onions, feta cheese, tomatoes, green apples, whole black garlic marinated olives, aji amarillo vinegarette, tossed with ample amounts of quinoa...omg one of the best salads ever ... one plate enough for 4 people (single portions he LOVED it. 

For appetizers, I ordered the Yucca trio dip which he loved the combinations of flavors of the guacamole, queso, and honey.Also,  I tried the chilled pervian mashed potatoe stacked over avocado and topped with chilled marinated octopus and shredded aji , with a spicy sauce lightly dribbled over it..amazing. 

For Main Course, My husband LOVED the wild alaskan salmon (chef special). I could barely finish my braised ribs sitting on a thin layer of pervian mashed potatoes, thickly sliced yellow potatoes, braised ribs on top with a rich and delicious redwine and tomatoe sauce (not chunky) over the top with swirls of guacamole lightly over the top...
Of course due to the heat wave we in SF were experiencing, I opted for the best sangria ever...thanks to my gf's recommendation..I normally don't drink sangria because it is too sweet, but this sangria is PERFECT!

 Our waitress was WONDERFUL and I was so happy and relieved that my husband actually is going to RECOMMEND this place to one of his clients!

I would say our date night was a huge sucess! :)
author: Daisy G.

description:
We absolutely love Piqueo's sister restaurant Mochica and are regulars there. We've tried Piqueo's once and loved it. We decided to go back there again. 

The restaurant is not big, but cozy. It is  also in a not too busy neighborhood, so parking is not too difficult. 

Their menu is different than Mochica's, but there's some similarity such as the ceviche, seafood paella, etc. 

We ordered the crab cake, seafood paella, stuffed calamari, and the scallop dish. They were ALL great. We especially liked the seafood paella, the seafood was fresh, the risotto was creamy and flavorful. And it also had some spicy kick to it. It was absolutely tasty.

We were quite satisfied with their recommendation for the wines as well. We wished we had room for their desserts! 

We would go back there in no time! I would totally order the seafood paella again. :)
author: Kai Y.

description:
Just had dinner here and it was AMAZING! I have been a little obsessed with Peruvian food ever since the first time I tried ceviche and lomo saltado just a year ago. The flavors are just so well balanced and I don't think I could ever get sick of it! 

We tried the ceviche pescado, beef heart skewer, shrimp curry, beef short rib with a red wine sauce, and seared scallops. Every dish was pretty phenomenal, but standouts were the seared scallops, shrimp curry, and beef short rib. Each of those sauces were just packed with flavor. Really great dishes to try if you've never had Peruvian food! 

-Seared scallops were perfectly cooked, nice char on the outside (not burnt) and just cooked on the inside. The sauce carried a hint of heat but didn't overpower the scallops.
-Shrimp curry had great flavor as well. The curry sauce I could not get enough of! 
-Beef short rib, again, had great flavor! Not overly salty in the sauce, which had just the slightest hint of tartness. Couldn't get enough of this sauce either! The short rib could have been just a tad more tender though, but that's just my personal preference. 
-Ceviche was great too, but a little on the acidic and spicy side. It left our mouths burning a little and definitely wanting some bread to calm the heat. 
-Beef heart skewer was good texture-wise. Flavor wise it reminded me a little bit of teriyaki beef jerky, but with a little more gaminess and chipotle-like heat. 

I can't wait to come back and try more dishes, especially the seafood paella and aji de gallino. 

Make a reservation, the place is pretty small and gets packed.
author: Grace C.

description: O think so far this is the best peruvian food i had ...... Im peruvian inwould know cheap and big portions authentic not that white wash type of shit like limon,fresca......
author: Javier E.

description:
We were in Peru last year, and the food here is comparable to some of the best we had there. In particular, anything with corn or avocados. The highlight was Palta Rellena (outstanding). We also had the Quinoa Salad (ok), the yucca fries (a little thinner than the ones in Peru, which made the center a bit crispy and not tender like in Peru, but excellent nonetheless), and the Pastel de Choclo (my wife loved it). The chef comped us a small side of marinated fried beans and white corn, which was a nice touch and also very good.

The service is a mix of friendly and matter of fact, but competent.
author: Ashish G.

description: Phenomenal birthday night! We had a party of six, and it was a fantastic evening. I applaud my husband for picking this place. We started with very good sangria, and ordered a slew of plates to share. Everything was truly fantastic -- there wasn't a low note in the bunch. Highlights included the duck quesadillas, the short ribs braised in red wine, and the quinoa prawns. The desserts were also fantastic -- the lava cake was heaven, and everyone plotzed over the dulce de leche topped with port wine whipped cream. Seriously, we could not stop crowing over our meal. And the waiter was a sweetheart. I told him we'll be back as often as possible!
author: Brooke H.

description:
Update review: Three stars for the food, 2 for the service. 

Our meal started poorly when the waiter spilled a glass of wine on me.  That was the lowest point, but we were also served the wrong appetizer (which appeared on our check, even though we sent it back).  Finally, our vegetable side dish didn't arrive until we were nearly done with our entrees -- and we had to remind the waiter that we'd ordered it.  Fortunately, the food (a duck quesadilla, squid ink paella, and garlicky spinach) was tasty, and they comp'd our first round of drinks.  

I'd go back, but not eagerly and I won't make a habit of it.
author: Robert W.

description: I went here with a group of 6 for a birthday dinner with a reservation. As we sat down everyone was having fun, talking and laughing. It took us a while to even look at the menu--a sign of a group of folks having fun! The waiter came over about 2-3 times asking if we wanted anything to drink or order within the space of about 10-15 minutes. The 2nd or 3rd time he seemed to be getting annoyed, leaving quickly even as we started discussing what we might want. No one was really making decisions yet. Finally he stopped coming by for about 10-15 minutes. I actually caught the waiter rolling his eyes as the one most boisterous friend started making jokes. I know we weren't the easiest group to wait on, but hey, rolling eyes is totally rude! Finally someone in our group just ordered food for everyone. As far as I recall the waiter never came by again and never asked if we needed any more drinks or food. I believe one of my friends went to ask the hostess to bring over a birthday dessert with a candle which was nice. The food was ok, pretty fried for the most part. A lot of sweet flavored, not particularly my favorite dinner dish. I don't think I would come back with a big group. I'm not sure if I would come back at all... Hard to say. But at least we had fun!
author: Alex S.

description:
I haven't been to Bernal Heights, so I was surprised on how cute this neighborhood is!

Piqueo is a tiny restaurant with a friendly vibe. It's dark and romantic, however the usual Bernal crowds (family with kids) makes it a bit more casual too. I love the intimacy.

Plus:
- Service is attentive.
- My bf ordered the chicken dish, which name we forgot. The chicken is flavorful. However the portion is pretty tiny.
- I ordered the paella negra, which is really good and comes with a good portion.

Minus:
- The maitre'd lost my reservation until I showed her the OpenTable email.
- We ordered the yucca ball as appetizer which is a meh.

Nevertheless, we had a good experience. Will go back!
author: Novalina N.

description:
Quality food, nice atmosphere, and I would have wanted to return again...until we were asked to leave by the hostess while we were still finishing our wine. We had company visiting from out of town and this was a very sour ending to what could have been a high quality dinning experience. We made a reservation, bought two bottles of wine for the group, and we were enjoying our meal until we were asked to leave after an hour and a half because they needed our table. I've never been asked to leave an establishment like that, especially when we had put in our proper dues for our space and time. I understand that a restaurant  has to conduct business and that includes attending to all customers needs, but we were never informed of a time limit, and we were the present customers. 

Again, the quality of the food and atmosphere were above par until the good service came to a stop as soon as we paid the bill. The "manager on duty" gave a simple "sorry" and left it at that, a disappointing ending.
author: Rosalba D.

description: Amazing food and service.  I just loved every bite of food served to me here.  Highly recommend the ceviche and fried yucca balls, I order those every time I come and they are always great.
author: Stacy D.

description:
Are we in Machu Picchu yet?? Gee, we went up that hill on a narrow trail. I think I saw Incas. Oh wait...never mind, there's MaggieMudd...where the hell are we?

Bernal Heights is not really a neighborhood you can just stumble upon ....you have to make a very specific detour in, for me, relatively unchartered waters. Driving up Cortland from either side of the hill, if feels like you've landed in Hooterville as reimagined by Stephen King. Even the excessive windiness there brings an eerie feeling of isolation. And lots of dogs...and smiling dog walkers. Kinda like a cult....know what I mean?

Into this palpable atmosphere are a sprinkling of culinary gems like Liberty Cafe and Little Nepal. This is a new one for me, and I liked it. I liked it a lot. If Destino is your cup of pisco, then you need to try Piqueo's. It's higher-end Peruvian, and I think the small plates are the way to go, at least the first time, to get a broad sampling of their food.

I went with my friends Jonathan and Syd last night, and while calling them food snobs would be the pot belly calling the kettle fat, I know the palate plateau is raised every time we go out. The first plate served was the $8 Choritos ala Chalanaca - three New Zealand mussels topped with chopped tomatoes and onions, those big Peruvian kernels of white corn, and slathered in a special lime juice. It's been so long since I've had the meaty NZ mussels that it was heaven on a designer plate even if it was a bit overflowing in the juice.

The second plate was the $9 Pollito, which were chunks of fried chicken - very fresh-tasting chicken with papitas doradas and a spicy tartar sauce. This was absolutely the dish of the night. If KFC was reinvented by Michael Mina, I am confident this would be it. This was followed by the $10 Pastelito de Choclo, probably the safest bet among the small plates. It's one robust corn cake made up with softened potatoes and those same big white kernels, mixed with saffrito and a Mexican white cheese with a fresh salsa on top.

The $10 Tomatoes Rellenos was our last plate - a baked tomato stuffed with piquilo and mozzarella cheese served with yet another different tangy salsa. Believe it or not, with just these four plates plus the ramekin of special Peruvian beans and other spreadable paraphernalia served with our bread at the beginning, the three of us were pretty satisfied leaving just enough room for dessert, again my biggest downfall. 

But Piqueo's has at least two excellent desserts. One is the $8 Flan de Camote - a total rethink of the classic Mexican flan where they somehow blend in sweet potatoes. The taste is there, and the consistency a bit heavier as a result. But it works magically especially with the orange-canela sauce. The other is the $9 Torta de Chocolate, a perfectly prepared little chocolate cake, moist but not runny and served with a combination of lucuma ice cream (just a tad too frozen but tasty) and caramel sauce. Lucuma is a tropical fruit native to Peru and hard to describe (I think they have it at Mitchell's too)...mmm, good. A nice wine to accompany the meal is the $32 Tempranillo, a Spanish wine from the Rivola winery with a nice, full-bodied cabernet body. Nice finish to it.

Stuffed. Completely. Total bill came to about $47 per person - which we thought was pretty fair given the stellar quality. And the place is nicely decorated with warm colors in a small space with an open kitchen. Service was very attentive, maybe a tad too intrusive during the meal as the three of us were more enraptured with the food than each other. A real dazzler. Not us. Piqueo's.

FOOD - 5 stars...not sure about authenticity...I seem to recall guinea pigs on a stick in Cuzco, but hell, I liked the dishes here...a lot
AMBIANCE - 4.5 stars...smallish but nicely decorated, a warm vibe, probably even better when it's pitch black outside given all the windows (vs. the vault-like feel of Destino)
SERVICE - 4 stars...like I said, attentive is an understatement here...even the busboys who could be paid by the plate
TOTAL - 5 stars...always room for another Peruvian treat destination in the city...Vietnamese is so five minutes ago
author: Ed U.

description: absolutely amazing dinner!  Great food and service.  I wasn't familiar with many of the items on the menu, with 6 of us (including a sous chef) we ordered some of everything.  I can't say which dish was my favorite because it was all so flavorful.  If you're looking for a memorable dining experience, you should definitely check this place out.  You won't be disappointed.
author: Linda V.

description: Ordered 4 tapas plates for two and by the end of the 3rd we were feeling pretty full, so had the rest doggy-bagged to save a little room for desserts.  Didn't care too much for the tuna tartar; not that it was bad, just not for my taste. Innovative creations and nice presentations.  I'd definitely come back to try out other dishes.
author: J L.

description:
I like this place pretty well (four meals in). The service has issues at time (as has been mentioned a number of times), but I think the food is really excellent so I overlook that and come back. Furthermore, it's an easy place to get a reservation for Saturday if you forget to think about it until Thursday or Friday morning. 

I'll just start with the cons, because they are few: 

CONS: 

- The service really is hit or miss. I think they need heavier staffing, as the waiters seem to disappear for 10-15 minutes at a time from the entire seating section they seem to be serving. 

- The food comes out at really random intervals. It'll be like wait, wait, wait, SALAD. Wait, wait, MAC AND CHEESE. Wait, wait, wait, EVERYTHING ELSE YOU ORDERED IN FIVE MINUTES. 

PROS: 

- The food is really excellent. Especially recommended are the tequenos, the adobo, the quinoa salad, the mac and cheese, the yucca with cheese, and the chicharrones. 

- The sangria is really great as well. I assume the wine is fine, but we always order a pitcher of sangria and have never had any reason to order anything else. 

- We ordered something that never came, but ended up on the bill. We were fine with it not having come -- we were stuffed -- but the manager took the item off the bill with minimal hassle. 

- Parking in Bernal is easy. 

Check it out. This goes on the list of places I'd put on "Check Please, Bay Area."
author: Tom P.

description:
Piqueo's (Peruvian Fusion Restaurant) is a quaint and charming restaurant nestled in a quiet Bernal Heights neighborhood. The restaurant is small, but the atmosphere is cozy, modern yet very elegant and the food isabsolutely delicious and artfully displayed. WOW!!
Piqueo's is a perfect setting for sharing delicious tapas and sangria with friends and family.
author: Victoria M.

description:
This place really does deserve more like a 3.5 stars, with a romantic and dim setting decor.  Was excited to try this place with my boyfriend for a dinner date on a random Saturday night.  Bought a $50 coupon off Bloomspot and figured why not try it now?

We've been to their sister restaurant, Mochica, a few months ago and had a great experience.  Food and service were great, so we figured this place wouldn't be too far from that.  

My boyfriend is a big fan of Mac and Cheese, so we ordered one for appetizers.  It came with a baked bread crumbs on top, with bits of bacon in it.  Delicious!  Better than I expected!

For entrees, we ordered the Pork Adobo and Seafood Paella to share.  Needless to say, they did have similar items on their menu.   I was determined to try their seafood paella, because I thought it was the safest and best dish to try to compare the two places.  

Adobo turned out better than I expected.  You can taste that it's been braised and sitting in their sauce.  It was paired with a sweet potato mash, which I've never had before, but tasted great since sweet potato is my fave!  The pork by itself may taste a bit too meaty, but the taste balances out together with the sweet mash.

The paella on the other hand, was not to expectation.  It didn't come out on the hot, iron plates like usual.  It was good, but not great.  Seafood portion was generous, but not enough rice.  Not a good thing for my boyfriend....good enough for me.  

Overall, I think this restaurant is mediocre and its location is a bit out of the way.
author: Nancy S.

description: I agree with other reviews : a solid 4. The food is good and you can share all the tapas. The place is nice. My only caveat is that they were really really rushing us to order.
author: Joanna B.

description:
Great food, terrible service
I'm a regular at this place, it's my favorite neighbourhood restaurant. Unfortunately the staff there is not capable of reliably managing reservations.

Here is my last story: I make a reservation at 6pm for a party of 3 at 7.30 via open table. At 6.30 I get an e-mail that my reservation has been cancelled w/o any explanation. So I call Piqueo's why my reservation has been cancelled and they say because I didn't pick up my phone when they called back (that's only the 1st terrible mistake), after telling the hostess that I am planning on coming with my guests she says she'll fix it. When we show up the place is busy and there is no reservation. The hostess claims she never talked to me on the phone and blames it on Open Table. Even though I recognize her voice. This is not the first time  a reservation goes wrong, therefore I one star it is. Piqueo's fix your reservations and I'll be happy to come back.
author: Jacques C.

description:
Solid 4-stars.  I've been to Piqueo's sister restaurants (Mochica, La Costanera) but never made it to Piqueo's until tonight.  Service was consistently friendly and timely throughout - from the warm greeting walking in to plate clearing in between tapas dishes and water glasses consistently refilled. If we were deep in conversation, the staff backed off and returned later to avoid interrupting.

Dishes were spot-on.  6pm reservations on a Thursday and seated right away.  We had:

1) Ceviche de Pescado: refreshing! Did not mind the addition of red onion (thinly sliced) and yams.

2) Costillita tapas (short ribs): Delicious! The tenderly braised meat was accompanied by polenta-like yucca and a scrumptious tomato sauce.

3) Fried yucca balls: Stuffed with cheese, meats and veggies. Filling!  Served with 2 different sauces on the plate.

4) Suspiro dessert - absolutely exquisite! Fresh, light and the perfect way to end dinner. Highly recommend! And I'm not a dessert fan usually.

We also had a red wine by the glass - the name escapes me now.  I asked for a taste first and our waitress graciously opened a new bottle table-side.

Overall, Piqueos is a hidden gem in the Bernal Heights area and I'll definitely be back!
author: M G.

description:
My worst restaurant experience, ever!

My husband and I had reservations at 5:30.  We get seated around 5:40.  We look over the menu and decide on Cebiche Chino, Pollo al Mani, and Paellas Clasico.

They give a free appetizer of fried garbanzo beans.  I thought they were pretty good, nice and crunchy.

Our cebiche comes out, and it was really flavorful.  Ahi tuna in a tangy, peppery marinade, with some huge Peruvian corn kernels.  Pretty happy so far....but then we wait.

and wait....

and wait....

I think they realize we've waited awhile so they put a second plate of garbanzo beans.  But then again, we wait... we are getting upset because NO ONE says anything to us.  Not "our kitchen is backed up" or "your food will be out in 10 minutes", NOTHING.  While we are waiting, the table next to us (who ordered AFTER us) has their food, and is halfway through their meal.  Same situation to with the couple on the other side of us.  Obviously the kitchen works.  Frustrated, we ask if we can just have our two other dishes to-go.  Then we wait...

and wait...

They give us a bill...

and wait....

and wait...

20 minutes AFTER getting our bill, and a total of AN HOUR AND 25 MINUTES after ordering, we have our food to-go.

We asked for an explanation, and they worker said it was because we a) ordered two entrees b.) we asked our food to-go halfway through the meal c.) it is tapas style, so usually meals take longer and d.) they are dealing with groupons.  We more than willing to wait for food, but SAY SOMETHING.  You can't have customers sitting for 30 minutes with the waitress not checking in, or giving an update.  And how does putting an order to-go take longer, when the chef puts the food on a plate, and the waiter dumps it into a container?!?!  And they aren't cooking the paella from scratch because they scoop two cups of COOKED rice out of a container.

Moral of the story, give your customer some updates!
author: Christina N.

description:
Service was very slow.  We stood by the check in podium for good 5 minutes, not one single person acknowledged our presence nor was apologetic about it.  The time it took them to take our orders and to bring out our food was also super long wait. 

Food was so-so, the PORK ADOBO was dry and lacked flavor, pretty much like boiled meat slobbered with a salty sauce.  DUCK QUESSADILLA was yummy, crispy and loved the sweetness from the carmalized onions in the center.  SEAFOOD PAELLA was too moist and had too little rice, but lots of fish in it though!  However having lettuce and raw onions on top made it an unusual paella, at least quite different from what I have had in Spanish restaurants.

The restaurant looks very nice inside though; lighting, color of the wall, the bar, it's one of the better, newer looking neighborhood restaurants I've been to.
author: Tadaa T.

description: To me, this is very comparable to Mochica and less of a wait! I would say Mochica has SLIGHTLY better food but with smaller portions, making me declare Piqueo's as the winner between these two restaurants!
author: Emily C.

description: Piqueo's is fantastic, inventive, and can host a romantic couple's dinner or a 10 person birthday extravaganza. Everything I have tried here is delicious, but the ahi ceviche, chicharrones, and duck paella are my go-tos. I adore this spot, their atmosphere, and their friendly staff. It is a great addition to the Cortland neighborhood.
author: Ali G.

description: The food is tasty, but be aware that the dishes are on the heavy side.  If you want a green vegetable you will probably need to order a side dish. The night we went, service left a lot to be desired.  They hadn't set our table for the number we reserved, they got our orders wrong, and they overbilled us.  It wasn't a busy night, we were practically the only ones in the restaurant. They did correct the bill after we complained about it.
author: Freestyle S.

description: Decent but generally unimpressive Peruvian food.  Very misleading menus on their website, where beer/wine prices are posted about 30 percent less expensive than they are in the restaurant- house wine and some glasses listed at 6/7, but nothing less than $11 on their menu?! (I brought it up and it seems intentional, they didn't have a good explanation other than it needs to be updated?).  Must be from a couple years ago?  Seemed very dishonest, to lure people in with a bait and switch...  Similarly non-transparent was to charge when we asked for a bit more of the complimentary garbanzo app (we had ordered other apps too).  All of this left a very bad taste in our mouth unfortunately, enough so that I won't return to their sister restaurants either.  Food wise, the ají de gallina was ok, stuffed avocado app was very bland, my mom's pollo borracho was a tiny piece of chicken with a few potatoes for $20... Pretty pricy for the portions you get. If I'm craving Peruvian food, I'll most certainly go somewhere else in the city next time, but I wouldn't return here!
author: Mana B.

description: i'm torn. the food was around 4-5 star worthy but the service took the overall rating down to 1 star. it's as if the chef/owner asked random people on the street if they want to go through the motions of being a server for an evening. FORGET dishes. FORGET drinks. PLOP the food down. PLOP the check down. well now i'm gonna REMEMBER to PLOP this review down.
author: Sanil S.

description: Good spot in the neighborhood...but the truth is their are just a lot of similar places  in the city that have better food for the price. Still great food and a good place to eat, but better options in the city.
author: christopher h.

description: Definitely very tasty food!  And I'm really picky.  Too bad this place is a bit isolated up in Bernal.  I'm guessing weeknights are tough, given neighbors have SO many food options and many of the family folks probably dine in.  It's definitely worth a trip up there for a meal!
author: m h.

description:
I was just here tonight for dinner and it was a good time. I had a Groupon voucher and made reservations via Open Table; made a note that I had a Groupon. The service was great! I wasn't treated like a second-class citizen with my Groupon and I really appreciate that in a business. Our server was awesome; he was attentive but not overly so. He must have spidey-senses because he seemed to intuitively know when we needed his services and he wasn't always just popping in to ask how we were doing.

We started off with a pitcher of Sangria that was well crafted. It was a good blend of fruitness and red wine (and stronger than it tasted - sneaky!). Our first appetizer was the Anticuchones (beef heart) that was quite tasty and unique. Beef heart isn't a typical dish (unless you go to a super-asian restaurant, from my experience). 

Our second appetizer was the Cebiche Mixto and this was totally delicious. There was red snapper, shrimp, clams, and mussels. I don't know if this sounds weird or not, but the seafood was not too fishy tasting which means that the ingredients were fresh. That's always a plus. This was the best dish of the night.

The paella negra is made with squid ink. I am a fan of paella, but in this case, I didn't think the squid ink added to much to the dish. It is also a liability - I wouldn't recommend it for a night with a (new) date, unless you're comfortable with someone seeing your teeth and lips (and fingers, to remove the shellfish shells) turn black. It's temporary and you can wipe your mouth/drink water... but still, just be aware. Lastly, we ordered the Flan con Quinoa and that was also just so-so; not really a dish I would recommend.

I also have to mention that all of our dishes includes roasted corn kernels (like classy corn nuts) and steamed corn. But let me tell you, the steamed corn kernels were huge! If you were a giant, they would seem like regular-sized kernels. I really enjoyed the oversized kernels... they were fun to eat! Additionally, the presentation of the dishes was well-done; they were little pieces of edible art.

Overall, I had an enjoyable time but I don't know if I would come back given the price point.
author: Kim T.

description:
Food Quality - Excellent
Food Taste - Excellent
Food Originality - Excellent
Price - Good
Customer Service - Excellent
Ambiance - Excellent

My favorite Tapas and Peruvian place in SF. Would recommend everyone to definitely try this out.
author: Vibhor C.

description:
Good food - snooty service

We've been here a few times in the past and always enjoyed the food but our most recent visit will be our last.

We stopped by without a reservation and were told we would have to eat at the bar or on the patio--despite several open tables. Not a problem. We asked about heat lamps on the patio. "We have one but don't like to turn it on." OK. We ate at the bar. 
When we left, there will still several open tables. We didn't get a goodbye or a thank you.

There are plenty of other Peruvian restaurants. La Mer is one. That's most likely where we'll go next time.
author: Max T.

description:
The service and ambiance are pretty nice, and the food is quote good--though not the best I've ever had. It's not strictly Peruvian--more of Peruvian/Asian fusion kind of flavor.  The kitchen is open and right in the center of the restaurant, so it can get WARM in there. 

My husband and I ordered four small plates from the tapas menu and it was too much food. We brought some home and were still overstuffed.  We would have been full off of just three plates.  They brought the plates out one at a time, timed pretty perfectly to arrive just when we had finished the previous plate. After the first two plates, though, the staff couldn't seem to remember how many more we should be getting because they kept asking if we were still waiting for another plate.

The yucca balls and pulled pork sandwich were our favorites. The crab cake was kind of meh--large, but not especially flavorful anf with big potato chunks inside. The scallops had a good flavor and were tender, but they were not deliciously flaky/melty and the whole dish was WAY oversalted. I also had a passion fruit soda that was tasty. 

With the four small plates and one drink apiece dinner came out to $65 (including tax) for the both of us. Pretty reasonable for a fun and interesting dinner out.
author: Lauren F.

description: I love this place, although I had a terrible experience with whom I was with! The service is fantastic.
author: Kevin F.

description: Good food. Lots of different options. The service was a tad cold. I told them it was my boyfriend's birthday and they didn't even wish him happy birthday or anything.  Good wine and plantains luckily.
author: Chris D.

description:
Piqeo's is really good. Small, expensive dishes, but definitely worth visiting. 
I
author: isaac t.

description: Oh my, the food is amazing and my server Esther was the best. Gave us really good recommendation, we tried everything she suggested. The ceviche de pescado was so flavorful and the yuca balls  with the cheese and the sauces. The camarones crocantes  where my all time favorite. My boyfriend was amazed, it was his first time trying Peruvian food.  We will defiantly be coming back with our family and friends.
author: Sandra F.

description:
This place is beyond uh-may-zing!! Came here on a Friday night, when they were about to close YET the service was still amazing!

Let's start with this amazing complimentary fried chickpeas that they gave us. They are bomb! Even though they're free, the serving is huge!! And its really tasty! I also had their sangria, made w red wine and it wsa bomb! its a perfect combination of fruit and wine! I also had this really good champagne mixed w passion which was very refreshing! We also had their tequenos which was really tasty! The avocado mousse that came with it was perfect! We also had a few other tapas and everything was amazing! Serving was big and everything was tasty!

The ambiance of the place was also reomantic. The lighting, the tables, the setting! Its perfect for an intimate romantic date with a special special person. This place is totally one of the best few peruvian places in San Fran. Must go if you are or even if you're not in the area!
author: Cathy B.

description:
I bought a Bloomspot for this place because so many people had raved about this place (and I like to try new things!) After work on a Friday, the boyfriend and I headed to Piqueo's.

First of all, the atmosphere of this place is super, super cute. It's the kind of place that I'd want to deem as my "go-to" based on aesthetics themselves. 

Unfortunately, the rest of the experience didn't live up to the hype. Our server, while friendly, was rather judgmental. Given that our Bloomspot was worth $50 bucks, and neither of us were drinking, we decided to try a bunch of different things to which we were asked, "Are you sure you want that much? That's a lot of food!" Umm #judging much? Yes, I am the fattest skinny girl ever- get over it.

We were disappointed that some of the items on the online menu were not actually available. (Duck paella- the item I had my heart set on, could not be made the night we were there). 

We ordered:

1) Some sort of cebiche- of which the boyfriend ate all by himself. I don't like the stuff personally, so I can't comment.

2) Camarones al Ajo- these were fine, but nothing special. It also made me kinda sad that for $15 bucks I got 3 shrimp. Surely, this wasn't worth it.

3) The boyfriend ordered the Paella Classico and neither of us liked it very much. Whatever the taste was, it didn't really sit well with either of us.

4) I ordered a fish dish, which isn't on their online menu. (But the duck paella is- and I couldn't order that!). I wasn't impressed.

5) We also orded a side of spinach- and as delcious as it was- SO OILY!

Had I paid full price for this meal I would have been very, very disappointed.
author: Annalise F.

description:
Piqueo's had always been a hit for me and when I lived closer, used to the my place to take out of town visiters. Always a hit for them too! While their peruvian is pretty good, after having tried several other places around the city now, I'd say this place is average compared to others but could probably give them 3.5 stars.


When I visit, I always have their Ceviche Mixto: Red snapper, mussels & clams, shrimp, red onions, cilantro & aji rocoto leche de tigre. It's always super fresh and very well marinated.

Items I've tried here are: 
 - Crab cheese won tons with guacamole sweet sour sauce.  
 - Empenadas that I remember being some of the best empenadas I've had and almost the size of my fists.
 - Grilled baby octopus with large white beans
 - Crab Cake Peruano
 - Crispy yucca balls stuffed with Ham & cheese. These little guys are pretty damn delicious, what's not to love about deep fried ham and cheese??

Everything is always such a great mix of flavors and I've never left disappointed. But like I said, compared to other places in the city, average, hence the three stars, A-OK. Oh but how could I forget the complimentary fried chickpeas! So tasty and the perfect intro to your dinner. Alright, definitely give them that extra half star for that.
author: Pauline T.

description:
The food here is "A-OK." Definitely not the best Peruvian food in SF. Since the prices aren't cheap, there isn't much reason to go back unless I was in the area.

 I had the tequenos and another appetizer or tapas that was fried mushrooms of some sort. The tequenos didn't have enough flavor but the fried mushrooms thing was delicious (sorry don't remember what it's called). My boyfriend and I shared the seafood paella and one of the ahi tuna plates. Both were fine and satisfying but again since I've had better, there isn't much reason to go back. For dessert we had the lava cake which was amazing. 

The service was good. The restaurant had a nice ambiance to it but it was WAYYY too hot. I was sweating bullets throughout dinner. I recommend you not sit at the bar.
author: Saralee L.

description: I came here with my mother for a nice dinner while visiting from Portland. I very much enjoyed my scallops with blue mashed potatoes and she loved the crabcake Peruano. We finished up with panna cotta and dulce de leche. The panna cotta was topped with passion fruit sauce and a rice sauce. It was a combination of flavors that I was a bit skeptical about upon ordering, and I was very impressed with it. The balance of flavors was perfect and I was pleasantly surprised.
author: Claudia R.

description:
Mehhh, I was pretty disappointed here.  Been here one time before, but this second time around just didn't do it for me. The 7x7 list had me curious about their fried chickpeas, so that explains the second trip.

The restaurant is cute, looks newly renovated w/ new paint and furnished w/ trendy decor. They should've also invested in air conditioning because it got pretty stuffed in there... and it's only Spring.

Service was mediocre. Friendly waitress, but the wait for your food was pretty long.  If it was crowded, I'd expect to wait but we were the only ones there at that time and the food took awhile to get.

We order the fried yucca, calamari, and lamb chops. Didnt realize the fried chickpeas were actually the appetizer, and it was free. Haha, cant believe that the "free" item was the best dish in the house. 

Presentation was the only winner. Every dish came out so pretty to look at, but as alwats looks can be deceiving. The food was edible, but the taste didn't match up to how GREAT the food looked. The yucca balls tasted plain. The lamb chops, which took the longest, was VERY tough to cut and chew, and even tasted burnt. They swapped the lamb & we ordered the braised short rib stew instead. Good dish, but only ONE measly rib came w/ the entree. The calamari was good, but when does calamari ever come out bad?

Overall, I was very disappointed w/ this place. Take it out of Bernal Heights, and please replace it with LIMON ROTISSERIE!! :)
author: Joy A.

description:
got a number of dishes for 5 people. everything was good, but nothing spectacular.

the best dish to me was the papaya rice dish with seafood. very well made, and generous portions.
author: Danielle A.

description: This is an excellent place for tapas and goes well with Sangria. Their cookie desert is perfect climax to an exquisite meal. The ambience is casual and seating is limited and you can hear other conversations. I don't consider this to be a romantic setting but good for casual friends and perfect for a group of four.
