Our bill for four came to ~$140 including a 20% tip. The tapa servings are decent for a group of four. We didn't care to get the entrées as the shared tapas satisfied our culinary desires to the tee.
author: Monish S.

description:
Was here the other night because my friend had a Groupon voucher.

Located in a small neighborhood.  We arrived right after work ~530p so it was not busy and parking was very easy.  It's metered parking on the streets and plenty of parking around the neighborhood.  

Drinks: a carafe of sangria between the two of us was plenty ~2 glasses each.  Pretty fruity tasting.

Food-appetizer: Cebiche de pescado (red snapper with red onions) - very fresh and delicious, my favorite dish of the night.
Food-appetizer: Anticucho de corazon (grilled marinatedbeef heart brochettes) - the texture was amazing and it tasted really yummy also.  Would order this again.
Food-main: paella negra (rice in squid ink with seafood) - overall great dish, but kinda messy and the squid ink stains your fingers.  Your mouth and teeth too if not careful!

Overall a really delicious meal.  Too bad it's not near a bart station, but would come back again if in the neighborhood.
author: Stephanie Y.

description: I love this place, I have been here several times and it's always great.  Food is really good, I wished I lived closer so that I could go there more often.  Last time we went, we took a couple of friends that had never tried Peruvian food and they loved it!  The lomo saltado is always a big favorite of ours.  The scallops were to die for.  The suspiro a la limena (dessert) is amazing.  I highly recommend this place, I am Peruvian and I love it!
author: Martha F.

description:
Bought a voucher of $50 value for just $25 from Bloomspot, what a deal!!  

Made our dinner reservation for Wednesday and were immediately seated on arrival at 8.30. Surprisingly the space was very small, but had a cosy neighborhood feel with an open kitchen. It was packed with people even on a week day, which was definitely a good sign.

Complimentary bowl of fried corn and chickpeas is served on the table, a delight!

Going with Yelp reviews we made safe choices. Ordered :

1. Duck quasidilla - $14, served 3 portions of good sizes with mint and mango chutney on top, a flavorful bite and very filling.

2. Seafood paella classica - $22,  Goshhh, the dish was filled with plentiful clams, calamari, fish, prawns. Ohhh so good! Seafood lovers - here it is!!

3. Adobo pork - $19,  Again big FAT portion! The meat was so tender it melted in the mouth. The chocolatey sauce made the dish a perfect 10!! Best was the mashed sweet potato served on the side, which we couldn't stop licking clean.


PROS:

1. This is the 1st tapas place where the portions served were a LOT!! Just couldnt finish the dishes, so had to get the leftovers to-go. Maybe we made the right choices for our hungry and starved tummy.

2. Service was very attentive and highly satisfactory.
Worth mentioning here, on informing our server about the voucher we had the staff was very professional in telling us that the voucher will be taken care of in the bill. This was a relief as in many places when you show discount coupons the business refuses to recognize the voucher or choose not to give good service. But this place was an exception! Even with discount coupon you are not treated cheap but like a king!!

3. Easy parking in the area at 8, as its in a laid back neighborhood and lot of street parking around.

4. Its romantic to sit by the window and look out, with candle-lit table.. a nice date spot.

Overall had a great experience and thanks again to Bloomspot, hope more such deals keep coming. Worth every penny.
author: Payal B.

description: Beware of this review. We had dinner here and waited ten minutes. The food was pretty good but I reduced the stars by one because we saw a cockroach. GROSS!!
author: Minh H.

description:
Best Peruvian food in the bay area, price excellent and the customer service the BEST.

I work in the customer service industry for many years and at moment I walked in I was surprised by their host, she greeted me with genuine smile, something you don't see every day.
The waiter made my dinning special, my date thought that I had everything planed for her, but it was all the waiter.  She was knowledgeable with wine pairing, ingredients and with dissert, she read my girlfriend's mind (thanks to that dinner I can call her my girlfriend).
I recommend anyone that is looking for a very pleasant time or impress some :^) go to Piqueo's. 

Special Thanks to Esther you were amazing.

We will visit soon.
author: HA E.

description:
If the portions were slightly larger I'd give 5 stars. The food is incredible, and pairs well with a jug of sangria.

Loved the ceviche, loved the bbq, and the curry. Great food, great date night.
author: Carl S.

description:
I saw a Cockroach on the wall right next to my table in the back of the restaurant. It was so gross. I know this kind of thing happens, but I saw it and it was part of the experience so that's why it's in my review! Kind of put a damper on my taste buds for a while, but like all bad things in life, you gotta get over it and move on...

...the food is pretty tasty though, and the price point isn't too bad for SF. The portions were on the small side. The cebiche is better than La Mar (also in SF).
author: A H.

description: I like this place.  Tried the Paellas and the tuna criolla.  Both good.  Fried chickpeas was a bonus.  Reasonable wine list.  A small neighboorhood restaurant with an original and creative menu.
author: Ron T.

description:
I liked Piqueo's. Nothing too memorable but I do remember the food being pretty tasty. The only thing was the pricing, the food was on the expensive side for the amount of food we got. 
Liked it but not sure if its too worth it to come back
author: Natasha I.

description:
My love life will probably lead me down the path of obesity.

Why?  Because they say that if you eat quickly, you're more likely to gain weight.  And when I go on a date with a bad conversationalist who later turns out to be a douchebag, I have no choice but to shovel my food down so as to not make any eye contact or conversation.

Good thing the food was more than just decent (we split about 6 of the tapas and it was more than enough).  Pulled pork sliders, Yucca balls, empanadas, plantains, these are a few of my favorite things!

3.5 stars for the actual food, rounded up to 4 stars for the easy parking at 8 PM and the nice service.
author: Tori S.

description: This is definitely a hidden gem in Bernal and now a spot I take anyone who comes to visit from out of town. The ambiance is great and isn't too loud. Seating is somewhat limited so I suggest making a reservation to avoid any kind of wait. I haven't tried them all yet, but every dish I have ordered has been amazing. Definitely suggest the sangria and any of the ceviche offerings, the empanada, corn cakes and quinoa crusted prawns.
author: Brooke M.

description: I had a pretty gd meal here last Spring, using a groupon of sorts.  We got to try a lot of little things- that were all delicious as I recall.  The service was kinda crazy, it was almost like we had two waiters & by the end of the meal I was feeling a little schizophrenic. Nice ambiance, aka dark or very dimly lit, and a little loud once the wine started flowing.  Also it was a little small in there.  But the food was delicious. Moderate-high prices for this fare / smaller portions.
author: Coco J.

description:
So we had dinner here the other evening with out of town friends.  My oenophile amigo Matt raved about this place and so the group rez was on.

Sure enough, Matt not only knows wine, Matt also knows food!!!

The restaurant is absolutely delightful, romantic and welcoming.  Great colors, lighting, layout, views of the immaculate kitchen and the impeccably competent chefs moving about, preparing all sorts of delicious piqueos for us to savor.  Service was also handled by a very capable young Spanish speaking lady.

We tried a little of everything and each time a dish was passed my way, I was thrilled at how delicious each creation tasted and washed down so well with Matt's selection of liquid grapes (Mas Malbec).  

Even the paella was scrumptious!!  By the time the dessert menus arrived, there was no room left in the "barriga"and so I look forward to my return visit, leaving room for dessert of course.
author: Anthony D.

description: I've been to Piqueo's several times. Their food is amazing and the deserts are to die for. If your in the city looking for a new place to eat delicious food Piqueo's is your place. The hostess are very knowledgeable and helpful with any questions you might have of the menu.
author: Alejandra S.

description:
My husband and I were visiting from Florida and were told to try Piqueo's from our daughter who lives in the city. So glad we listened! The ambiance is so cute when we  first walked in we were greeted with a friendly smile by the hostess and given a table by the window. I was thrilled to be seated by the window so I could look out on the adorable neighborhood of Bernal Heights.

Our waitress was so friendly and made some great recommendations. Here is what we had:

Quinoa salad: It was really lovely and quite colorful the ingredients were all really fresh and the dressing was outstanding!

Hongos: fried portabello mushrooms with an aji dipping sauce that had just the right amount of heat.

Lomo Saltado: Most lomo I have had use a tritip but this place uses a fillet Mignon, so tender. Yum!

Mac n cz: Creamy with bacon. Need I say more?

Carne Empanada: Delicious buttery and flaky!

We split a bottle of Pinot Noir that was the perfect accompaniment to our meal. Unfortunately we were too full to try a dessert but I look forward to getting one next time I am in San Fran!
author: P T.

description:
So it went:  Four adventurous San Franciscans with a penchant for great food and even better conversation came out of the pouring rain and settled into the corner of a fully- enclosed, tarp-covered patio nestled behind the "Peruvian fusion" kitchen of a homey neighborhood restaurant in the (underrated) southeast corner of the city.  

Three hours and a seemingly infinite trickle of flavorful small, medium and large plates passed before us.  With a couple of inconsequential exceptions, the food was outstanding and impressively creative.  Soon after our arrival, a pitcher of amazing sangria and a zesty quinoa salad were set before us.  The salad combined the earthy taste of the quinoa and Peruvian corn, the subtle sweetness of tomato and onion and the slightly kick of the aji amarillo vinaigrette.   We knew more goodness was in store.

Our favorite hot dishes were the chicken thighs with a mole-style sauce and yucca, a (reportedly, for I didn't partake) succulent lamb shank, and the incredibly addictive macaroni and cheese with bacon and a spicy, creamy huancaina sauce.   Long after these dishes were consumed we received the a forgotten plate of ham-and-cheese stuffed yucca, a hearty treat that makes for ideal (if sinful) finger food.
Our sole disappointment in the meal was the absence of the sanguchon (pulled pork), a favorite of our companions and, apparently, too many others, as they'd run out before we arrived.

For dessert, we dove into the chocolate lava cake.  Enough said, really...it was fabulous, and was crowned with a homemade ice cream crafted from a Peruvian fruit, the name of which my sangria-addled brain cannot recall.

Our server was aloof, indifferent and nearly invisible, as we went nearly half an hour without a visit, empty water glasses and more on the table.   I look forward to trying another round of new dishes on my next visit, hopefully accompanied by more attentiveness from the staff.
author: Derek W.

description: Delicious. Everything we ordered was fantastic, especially the baby octopus. Our vegetarian friend was super happy with all of it, too. Will be back!
author: christine c.

description:
Yup, second time at Piqueo's and it was a disaster. 

Plus: it's in walking distance of my home.
Minus: all else. 

The meal consisted of:

*shockingly bland arroz con mariscos

* cebiche de pescado that was out of balance (note: they brought us the wrong cebiche and then quickly replaced it - looked like they removed the shellfish from the mixted cebiche, reassembled it and gave it back to us - yuck)

*BBQ ribs that were sickeningly sweet and insult added to injury when placed on slabs of cold sweet potatoes.

AND to top is all off, service was diffident and inattentive. 

We left thinking "what the hell just happened?" I then wrote a respectful and polite email to the restaurant to get their perspective - anyone can have a bad day. NO RESPONSE. I then sent a note via their website form to alert them to my previous email. NO RESPONSE.

The greatest sin: not understanding the meaning of customer service. By the way, my husband and I were taking a much needed break after deal with a death in my family. Not like you knew but that is beside the point: treat your customers like they matter.

That's it - I may walk the streets, I may walk out front of Piqueo's but I intend to walk on by.
author: CJ C.

description:
Sauces galore! First of all, we *loved* the chickpea mix they give you on arrival - it's a great mix of lightly fried chickpeas, onions, feta and seasonings. Yum, more please! 

We ordered the Ceviche de pescado (fish) -- I think I would've really enjoyed this but it was waaaay too spicy for me (I was sweating on contact), but it was "cooked" and seasoned with lime just right. My Malbec red wine helped to cool me off and yes, please open that window! 

We had the tuna tartare and avocado stuffed with chicken - very tasty! Along with the yucca fries and its many sauces - loved this! Conversation and wine was a-flowing, but a definite highlight was dessert - yes, I wholly agree that everyone should have the dulce de leche! 

All in all, a delightful experience, and I liked how they brought our dishes out one at a time so we could enjoy and savor at our leisure. I would definitely come back to try their other dishes. 

Dinner+2 glasses of wine+tip+tax = $58
author: Maile N.

description:
we were somewhat disappointed, after all of these glowing reviews.
the waitress was really nice, so no complaints there!
the food, however: there wasn't much variety in taste, especially given that every dish seemed to be covered with a combination of the same three garnishing sauces.
overpriced, for what it was.
author: H G.

description:
Pretty good place.  Had dinner there recently.  It's upscale Peruvian.  

1) The ceviche was good; but besides fish, it was loaded with all kinds of other stuff - yams, two kinds of corn kernels, seaweed, and lots and lots of red onions. I'd preferred if it had more fish.

2) We had another appetizer, blue corn and potato cake. It was tasty. The presentation was the best thing about it; looked like an art project.

3) We shared the paella for our main course.  It was average, kind of a disappointment.  Didn't come in the cast iron pan like I expected.  There was very little fish or shrimp; lots of mussels and squid.  And lots and lots of red onions (again).  Instead of saffron, we tried the black ink; I much prefer saffron.  Wouldn't get the black ink again.  Portion size was small too.

Would I go back?  Maybe one more time, and hopefully have a better food experience.  It's kinda pricey for what you get.
author: Ramon C.

description:
Four stars for the food, but two stars for the service.  Fried calamari, Grilled octopus, cheese wonton with guacamole, seafood risotto, and complimentary fried chickpeas are great!  I only didn't really like the beef heart skewer.  

The service, though, was spotty.  Although we didn't have a reservation, we did come early with our 14-month-old (5:30).  We asked the hostess if they had anything available, and she initially said "I can give you a table if you finish in 20 minutes."  I don't think it's reasonable to be telling your customers (with an infant!) to finish their meal in 20 minutes.  Then she said, "Oh it's okay."  I guess it was confusing.
author: Elena L.

description:
Go Ducks.

A phrase once used in reference to college sports. Now used ever so appropriately to describe Piqueo's duck confit, goat cheese, caramelized onions and chocolate suace quesadilla. A culinary touchdown. Best dish of an outstanding meal.

Save room for the grilled calamari basking in a pumpkin puree, any dish with their intensively flavorful scallops and their paella. Excellent medley of prawns, snapper, mussels, clams and halibut at a very excellent price ($18).

Sangria was comes by the glass and by the pitcher. Order the pitcher and do not miss the alcohol soaked fruit like grapes. Consider it an adult jungle juice.

We had no room left for dessert. This was a good thing.

Food and drink alone is worth a visit. Service (friendly and attentive), design (deep colors), accents (candles and modern lighting) and layout (open kitchen provides a captivating snapshot of the chefs at work) take things from four stars to five.

Go Piqueo's.
author: Jason B.

description: Every time anyone visits me in San Francisco, this is the first place I take them to dinner.  All the tapas are well executed and fun to share.  The service is good and the people who work there are always friendly and knowledgable.  I LOVE their camarones croquantes, their cebiches, and their lamb shank.  Don't skip on sangria or desert because those are awesome too!  Can't wait to go back soon!
author: Morea S.

description:
The GF and I stopped by for dinner on Friday night around 7 and had no problem being seated.  We opted to share some small plates.  

Everything we had was good.  The yucca balls were good and I really liked the Pobrecito.  I thought the ribs made with Inka-Kola BBQ sauce was good, but I'm a sucker for Inka-Kola.

The service was very attentive too.

My only complaint was it's a bit pricey.  But oh well, it's tasty.
author: Larry L.

description: Been here probably 10 times. Food always superb, from the funky fried garbanzo bean appetizer to the short but sweet dessert list. Seafood is fresh, meats are tender, juicy, and occasionally spicy. My favorite date night place in the neighborhood.
author: Mike S.

description:
Delicious food and great service. We ordered the following to share family style:

Crab Cake Peruano, Sanguchon (pulled pork sandwich), Costillita de chancho (grilled pork sparribs), beef Empanadas, Paella, Papa Rekkeba, and stuffed squid.

Overall everything was delicious, especially the sauce that accompanied it. 

As with most tapas, the prices of each dish was a bit on the higher side. However, since the quality of the food was great, it didn't bother me that much.

5 stars for the food!
author: Stephanie K.

description:
I came here with three friends for dinner recently and I was pleasantly surprised by the combination of easy parking, delicious food, and great atmosphere. 

We decided to go family style, starting with a pitcher of sangria and then splitting the cheese balls, a cebiche, adobo (pork shoulder) and lomo saltado (beef tenderloin), and a couple other dishes (my memory is slipping!).

The chicha morada I ordered tasted quite different from that which I had eaten in Peru just a year ago, so I wasn't the biggest fan there - but the rest of the food was outstanding. The service was good - not great - but I had no complaints whatsoever. I chose this place because I had a Bloomspot coupon and I'll definitely be returning here!
author: Aaron F.

description:
This place is just plain good! :) I love a good tapas place, where you get to try several different flavors, and Peruvian food is my new love of the new year, so Piqueo's mixture of these two things makes for a wonderful match!

The restaurant itself is dimly-lit and romantic, just lovely all around. Black tables are set with plates, silverware, and wine glasses. Paintings hang from the walls. It's a lovely atmosphere, which foreshadows the beautiful presentation of the dishes to come.

Service is very pleasant to interact with, and quite friendly. They're super knowledgeable about the menu, and very able to give recommendations. Bread and drink glasses are refilled promptly. Everything about the service is amazing.

The dishes are also artfully presented; they look as good as they taste! So, what did we have?

We started with the ceviche de pescado, which is perhaps my favorite dish right now. It's a tilapia marinated in lemon and lime, seasoned in garlic and other seasonings, and then topped with onions. Piqueo's ceviche was very good, though a bit on the sour side (even more sour than ceviche usually is).

We then moved on to the bolitas de yucca, which were ham and cheese balls that are deep fried and crispy. This was quite tasty, and perhaps was the highlight of the three dishes we ordered.

We ended with the pork adobo, which was unfortunately a bit on the bland side. I could have done without this dish.

Overall, though, it was still quite a good experience. I'd come back!
author: Matt V.

description:
Used to be a La Mar fan until recently.  Food quality isn't quite like it was a few years back.  And the drinks as light in the booze.

So, someone recommended Piqueos.....very happy they did.

1. Cebiche de Pescado - Red snapper with red onions, cilantro in aji rocoto
& leche de tigre - 4 stars.  fresh and good balance of flavors.  Also liked the portion size - Will order again

2. Anticucho de Corazón - Marinated beef heart brochettes with potatoes
& spicy sarsa panchit - 4 stars. Very yummy - Will order again

3. Crab Cake Peruano - potato chips crusted fresh Dungeness crab cake served with Sweet aji rocoto sauce - 3 stars - it was ok. the person who recommended the place really enjoyed this dish but I thought it was ok - Not order again

4. Adobo - Pork shoulder braised in adobo sauce with, soffritto, beer,
And banana leaf infused with mashed potatoes - 3 stars - it was ok, nothing special - Not order again
author: Lev E.

description:
Good food in an area of town (Bernal Heights) that I need to frequent more.

The Quesadilla de Pato, Chino-Peruano,  Seco de Cordero were terrific.

Nice selection wine selection to include Cantos Rodados.
author: Francis M.

description:
Wow - I *loved* my meal here.

The scary thing about San Francisco is that a place as good as this was completely off my radar.  I only had the opportunity to try it because a friend of mine lives in the neighborhood.

I was there a few months ago so I unfortunately can't be too specific about each dish.  All I know is that I liked everything I had:

Crab Cake
Yucca Balls
Pulled Pork Sandwich
Duck Quesadilla
Corn Cake
Dulce de Leche

Reviewing the menu to write this overdue review, I see at least 10 other things that make my mouth water.  Great service and sexy atmosphere too.  I'm definitely due for another visit to Bernal.
author: Shauna F.

description: My wife and I have been here around three times. And I come away more impressed after every visit. The food is beyond wonderful, the atmosphere has the perfect balance of homey and upscale. And the wait staff has been stellar on every trip. I'd say, for this price point, this is one of the best restaurants in SF.
author: Marcus L.

description:
I am sort of obsessed with this place at the moment! Great ambience on the covered back patio.
Mac and cheese (with bacon) to die for!
And the desert in the glass- forgot the name of it! 
But this place is absolutely amazing!
author: Sarah Z.

description: I love the way the restaurant is set up; when you walk in, you think the main room is it but you go through a hallway to additional seating where its quieter.  The service here is great.  I really enjoyed the papa a la huancaina - its almost as good as my mom's! I had the aji de gallina but didn't really enjoy the sauce.  Ceviche is delicious though, as is the lomo saltado.  Will definitely be back!
author: Stefanie M.

description: Absolutely delicious. The beef tenderloin is something else. If you can get a seat facing the kitchen it's fun to watch the flames touch the roof. The restaurant is in a great location and presents very well. Service is excellent and the waiters will happily recommend - definitely worth the trio - we'll he going back. Plus they have a new location opening in dogpatch.
author: Marsh M.

description:
Two words: CHICHA. MORADA. For the uninitiated - that's purple corn punch spiked with cloves, cinnamon and lime juice! Perfect elixir for the dog days of summer. Paired with ahi tuna ceviche or the Empanada Peruana, you cannot go wrong. Churrasco a la Parilla con yucas fritas is divine, as is the quinoa salad.

For such an elegant setting I wouldn't say it's 'kid-friendly', but we managed a lovely meal with a well-behaved 5-year-old. 

If only they had happy hour, I would stop in just for the chicha. I suppose it's always 5 o'clock somewhere...
author: Jaime Y.

description:
Great neighborhood restaurant - good buzz, good service, and pleasant ambience.  I'd probably rate that as the top 3, food is sort of secondary for me here.  It's good but not out of this world.

With that said, for the price and overall food presentation, it's a good place to go for a pleasant night out.
author: Gina C.

description: Hits all the right buttons. No pretentions, just honest food cooked with care and attention. The staff are also attentive and always rushing round looking after everybody. The place is always buzzing and is testament to why so many people patronize the restaurant.
author: Kevin R.

description:
This is a great little space in Bernal Heights. It's small, painted a light yellowish green inside, dimly lit, not too loud. There is a small bar area with a great wall display of wine bottles. Service was good, attentive without being intrusive. 

Dinner consisted of the following:

Calamar relleno...
Spanish chorizo, stuffed calamari with green lentil & huacatay sauce
Pollo al mani...
chicken thigh braised in a peruvian peanut curry sauce made with sofrito and cusqueña beer and served with white rice
Pobrecito...
tacu tacu, plantain, spinach, poached egg in peruvian curry sauce.
Paella negra...
wetter than most paellas I've had but very tasty. Slightly spicy with shrimp, mussels, clams, calamari, and fish.

Dessert
Suspiro a la Limeña...
dulce de leche with pisco whipped cream

I will definitely be back to this restaurant. Food and service were excellent.
author: Maria M.

description:
The food was pretty good but it was expensive and the portions were small. If I didn't have the Groupon, I'm not sure if I would've gone. 

My friend and I shared the food. We had the ahi ceviche, which had good flavors but the chunks of fish seemed a little big. I'm more used to smaller pieces but the quality was good. The beef empanadas were our favorite. We also had the short ribs but it was a piece that was about 2x2 inches. The crab cake (singular) was really good but it was one crab cake that had potatoes in it for $14 or something, which seemed like a rip off. 

I really like this neighborhood and the restaurant was cute but unless you have a coupon, I don't think it's worth it. There are a lot of other Peruvian places where you can get great tasting food for much less money.
author: Jessica J.

description:
This place is great, easy to get to and park, cool little neighborhood ambiance, and very authentic.  It has a down to earth peruvian menu that doesn't try to hard.  

The short ribs were fantastic.  This is a great place to have something different that doesn't struggle to be too different.
author: Zack M.

description:
Discovered by accident while lost in the neighborhood, this gem of a restaurant is a true find.  Short is the 4 of us ate here last night and loved it.

We picked dishes throughout the surprisingly extensive menu considering the size of the restaurant - all were wonderful.  Moreover, considering the range of restrictive diets (i.e., we are painful customers) they altered dishes as necessary to make us happy.

Atmosphere was comfortable and quaint, with an open kitchen.  

Wine list was inventive and interesting. 

A winner - "pique" Piqueo is you're trying to decide where to eat tonight.
author: David A.

description: Why all the dishes were SWEET???? I never eaten sweet Peruvian food, except for the chicken meal with orange glazed sauce (I forgot the name in Peruvian, I ate it in Cuzco). Thank God,  the lomo saltado is not sweet, lol. Nice plating, although I found it gross to make ceviche with sweet chili Thai sauce from the bottle. Yuck!!! The flavor is just so damned weird and it's like eating 'sweet raw fish sashimi'. The chinese version of ceviche is also weird. I'm a foodie and have lived in various part of the world. I know what I'm talking about and I've been to Peru myself. Lomo Saltado also so so, I've had better ones, this is a classic Peruvian dish. If you modified too much, it turns weird. The sauce doesn't taste 100% right. I like the place, tucked in a cute bernal heights neighborhood. Too bad, the food aren't authentic. It's more Americanized, because American loves anything super sweet. It's like Chinese sweet and sour sauce Panda express...............
author: Clemencia S.

description:
Everything was great until we found a humongous alive worm swimming in our ceviche. We are still grossed out about it. Just came back from the restaurant and felt like I had to write about it. The waitress said they used red snapper and the fish had worms. I guess cleanliness is not their strength. Yucks!!!
On that same note I tried their fancier restaurant Costanera and we loved how the restaurant looked but I also got very sick from their seafood. Called them the next day to ask if someone else had gotten food poisoning but their manager said no one else had called.  I don't think I'll be coming back. If you go look at your food before you eat it ( inspect it first...  Look out for anything moving that shouldn't!
author: Giuliana H.

description: Its piqueos......what else do I need to say? They have a few sister restaurants such as mochico on Harrison that's also a great dining experience. The food at both locations have never been a disappointment. Its not a bargain dining experience but you get what you pay for in the food quality and dining experience
author: Mike H.

description:
Right before the winter break, I had a chance to check out Piqueos in Bernal Heights.  I had walked by this charming little restaurant many times during weekend strolls and was always intrigued by the Peruvian small plates menu on display in the window.  This time, I returned during dinner hours when they were actually open to see if their offerings matched what I had imagined over the past couple of years.

Generally speaking, I was not disappointed.  I have to admit the small plates are a bit of a blur (we finished off a bottle of wine) but everything was on par, and the ceviche with corn was a stand-out.  If memory serves, the meat dishes were less impressive than the vegetable-based ones, but nothing was a disappointment except the rice pudding dessert.

Service was warm and friendly, with the occasional misfire but all in all, quite good.  In terms of ambiance, it's a great date place; candle-lit and cozy with warm dark woods to sink your self into, allowing time and comfort in which to enjoy your meal and your company.
author: Saminda W.

description:
I will definitely be going back to Piqueo's.  The appetizer and entrees we ordered were absolutely fantastic. The meals tasted so fresh, and everything was seasoned perfectly.  The chef/cooks here really know what they are doing.   We started with the Pastel de Choclo, and my friend and I both wanted to order another when we were done.  Our entrees were the Arroz con Pato (Duck Paella) for me and ahi tartar for my friend.  We both loved our individual dishes.  

There were a number of other dishes we both wanted to try, but weren't really ordering off the tapas menu (we will next time).  The only detractions were 1) The service was a little slow, both initial approach and between the courses; and 2) The dessert wasn't very good. We had the Dulce de Leche with port whipped cream.  I think it would have been much better if it hadn't been dusted with cinnamon.  Cinnamon did not go with the caramel flavor OR the port in the whipped cream.  It was also incredibly sweet (though we were warned about that).  without the cinnamon and a higher cream to pudding ratio, it probably would have been excellent.

We want to try the chocolate cake next time.
author: P K.

description:
I've been there several times and love this place. 
Pricey, but you pay for what you get. 
Tried their stuffed calamari and short rib appetizers, grilled lamb chops, Lomito al Jugo (stir fried beef), both of paellas classic and black. We liked second one more , coz it's interesting and unusual to have your fingers turn black after your food)))
There was something else - I don't remember now. But all food was delicious and absolutely worth coming back!
author: Anastasia B.

description:
Whoever took our reservation on the phone failed to record it properly or communicate it to the host or something, so we had to wait for about 30 minutes... not a good first impression.

The food was great though, and we got a nice quiet table out in the back of the restaurant. Three of us shared a handful of small plates and enjoyed them all.  The food was all very beautifully plated as well.

The ceviche was delicious, as was the sangria.

To be honest I'd probably give this place 4 or 5 stars if it weren't for the mess with the reservation, but that was just completely unacceptable.
author: Mark N.

description: Yum! Great to sit at the bar and watch the amazing chefs pull together one amazing dish after the next. Spareribs were incredible. Great passionflower dressing on the salad. Paella was fresh and flavor was on point. Great service to boot!
author: Hillary L.

description: Excellent authentic Peruvian cuisine. Love it.
author: aL Z.

description:
Peruvian food is amazing. Piqueo's was almost like being back in Peru. Almost. 
The restaurant is small and cozy, located in Bernal Heights. We found out that the Chef owner of this place is the same one as La Costanera in HMB, so the menu was very similar to theirs. 
The food was delicious, we had a bunch of different tapas, the service was great and friendly, and their prices are acceptable. 
We will definitely come back.
author: andrea k.

description:
The chickpeas ARE that good! They get the meal started in a good good way.  
We also had two different cerviches, both of which were excellent; the Cerviche Peruano, and the Tuna Tartare. I love the many different flavors on each plate.
 Next we moved on to the Antichuchos de Corazon, which I loved, and the Empanada, which I didn't, although my friend really liked it.  The sangria is surprisingly great, we never even got to any of the wines because we just kept drinking it.
Service is excellent. I would definately go back for more sangria and tapas!
author: Deb A.

description: I love this place! Especially the service Esther the cute girl gives you on Thursdays. She's awesome!
author: Carlos N.

description:
My new favorite restaurant in San Francisco. 

Came here with a couple girlfriends and had an amazing evening. The restaurant ambiance is tasteful and trendy without being dark and blasting loud music. The wait staff was exceptionally helpful with our order and really took into consideration what we were in the mood for. 

We started out with the Sangria which is sweet and delicious and dangerously tastes like juice. We had: quinoa salad, prawn fritters, spinach empanada, cebiche de pescado, duck quesadilla, and the panna cotta dessert. The prawn fritters were pillows of heaven while the quinoa salad was delicious, but I would definitely order something else next time. The menu is overwhelming because everything looks delicous, and it is. 

I suggest coming here with a few friends and ordering as many dishes you can afford/stuff in your mouth, because everything is worthwhile. I just bought the groupon for my parents so they can go and fall in love with this place as well.
author: Claire R.

description: The cebiche pescado, the crab cake and corn cake were all delicious. The chicken and yuca braised in peanut sauce was a bit too heavy.
author: Amin S.

description: Peruvian food is my fav, great options, not that pricey. Would try it again!
author: Shadi K.

description:
My wife and I have a new favorite Peruvian restaurant in the City...yup, it's Piqueo's!  Why? Simple: the food is much tastier than any of the Fresca locations (I've been to Fresca--mostly West Portal at least 20 times), definitely much tastier and better presented than Limon, and much tastier and less expensive than La Mar.  We also really enjoyed the restaurant's small, low key, neighborhood feel.  Also, a super plus---lots of street parking. 

Here's what we ordered and ate:
Ceviche Mixto (nice little heat on the taste buds)
Causita Lemina (tender, moist and flavorful)
Pappa Rellena
Calamares Relleno (this can't be found at Fresca or La Mar)
author: Al G.

description: I thought it was very good, but not mind blowing. We get spoiled in SF... I had the squid ink paella. It was pretty good and tasted even better the next day (except it spilled all over my car when I tried to eat it on the way to work. Don't do it..just eat it in the kitchen and THEN get in the car). I would say the food was a lot heavier than I'm used to out of Puruvian. This felt like the soul food version.
author: Nicole S.

description:
We came here because my boyfriend got us a Groupon daily special for the restaurant.

Honestly, this is probably the best Peruvian 'contemporary' (or often called "fusion") place I've been to in the city, hands down, and I've been to almost every one of them.

I ordered their salmon special---good lord---absolutely incredible, while my boyfriend had their quinoa special (incredible again). We also shared a special appetizer, I forget what it's called, but it was these cream cheese filled delectable fried bread-ish things. YUM.

Service and decor was impeccable.

The kitchen smelled absolutely delicious.

The only downside: it's pricey. Even with our $25.00 for $50.00 worth of food, we still ended up paying a little over $30.00 (including tip) for the food. Still, in my opinion, it was worth every cent.

If you got a little bit of extra money to spare, I strongly suggest this place. The food is worth it.
author: Cristian G.

description: Loved this place! Definitely a neighborhood  in Bernal Heights. It is a rather intimate setting however it didn't stop me and my friend from enjoying ourselves. We ordered several tapas to share and a pitcher of sangria. My favorite tapa was the Dungeness Crabcake. That was deelish. The wait staff was warm and attentive. Was a nice time with good wine and food.
author: Yacha G.

description:
This was the first time eating Peruvian foods..We had an amazing time.
We started out with the  Cebiche Mixto  it had Red snapper, mussels & clams, shrimp, red onions,cilantro & aji rocoto leche de tigre.Extremely fresh and plenty to share.
I had the Churrasco Grilled N. York steak, served with yucca fries
& piqueos chimichurri. My partner had Paellas Clasico 
Arborio rice cooked in saffron-tomato sauce with prawns, red snapper, mussels, clams & halibut

We have been back three times since our first visit and we are looking forward to the next...
author: Robert O.

description: Awesome awesome awesome...no need to get your own plate, the small plates are the way to go.  Great for GF eaters - almost the entire menu can be re-done GF (and most require little to no alterations).  Excellent service, decent wine list, cool vibe, and just down the street from Holy Water!
author: Bradley O.

description:
Groupon took me there for the first time yesterday.  The restaurant is small and not very well planned so seating is a little cramped and, without proper ventilation, you leave smelling like smoky food.  The place was crowded (which is a sign of good food) and as a result service was painfully slow.  They didn't have the grilled baby octopus which I was keen on trying.  

However, I have to give the food 5-stars.....everything we ordered (Camarones al Ajo, Cebiche, Empanadas) was amazingly good!  For dessert, we shared a dulce de leche which was interesting but not as amazing as the server told us it would be.  All in all, a good experience and I will go back to try more.
author: Donna D.

description:
Came here since I had a Groupon. Seated Promptly, however upon arrival, most of the servers/busboys kind of ignored me until a food runner came up to me and said the hostess will be right with me.

Anyway, on to the food. We ordered 2 fruit juices forgot the names, but they were juices so meh. We shared the beef empanada, cebiche de pescado, and the duck quesadilla. Overall, the food was enough for the two of us, however it didn't really have a wow factor. I thought the cebiche was a bit too acidic and I didn't really like it, I liked fresca's more and when I ordered yucca chips, it didn't come out until the very end with the quesadilla, which ruined the whole point of getting it. I wanted to eat the chips with the cebiche. Both the empanada and quesadilla was tasty, but wasn't great that I'd want to come back again.

Service was alright, the busboy came by frequently to clear plates, however, whenever they dropped food or clear plates they didn't realize my water glass was empty which was disappointing. The hostess came by to refill water but we were already at the end of our meal. The waiter took awhile to come check on us after the last plates were cleared, even though half the tables in our area had cleared out.

Oh and when i went to use the restroom, there was a roach on the mirror...gross!
author: Lily K.

description: A nice and cozy place in Bernal Heights. We have been clients for a couple of years. Everytime we come, the food is excelent. If you want to try what really fine Peruvian cuisine is like, try this restaurant. The latest addition to the menu, Passion Fruit Panna Cota, is to die for!
author: Lindsay K.

description:
If your taste buds are in need of a little pick-me-up, Piqueo's might be just what you need.

Rich, bold flavors are in abundance in this new Peruvian restaurant, which quietly and respectfully slid into the old Moki's space and made itself at home.  And at home it is - the deep, wine-dark walls and clean styling work well in the space, creating a cozy yet modern feel. 

The service was genuine & friendly from the minute we walked in the door (1/2 hour before closing, with no reservation), and our server was very knowledgeable about the dishes and made some very good recommendations.

We started our meal with an order of the baby octopus which was amazing both in flavor & presentation (see photos).  The sauce was tasty & smoky and the potatoes were topped with 3 different colorful sauces, each with a bit of a kick at the end.  It was a very unique dish, definitely a signature of the restaurant.  We also shared the Choclo Peruano, or fried corn ball, which was very good, and the Chicken Empanada which was excellent - a must-have.  Juicy chicken mixed with raisins in a tender crust sprinkled with powdered sugar - divine!

For my main course, I had the Lamb Chops, which were extremely tender (I barely had to chew) and cooked perfectly, in a wine sauce and on top of a bean/vegetable mixture.  The beans were great - the veggies reminded me a little of succotash, but still tasted very good.  My husband had the Aji de Galina, or shredded chicken in sauce, which was spicy and delicious.

There are a number of wines and beer to choose from, or for something really interesting and different, try the chicha morada, a drink made with purple corn.  

We were too full for dessert, but I know I will be back soon, and I am looking forward to seeing what else Piqueo's has to offer.  It's refreshing to have such a solid experience at a new restaurant - kudos to Piqueo's for a job well done.
author: Liz S.

description: Love love love this hidden Peruvian restaurant in Bernal Heights. I spent a month in Peru studying Spanish so I am really picky about Peruvian food. I've been to many Peruvian restaurants in the city, La Mar, Mochica, Inkas and Mi Lindo Peru. Piqueo's is by far the best. My favorite dishes are: cebiche de pescado, chicharrones de pollo, aguadito de pollo (not on the menu, you have to ask), lomo saltado, empanada de carne and suspiro ala limena. Their sangria is delicioso! If you are lucky, you can hit a time that they do special deals through Living Social or Groupon. One complaints about their anticuchos de corazon. They cut down the serving size to half because of the rising material price. Bummer...
author: Yina M.

description:
Long time lurker here.    This place ticked me off enough to open an account.

I presented my OpenTable coupon ($25 for $50 of food) which gave certificate number as well as invoice number from my OpenTable cell app.   I was informed that I "had to print out the certificate for their record keeping."   I suggested the write down the certificate number on a sheet of paper and that would serve the same purpose.   Nope, they want the print out.

They have my ID until I come back with a printed version.    I was not going to pay full price and give the satisfaction of coming again and using the certificate.   The irrational manager said they've had the problem with lots of customers.   Really?   Then fix this stupid problem, I had even showed her the 4 other restaurants I've used OpenTable with before.   Still wouldn't budge, wants me to print it.    Could not believe.   Recommending to nobody on sheer principle.
author: russ h.

description: Elena and I are losing a friend of 8 years who is taking a transfer to Hawaii. We needed a special place to take her for her farewell dinner. We chose Piqueo's. It was a pleasant surprise in every way. I t is quaint and charming. The staff is wonderful. The food was truly 5-star. We also discovered a superb Peruvian wine called Mecenas. This restaurant is wonderful and special. Elena and I strongly recommend it for anyone looking for a little bit of the charm of Peru in San Francisco
author: Jack W.

description: Came here Sat nite for dinner. Parking sucks. Lucky if you could find parking on the main street, but if you had to go through the neighborhood like I did, the street is very very narrow. Anyway, back to the restaurant. A very cozy place, dimmed light, perfect place to bring a date. Service was excellent. We ordered the Chicharrones (Calamari) as a starter. It was delicious. Then we had Costillita de chanco (BBQ). It was good but nothing really special about it. We also had Lomito al Jugo. I didn't really like it as it wasn't really tasteful, it tasted like chinese stir fry minus the MSG. We ordered the Empanadas which came last (I thought they would come out along with the appetizer). I assumed our waitress forgot about the empanadas until we reminded her.
author: Lovetoeat A.

description: Truly a little gem. Great atmosphere and delicious food. This restaurant has a refined take on Peruvian cuisine without being pretentious. The wine selection is also very good and the staff is very helpful and knowledgeable. It's one of the places that make the San Francisco restaurant scene so great.
author: Jeni K.

description:
We love Peruvian food and decided to try this place. We had the anticucho, which was delicious. My kids each had the lomo soltado, which they both finished because the portions were on the small side. The entrees tasted good, but not as flavorful as others we have tasted. I had the arroz con mariscos with seafood. It was very tasty, but also could have been a larger portion. The lighting in the restaurant was so dark that I could not really see what I was eating. The sauce was black and tasty. I wish I could have seen my food better. They must save a lot in their energy bill! My wife had the salmon andino. She liked it but it would have been better with some vegetables and some rice to accompany the food. Once again, the portion was quite small and disappointing.

We had to order dessert because all four of us were not full yet. As expected, the two desserts we ordered were very small!

In summary, the food was pretty good, but we did not like the small portions or high prices. The lighting could have been brighter so we could see our food better. Service was very good, but I wished that they would stop asking how our food was several times during the meal.  

We might go back some day, but I would rather eat at some other Peruvian places instead.
author: Chester L.

description: Proof positive that you can almost get any cuisine in SF.  The food here is well executed and as good as the more trendy La Mar along the Embarcadero.  The one weakness is the lack of a full liquor license so we could not get our fill of Pisco Sour.
author: Laurence H.

description:
The standout dish here is the arroz con mariscos (seafood paella). So flavorful and creamy, and there's a slight hint of spiciness but it doesn't overwhelm. They also added a lot of seafood(mussels, scallops, tilapia, shrimp). The adobo(pulled pork) entree was also tasty; as the pork and the mashed sweet potato just melts in your mouth. I wish they gave more of the tasty fried yucca balls; sauce went very well with them.

We also had the sangria, so delicious! And one of the Peruvian soft drinks, chicha morada; sweet but not overwhelming.
author: Karina C.

description:
Enjoyed the food here but was only given one vegetarian option for the entree, it did seem there were more small plate items I could have eaten. Chickpeas we were given were awesome. The dish I had was made with quinoa, it was kind of creamy and was flavored very well. There were also some fried mushrooms in it which were very delicious.  

Overall, cool place. Like other restaurants on Cortland, it is a tiny restaurant and looks like it used to be a house.
author: Angela T.

description:
the ceviche, sangria and chocolate cake are the reasons to come here-  all amazingly wonderful!

Still love it, but didn't order the right things this time- i really didn't like the flavor of the pulpito (octopus)- and the chicharrones de pollo weren't made with good pieces of chicken- they were nothing special- just tasted like fried chicken with ranch sauce...
author: Layla L.

description:
I have been to the other "sister" establishments (Mochica, La Costanera), so I guess its really hard to beat the food at La Costa, but this place was a bit of a let-down.  The portions, at least with regard to the entrees, were too small - but they tasted great.

Pros: Cebiche Mixto - excellent, and decent portions for a "starter" (why didnt this idea carry-over to the entrees?);  Service was great.  Love the small, intimate atmosphere, just perfect for Bernal Heights.  In general, the food is full of flavor, with great selection of Peruvian seafood and meats.  The fried chickpeas are to die for (and its FREE)

Cons: small entree sizes; not a lot of elbow room (if you need it); price doesnt reflect portion of food.
author: M P.

description:
The four of us came here last night for some above than average food that was served randomly.  I don't think it was our waiter's fault, in fact, he kept apologizing and gave us two additional plates, while we waited about an hour for our paella, as well as offered to top off our wine glasses, but it's clear that there's some challenges in the kitchen.  

We ordered the cebiche mixto, which was overly acidic and unfortunately, the snapper was replaced with scallops, since the restaurant "ran out."  The classic paella was also decent, but nothing exciting.  Everyone at our table thought we've had better.  On the the other hand, the tuna tartar was fresh and delicious and the prawns and yucca balls were very tasty!  I esp loved the japanese sweet potatoes accompanying the prawns!  We also thoroughly enjoyed the hominy, corn and chick peas dish that was served right when we were seated at our table.  The atmosphere is very quaint and decorated warmly, but they do need to do something about the ventilation.  It was a bit smoky and oily inside.
author: Sheri H.

description:
I normally don't go to restaurants based on others' recommendations. I'll do my own research and check it out on my own terms. Piqueo's was recommended to my by maybe 9 different people when they knew I like Peruvian food.

So on a whim one day I made reservations for two on a Monday night(thanks Opentable). We walk in, and nobody was at the front to greet us so we're kinda stuck in this awkward "should we sit down or wait around?" stance. Thankfully we were seated soon after, and offered drinks right away.
Glass of Malbec (my new favorite) for the lady, and an Anchor Steam for the gentleman.

Jennifer L. was right when she said "service here is pretty lax, but still nice and personable." I would say it took about 20-30 minutes for the waiter to come over and take our order. It was longer than I would have liked, we had already finished our first round of drinks.

Must-try on the menu:

Cebiche Chino-Peruano - large chunks of fresh snapper marinated in lime, onions and giant corn kernels.

Braised Ribs - melt-in-your-mouth ribs that are already off the bone. 

If you're planning a dinner for a larger group of people, you can request the back patio. It's secluded and private, great for special occassions.
author: Alyssa G.

description:
We dined here on a Saturday night with an early 5:30pm reservation. There were a few tables seated and by the time we left around 7pm the place was completely packed.

We thoroughly enjoyed the food and particularly the appetizers - the fried mushroom dish as well as the stuffed peppers. The mushrooms came with a spicy dipping sauce and tasty bell pepper / salad like mixture served underneath the mushrooms. The stuffed peppers were very savory with a slight spice offset by the slightly sweet taste of the peppers themselves. Along with the apps, I enjoyed the chichamosa - chicha morada and sparkling wine - a great paring with the apps!

For the entree we shared the paella with various seafood and lots of flavor as well as the lomo saltado which was probably our least favorite dish. It was just lacking a bit in flavor and was not as tender as we would have liked. 

We finished the meal with the chocolate cake with pisco flavored ice cream - it was good but not particularly exceptional. We would have liked to have had the traditional Peruvian cookies but they weren't offered on the menu. 

Overall, we really enjoyed the ambiance, service and the food. And would definitely recommend if you are looking for a nice "date night" restaurant in the area.
author: Shannon W.

description:
Wandered in late one night with a 20-minute reservation for six.  Had a great meal (lots of tapas, some more tapas and some tapas on top of that) and wine.  Some more tapas after that.

Sat in a back room - quiet, warmed by the street heater which was handy cause it was cold outside and the room was open, more like a patio.

Logged on Yelp, gave it four stars.  It's not as good as it gets, but I'm definitely a fan, and the fifth star is for matching my mood for Peruvian cusine.

Oh, my neighbors are Peruvian, and their stuff smells just like what we ate.  I should ask them for samples...
author: S C.

description:
Very tasty and original food. Their menu changes regularly to keep it interesting. This place is nice for a date or a special occasion. It's a bit pricey but it's worth it! Keep room for their dessert!
Try not to seat on the back patio though because it sucks. It's cold, smells funny and you feel like they forgot you. :)
author: Aya I.

description:
Little Nepal is closed on Mondays.  Must be the Nepalese sabbath.  "Never fear," said I.  "There is this great Peruvian place we can hit up instead."  I was only going to bump my rating down one star considering how great my first experience was here, but I can't help it.  If there's anything I hate it's ranting and raving about a place to someone only to have it be a colossal disappointment.  Honestly, if this were my only time here they'd probably get 2 stars...maybe 1 on a cost per value basis.  Honestly it has to be bumped down 2.

To break it down, we had:

A glass of the malbec and a glass of the cab - as mentioned in my previous review, they do well on the wine.

Ahi Ceviche - OK, this was great!  It was different from other ceviche I have had in that the pieces of ahi were so big...and it was very tart so I wouldn't order it if you don't like that.

Plantains with Smoked Mozzarella - They tried to get too creative.  It was edible and all...but not a great combination of flavors.

Yucca balls stuffed with ham and cheese - Also great...and covered in something that tasted like curry sauce.  Yum.

Duck Quesadilla - Horrible!  HORRIBLE!  My friend and I both took exactly one bite each.  Just one bite, and I fell so oh oh oh, ooover you.  The waiter (whose picture should be in the dictionary under inattentive BTW) picked up the uneaten offending quesadilla without so much as a word to the effect that we handn't eaten it.  I'm sorry, but a 5 star restaurant does not make you pay for something you hate.

Dessert - I don't remember what it was called...but dessert was, for lack of a better word...stupid.  Yes.  It was stupid.  What happened to that WONDERFUL chocolate cake?!  Why instead did I get a cookie that tasted like it was from Keebler (not knockin' Keebler...just that a package is three-fitty if ya know what I mean).  Anyway...it was a Keebler cookie doused in half an inch of powdered sugar and accompanied by a single strawberry: cut in half, a singe raspberry: cut in half and a single blackberry: cut in half...and then drizzled in a nasty unidentifiable and tasteless berry sauce.

Yes folks...all of this can be yours for the low low price of just $82.

I want the old menu back.

*waits patiently for the restaurant owner to tell her that the chef has been on sabbatical and I can expect him to return shortly*
author: PrincessPeac H.

description: If you sit at the bar to eat you will truly enjoy this gem of a restaurant. I found myself missing living in South America and happened to be strolling through the area. The best sangria I have ever had! Watching the staff create the lovely inventive dishes from my seat at the bar was a joy. My friend and I ordered 3 starters and 3 main dishes. We where excited by all of them. I look forward to trying all the other dishes on the menu as soon as I can.
author: Anna S.

description: If you are in Bernal Heights, this is a great place to grab a bite. They serve great tapas that pack a punch of flavors and moderate heat. There are a lot of seafood options including cebiche, scallops, octopus, and the paella. The portions are small but they are designed to share. Prices are a little rich but the food is unique and tasty. Service can be a little slow as well.
author: Ed L.

description:
My experience was weird, it was one part rhapsody, one part discordant mess.

Observe:

The Chilean Cab and the Argentinian Malbec?  Beautiful! 5 Stars
Fried, stuffed yucca Balls: Amazing!
Tuna ceviche: Delicious!
Plantain with smoked mozzarella: weird, there was something off about the flavor profile for me, but it wasn't terrible
Duck Quesadilla: just awful, there was not a single redeeming quality to this dish.  We each took one bite and threw it back on to the plate.
Dessert (lemon cookies, powdered sugar and caramel): Eh, I didn't love it but it was ok.

The service started out great and tapered off, which was odd because they really weren't all that busy.

I wish I could figure out the secret to ordering here, because the things that were good were well worth a second trip.
author: Renae H.

description:
It could have been a disaster, but it was great.    
Super Hungry + Tapas  could = Expensive Meal or not Enough to eat.  
That did not happen here.  

The food was very very tasty and the portions were pretty good sized. 
There are a lot of items on the menu I look forward to trying in the future.    
The servers  Juan & Sierra (like the beer and the mountains) were very friendly and attentive.
author: John M.

description: A great spot in our neighborhood filled with friendly staff. A fun place to go with two couples so you can try more dishes. All the dishes are good and many excellent and unique. They have a reasonable corkage policy so go and order a variety of plates - your taste buds will thank you!
author: Michael L.

description:
I came here with a Groupon. Service was slow but the food did not disappoint. We ordered three small plates: chicken thighs, crab cake peruano, pastel de chodo (corn cake, not to be confused with corn bread), and a side of sweet potatoes. All were delicious and moderately priced. Plus we took a bunch of food home. 

I would give four stars but the service was a tad slow.
author: Christa K.

description:
Piqueo's is a cute, nicely decorated, little restaurant on a corner.  It looks very clean and the service was excellent.  Our server was very friendly and fast.

Many years ago, when there were only very few peruvian restaurants in the bay area, none of them offered piqueos (tapas).  And still now, i think this is one of the few places that offer a wide variety of small plates.  And i love this because sometimes, i want to try a lot of little bites of everything.

The menu i think has recently changed, but a couple of weeks ago, we ordered, of course, piqueos:

1. Chuletita Alberto:  Perfectly cooked and delicious.

2. Cebiche de pescado:  It tasted just like a cebiche in Lima... and that is very hard to find in the bay area.  For me, it was the perfect combination of spicy and sour.  It came with a bit of typical canchita and peruvian corn.

3. Humita Dulce:  A delicious fusion of a peruvian sweet humita and curry sauce...  loved it.  The humita had the perfect texture.

4. Peruvian crab cake:  I wasn't going to order this because it's not a typical peruvian dish, but i'm glad we did.  It was very good.

5. Pastel de Choclo: Very yummy corn cake, typical peruvian piqueo.  

6: Chocolate cake with Pisco Ice Cream:  the chocolate cake was to die for.  The ice cream was good, but i honestly did not feel the pisco taste.

Oh, and that house chickpea spicy thing is very very good.  Even though i have never eaten a chickpea ají in Perú, the flavor of the mix was definitely peruvian.  Loved it.  

We had an Open Table certificate and had no problems redeeming it.

I totally recommend Piqueo's and would absolutely go back again for more.

Gracias Piqueo's, for offering a yummy meal away from home.
author: Rita F.

description:
We came here for a date night and I was glad that we weren't on a time crunch because service is here is pretty lax, but still nice and personable.  I say lax because they strategically spaced out our dishes so our table wouldn't be too uncomfortably cramped.  Smart!

Our server was really cute and was attentive enough without being overly attentive (did that make sense?)  She definitely made us feel comfortable and didn't rush us through the end of our dinner, even when we ended up being one of the last tables left.  She even checked to see how long MaggieMudd's Ice Cream would be open.  We kept eyeing it to make sure it was still open...We didn't make it, but I thought it was nice of her to do so. :)

I was really impressed with our food, minus the paella...you'll see why.  

First off, the Fried Chickpeas are addicting (good one, 7X7).  Luckily, they're light and small in portion.  I love how restaurants offer yummy alternatives to the filling combination of bread and butter.  

The Red Snapper Ceviche was so good!  The fish was perfect, tender and full of flavor!  Let the snapper marinate in your mouth before chewing on it...definitely a "moment"!  I'm glad the server didn't bring the other dishes out while having the ceviche because it's definitely one to finish on its own without other dishes to distract your attention.  

Next up, the BACON Mac n Cheese...Not only do they sprinkle bacon shreds on top of the mac n cheese, they also chop up thick chunks of bacon IN the mac n cheese.  Knowing my love of bacon, my date found a ginormous chunk of bacon in his share and gave it to me..."HE LIKES ME!  HE REALLY LIKES ME!"  Give me your bacon and my heart is yours... 

Then, the Chicken Chicharrones...can we say Yum?  We commented that usually, when you think of Chicharrones, you think of crispy fried skin.  But this chicharrones dish came with the tender meat and some out of this world dipping sauce.  I dipped it with some of the mac and cheese...EVEN BETTER!

So, after all the wonderful "moments" I had with the tapas, the paella came last with not so wonderful flavors.  I think, however, that if the paella come out earlier, it would have been better.  It was just "meh" to me.  I will say that they were very generous with the fresh seafood portions...

Overall, points for its cozy romantic feel, nice service and tasty "moments"...
author: Jennifer L.

description: never heard of this place and its so good, how did i miss it?  i like the short ribs, chevice, salmon, squid ink risotto, crab cakes, and most of all the octopus!  the stewed octopus is better than le ciccia's version.
author: Wakako U.

description:
I live in  Bernal Heights, am a big fan of supporting local businesses and was excited to take my in-laws to Piqueo's for an early family dinner in late November 2012.  We had a sub-par experience from a service perspective where we were forgotten about by the server then ignored by the staff as it became clear that an entree was never cooked for one of our party.    It was hard to get drinks, impossible to get more water and we could not get a response out of anyone.  There were no acknowledgements of the missing entree and when we finally were able to get a staff member's attention our missing meal was brought 15 minutes later.   The food was ok but by that point the poor service made it less palatable.    
When we were trying to exit the restaurant the hostess actually hit me to get me out of her way-inexcusable and very rude-it was so shocking I did not say anything because I could not believe she did that, but sadly my husband confirmed that she did indeed bang into me to move me out of her path.  WOW!.
I wrote to Piqueo's customer service email address provided on the site immediately after our poor experience but never heard back.   This is a small neighborhood and such deplorable service is incredibly disappointing.  We will not be returning.
author: Jennifer T.

description: Quickly one of my favorites in SF. This place is fantastic. The traditional ceviche is one of the best I've had.  The quinoa salad is unreal, short rib extremely good. Can't go wrong. Definitely recommend trying this place if you like Trying new places or like this type of food.  There's something for everyone on the menu too.
author: Max C.

description: quaint restaurant with great food. Everything we ordered was great. I definitely enjoyed the Sanguchori, oh and you can't leave without ordering the Suspiro for dessert. Space is kind of cramp but we enjoyed ourselves and will definitely be back to try more off of the menu.
author: Jennifer P.

description:
Very relaxing, warm space tucked away on quaint Cortland Ave.  The food is tasty and the service is friendly although the timing between dishes sometimes ran a bit long.

Nommy noms:
- Tiger prawn cebiche: great, bright flavor and the prawns had a great texture
- Crab Cake Peruano: light, soft and fluffy with loads of crab meat (perhaps too much sauce on the plate though)
- Sangria: not too sweet, just right
- Sweet Potato Fries: so tasty and loved the dipping sauce (hated the tall, narrow paper cone they were served in, couldn't even see the fries) 

Just OK:
- Quesadilla de Pato: with a chocolate sauce, some kind of guacamole sauce, and a salsa-type garnish on top this dish was TOO busy to really appreciate and taste the duck confit filling
- Short Rib Stew: while the short rib and veggies were nice and tender, the sauce was under-seasoned

Note: The portions are larger than at other tapas restaurants. 4 tapas, a side of sweet potato fries, and a pitcher of sangria was PLENTY for 2 people. Will definitely order less next time.
author: Vicente G.

description:
Ambiance was beautiful & clean. Attentive staff. Amazing food. This was my second time trying Peruvian. Limon (also great) was my first. Decided to bring mom here for mother's day. My family all loved Peruvian food now lol. We had the chicken chicharron, yummo. The ceviche was cut a bit too chunky for us but the taste was great. Lomo Saltado was great, but Limon's was better. Dad had the duck quesadilla, goood too!

It was a very intimate restaurant, great decor, great for a small intimate family dinner or date night!
author: Mirella M.

description:
New to San Francisco, I did my homework on this one, researching the best place to go in the city for my boyfriend's birthday cuisine of choice: Peruvian. Even then, it's a bit of a crap-shoot. 

Much to my delight, the rave reviews were spot on or even a little modest. This place was amazing! and exceeded my expectations. Comfortable, attentive (albeit not overly so) service and absolutely delicious tapas. The sangria, too, puts others' to shame. 

My only criticism is relative to the Cebiche Sampler. Three of the 6-7 are offered in small portions. However, one (the camarones), in comparison to the other two fish based versions seems harshly bitter, whereas I can imagine, if eaten on its own, one's impression of it might be significantly different. 

All-in-all an excellent dining experience, one of the best I've had in SF, and a deliciously fun birthday for my boyfriend!
author: Alexis R.

description:
Lured by the 7x7 list, I came here for the chick peas.  Note that they are not on the menu because they are a free condiment prior to the meal.  They were very good.  Four of us ordered a lot of different things.  Everything was really good.  They make the best mac n cheese that I've ever had.  What a surprise in Bernal Heights.

Food - 9/10

Value- 3/10

Service - 7/10

Conclusion - a very good restaurant but too pricey for what it was which is why I gave it 4 not 5 stars.
author: foodiewithadrawl S.

description:
I came here with a bit of reservation as my experience at the sister restaurant, Mochica, was less than stellar. However I left Piqueo's with a full belly, a smile on my face, and a few extra dollars in my pocket with the coupon from Bloomspot. One caveat...service was slow as a slug and many plates randomly arrive with no consistent timing between each so at one point we had too many dishes at the table and at another the table sat empty while we waited for our last dish which in fact should have been the easiest to prepare.

Anyhow...the food...

Cebiche Mixto - Good. Pretty much on-par with the ceviches served at every other Peruvian restaurant on the planet. I love all the crispy elements of the dish.

Anticucho de Corazón - Extremely tender (sign that they treated this normal tough muscle just right) with a really nice smokey sauce but perhaps a bit on the tart side

Crab Cake Peruano - Not really worth $16, but a really well presented dish. The potato chip crust didn't sound particularly appetizing but I was so very wrong as it added both great texture and flavor.

Quesadilla de Pato - My favorite dish of the night. I'm a sucker for duck confit and this quesadilla was filled to the edges with succulent duck meat.

Short Ribs (Stew) - I'm also a sucker for braised short ribs. Nothing really Peruvian about this dish although it did have a great green sauce (perhaps cilantro-based) that added a nice freshness and lightness to a dish that ultimately boils down to meat and potatoes...yum...

Clasico Paella - One of the better paella dishes that I've had and they definitely did not skimp on the seafood.

All in all, I'll definitely come back.
author: David H.

description:
Pulled pork- 5 stars
Short ribs -5 stars
Cebiche Pescano- 4 stars (a little too acidic)
Scallops- 5 stars
Plantains - 4 stars (little too fried)
Crab cakes - 5 stars
 Albariño wine- 5 stars! 

Service- 3 stars, not that attentive 

I really contemplated between 4 and 5 stars  because I didn't love the service, but the food should get a well deserved 5 stars.  Excellent meal! Will def be back!
author: Candace D.

description: I had no idea that this caliber of food was right around the corner.  What a fun little tapas place with a really friendly wait staff.  My girlfriend and I ordered a bottle of wine and 5 different tapas plates to share.  I would think that there would be some good dishes and others would just be okay, but that isn't the case here.  Everything that we ate really tasty.  Pleasantly surprised and will be going back several times in the future.
author: Brooks J.

description: Sangria... Amazing! Camaron crocante... Delicious!! Costillita de chancho... Yummy!! This place is really is really really really good!!
author: JP C.

description:
My husband and I have a 2 year old, and hadn't had a date since Avatar came out-please don't do the math!  Suffice it to say that we were hankering for a nice meal that did interesting things with our tastebuds, in a friendly and intimate setting.

Piqueo's was the perfect choice: the chocolate brown walls are relaxing, the service attentive, but really, it's all about the food.  And the food was great!  The sauces were extremely flavorful without being so rich that you felt that they had taken over the dish.  We had the ahi Tuna chef's special, which was perfectly done and artfully presented in a small tower.  The scallops were also extremely well executed.  The wine was reasonably priced, and the desserts, though not life changing, were delicious.

We highly recommend Piqueo's, and hope that our next date night comes soon!
author: Alison H.

description: Consensus opinion, Piqueo's ceviche blows away La Mar.
author: Carolyn Marilyn H.

description: Phenomenal tapas!!!  Tonight, my husband and I celebrated our first wedding anniversary with dinner here after hearing excellent things about the food.  Piqueos far exceeded our expectations!  If only I could leave a 10 star review!  The staff was all around very friendly and attentive with a special shot out to Engelbert for his amazing recommendations!  My favorites were the ceviche, anticuchos, and the dolce de leche dessert.  4 Tapas plus dessert was the perfect amount of food for 2 people. Can't wait to go back and explore more of their menu!
author: Rachel R.

description: Piqueos is the one restaurant in San Francisco that has the closest flavor to what real Peruvian food consist of. Out of all the Peruvians restaurants that I've tried in the city, Piqueos always meets my expectations as a Peruvian native. The dishes that I recommend are: seco de cordero, arroz con pato, ceviche mixto and anticuchones. They also have an amazing sangria topped with fresh fruits. I highly recommend trying Piqueos, they don't only have great quality of food but also customer service.
author: Michelle C.

description:
Tried this place for an impromptu date night. We were walk ins on a Friday night but we got seated pretty quick. 
We tried some tapas....yucca balls were amazing. Also had the crusted shrimp and scallops. Shrimps were delicious but scallops were really salty. 
We had also ordered the toasted pepper but they forgot about it and by the time we got it I was kind of full. It was very tasty but because the service was off I did not really enjoy it at the right time. 
Perhaps I am being a little tough with 3 stars because the food was actually really good but the service is a large part of the experience when dining. You could have the best food but if service is off the overall experience still leaves a bad taste in your mouth. 
The point is that there are a lot of restaurants out there and competition is tough so it's so important to do it right.
author: Caroline K.

description: I had a good bottle of wine here: Abel Mendoze.  The crab cakes were a little on the salty side but not bad.  Yucca balls were no good.  Don't order it.  The oyster in the Cebiche Mixto was overdone.  Otherwise, the dinner was nice.
author: Byron L.

description:
Going to Bernal Heights is like leaving San Francisco for a tiny foreign country.  And there you will find small and cute Piqueos, which offers some pretty good food, so-so service, and a price that will surprise you on the high side. 

Fried calamari were the high point of my meal.  They were not at all greasy and their coating was assertively spiced.  Great.

Short ribs braised in wine were tender, not at all fatty, but after the calamari this plate seemed a bit bland.  Too tame for me.

Tai snapper came stuffed with spinach and mushrooms and a pineapple chutney sauce.  There was so much going on on the plate that tastes were muddied and the piece of fish was undersized for the price.
author: David D.

description:
I've never been to a place where I absolutely fell in love with the ambiance. It's cozy with a very warm decor, soft candles, large windows to give it space and a fantastic open kitchen.  It's a great place to settle into after a day walking around the area. 

The tapas plates are simple but packed with flavor and filling for two.  To be perfectly honest, I don't really remember what we had but do recall the pork spareribs which was excellently cooked and meaty but some pieces were bony so be cautious when relishing this dish.  However, I can say there was nothing that I was disappointed in and I would go again just because it's just a gorgeous little restaurant.

Great for a date you're trying to impress or to get outside the hubbub of the city, walk the "hill" of Beranl Heights enjoy the view and then stop in at this little treasure.

ONLY reason this place did not get 5 stars is because, I had been given a gift that I forgot there and it mysteriously disappeared. I don't want to suggest the staff took it but I placed it in a very obscured spot that it wouldn't had been seen by a regular patron.  That was my only disappointment.
author: Deena B.

description:
I journeyed out into Bernal Heights of San Francisco for a good friend's birthday and found myself at Piqueo's -- an ultra-hip Peruvian Fusion Fantasticpiece. I practically danced (okay Samba'd to my own beat--I won't lie) out of the place as I drove off more than satisfied. 

First off, the group of 12 of us were seated in a small backroom that required us to be brought through the tiny place, alongside the kitchen, and out onto a covered/heated/enclosed deck of sorts. To be honest, I thought it was pretty cool. Its that whole elitist/VIP thing ya know? Ooooooh, Private Room!

Moving from decor to deliciousness, our group pretty much ordered a little bit of everything. From ceviche, to beef brochettes, to plantains, the flavors were both adventurous and strong. Fish across the board seemed very fresh, and prepared well. Almost everything was done very well in fact, with consistent touches of lime, tomato, and garlic. I enjoyed, literally, everything I tasted.
