Drinkwise, the wine selection seemed decent (other people had ordered a few bottles). I ordered Sangria (they do it blended in-house) and it was some of the best Sangria I have ever had. It was strong, fruitful, and deliciously dangerous.

Dessert shared among the group was rich, flavorful, and true to the Peruvian Fusion theme. The chocolate was unbelievably decadent, and a few bites had me more than satisfied. Word of note for you heavy-sangria-drinking-peruvian-barmaids: they don't serve coffee (not that I would know, since its not like I'm a heavy-sangria-drinking-peruvian-barmaid).

Its on the pricey side, but well worth it for a special occasion.  The service could use a little work (entree dishes came out at drastically different times, and left 2/12 -- including me -- dishless for upwards of 10 minutes). My bet would be that the same trouble wouldn't happen in a smaller group; the service beyond that was seamless. 

Impressed? Definitely.
author: Thom S.

description:
I've been wanting to check this place out for awhile. It's in a cute little neighborhood in Bernal Heights with lots of yummy looking restaurants. The hostess seated us out on their back patio, which was actually nice because it was a lot more quiet. I liked the ambience and coziness of the indoor portion of the place as well. Everything on this menu looked good- we had a tough time narrowing it down. We decided to get a bunch of little plates- mac and cheese, tequenos, cebiche mixto, tiger shrimp, and a side of corn. the mac and cheese and cebiche were the best by far, but everything was pretty tasty. we had the dulce de leche dessert and it was de-lic-ious, seriously amazing! the sangria was good too and i have to admit i was feeling a little tipsy after only 2 small glasses...

i'd definitely go back again.
author: Tami W.

description: Having eaten several times at most of the Bay Area Peruvian restaurants including La Mar, Limon, Fresca and Piqueo's my favorite is Piqueo's. Piqueo's dishes are the freshest, tastiest and most innovative. I had the fried chickpeas, ceviche sampler, tuna tartare, sangria, chicken skewers, roasted chicken and paella negra.
author: Konnie X.

description:
I'm really disappointed this place....
Every dish we ordered tasted burned and service was so slow...
Inside the restaurant was so dark and it was really hard to see anything...
author: osamu m.

description:
I really wanted to like this place more and give it 5 stars. The dishes sound inventive and delicious on the menu. Service was attentive and friendly and even got a free round of drinks on the house.Our server was kind enough to suggest that we had ordered enough for two (eyes bigger than our stomachs!)

Started with the Ceviche Chino Peruano with had Asian influenced flavors and was wonderfully acidic with a touch of heat and salt.

Had the blue corn and potato cake (pastel de choclo) which was kind of a waste of precious eating capacity since it was just mealy and pretty boring as well as followed by Tequenos which sounded amazing on the menu but were such a disappointment! Shrimp and cheese stuffed wontons...how could you go wrong right? Well, for starters, there was so little shrimp I absolutely got no seafood taste and then they messed it up even more by rolling the wontons in sugar!? It would have been nice if we got a heads up about the sweet approach - no thanks!

Finished with a shared main of Adobo which again, sounded good on the menu - pork shoulder braised in adobo sauce but sadly tasted like some overly sweetened marinara sauce (no spiciness whatsoever).

Sangria was decent but I got a wicked hangover from it plus some wine - hmm...

Ok, I guess I'm on the fence about this place overall. A Bloomspot helped sweeten the experience.
author: Steven H.

description:
Wow what a great find!  This should be a 5 star eatery, but there are a few flaws.  First the positives:  this was our latest try on our date night, and it was a terrific, great meal all around.  Everything we had, including the drinks, were great, tasty and original.  I think there was one mushroom tapas that wasn't up to spec, but everything else blew both of us away.  For desert we had a dolce de leche, I think I got diabetes but it was soooo good.  Simply put, this was a place I'd love to go to often and use it to impress guests.

Now the 1 star miss.  It's just waaaaay to pricey.  I have no problem paying up when all the elements add up...this includes food (priority #1), service and aesthetics.  The location of the restaurant just sucks.  It's a dumpy location plain and simple.  No good views, nothing out of the ordinary in the inside, and nothing that made me think the cost is paying for the site.  I also didn't notice that the fish or meats were free-range, or flown in fresh from japan, etc. so why the huge premium?  The tapas are just a rip-off...they were ranging from $12+...so if you get 2, you wont be full and out a good chunk of cash.  The mains were in the high 20s, so that's fine....but tapas should be less than $8 plain and simple.  

Still, we're going again for sure.  The tapas are just too expensive, but still tasty.  The mains and apps were priced fine and terrific.
author: A A.

description:
My partner and I called in advance to see if their kitchen was still open. Kelsey answered the phone and let us know that, even though it was late, we still had time to get in and order. We arrived and, believe it or not, Kelsey greeted us, seated us and served us. We asked a million questions and she was very patient with us. Kelsey also had great recommendations, too. The food was cram packed with flavor and we stuffed ourselves. Carlos Altamirano, the Chef, has something going! Even though the restaurant was really busy the kitchen kept the food coming. We really liked the Chino Peruano, sweet potato tapas, Aji de Gallina, etc. Our whole experience was incredible. We'll be back for sure!
Billy
author: Will B.

description:
First off, I just have to say...YUM!!!!!

I went here last night with my friends and it was fabulous!  They have so many tapas to choose from, so we decided to get entrees and split a tapa ( I picked blindly) and it was the Rellena  Papita- potato stuffed with meat, raisin and egg- with a creamy and a spicy sauce- we could have eaten just those for our dinner they were so good, plus when you get there they give you this awesome garbanzo bean concoction that was so fantastic, we had to order more for the table- a bathtub filled with this would have not been enough! de-licious!
My one friend had the Lenguadito Relleno- stuffed halibut- it was so good-- my other friend had the ribeye-yum, and I had the Tallarines Anticuchero- chicken, chorizo and shrimp pasta! mmmmmm!

the flan and the caramel desserts rocked too-
Next time- tapas only- they all look so good-
this place is cute- red walls, and a cozy atmosphere- it is where Moki's used to be- definitely worth going to, and the service was great!  My friend likes to put hot milk in her coffee, and the server brought out 3 creamers full of steamed milk for her!

go here!!!
author: Lisa M.

description:
YUM x seven, folks!

When I first looked at the menu, I thought: wow, kinda pricey. After I bit into the fried chickpea amuse buche (well, it's really their "bread"), it was like that w-r-r-r-r-r-u-p [needle scratching on vinyl record] noise that's so popular these days: THIS FOOD IS SOOOOOO GOOD--It's so very reasonably priced! (That's a complete flip-flop, but in a good way.)

On my first visit I ate the Empanada (yummmmm) and the Baby Octopus (double yummmmm--and thanks, little baby Octopus, for sacrificing your octopus teenage years and possibly adulthood for my dining experience). The food is fresh, the flavors, incredible... I would even say transportive!

I went back with a foodie friend and had the Duck Breast--superb, and some things that looked like big rice balls (no surprise from my friends that I like big ball thingies).

I went a third time with my brother and his son-in-law, and they now bow to me as the Master of Culinary Knowledge. No joke, they call me up and say, "We're going out to eat--where should we go?"

Delightful restaurant--all the dishes are good--but I still can't pronounce the name, or even remember it too well. The wait staff is very friendly, the atmosphere is very relaxed. A true neighborhood gem!

Drawbacks:

None that I have encountered. I even like the excuse to head over to Bernal Heights to eat there!
author: Russell H.

description:
We had dinner here on Tuesday evening and were seated immediately without a reservation. Yay!

The ambiance was very cozy / romantic. Tasteful decor (color scheme is spicy-earthy browns, rusts, greens and great pictures in the restroom!) and comfortable furniture--a table for two is just large enough to hold one tapas plate in the center to share.  Great mood music, and just loud enough to be audible without having to raise your voice to have a normal conversation.

We received a fried chickpea and Perunivan corn appetizer...YUM!!!

Our server was very personable and attentive.  He helped us select our wines and tapas.

We had about four dishes, the most memorable were the fried shrimp wontons that I thought was spectacular, until the peruvian corn masa thing with sauce arrived. It was so mind-blowingly delicious I competely forgot the rest of the evening, and where we were in conversation....all that exsisted for the next 15 min or so was my delicious corn cake thing swimming in this decadent sauce. It was a toe-curling experience. I even completely forgot to order plantains....

I'm definitely going back to taste everything else on the menu!
author: Sasha P.

description: Very cool spot in Bernal Heights. They have typical Peruvian cuisine along with Spanish style tapas. We tried the Cebiche Mixto, Seared Scallops, chicken chicharron and Yucca fries. Everything was prepared well, had great flavor and the portions were good for a couple to share. The yucca fries lacked a bit of flavor but nothing horrible. Service was great and we were seated immediately. Two thumbs up for this hidden jewel
author: Ernesto C.

description: Peruvian w/ a twist. Incredible. Too many tasty dishes to name! Go w/ a group & feast! Even w/ a 1/2 hr. wait. A must if yr in the neighborhood.
author: Franco P.

description:
I have to say, the concept of Open Table is not one which has ever sat well with me...I mean, jeez, are we that far gone that we cannot call up a place to make a reservation, anymore ?  Must the internet so 'simplify' everything ? But, if not for Table, I would not have ever found Piqueo's...which would have been a shame.

Right off...my favorite Latin-y/Tapas-y places in the city are B44 and Zarzuela...both superlative, consistent, and fun.  Both are also in the NE corner of town...which happens not to be where I am.  So it's nice to find a place on the southern side of SF.

I was very impressed.  Ambience was very nice...comfy, pretty, generally quiet as opposed to the boisterousness of the aforementioned.  Service was attentive and the food was really good.  A bit more experimental than your typical Tapas joint...and there was definitely a sorta Latin-asian sorta fusion going on in some dishes....but if you have a hankerin' for Latin American cuisine of a classier variety, this is a good place.

And apparently Piqueo himself actually is on-premesis (even on a Monday night!)...which you gotta love.

Wine list was nice...but the Sangria is way overpriced (good, but overpriced).  Also, the Pulpo (octopus) would be better served with sliced potato as opposed to mashed...but, it being the TEST of whether a Latin American place is up to snuff....the dish passed muster.  The octopus was prepared very well.....not undercooked rubber (see Pasion) nor overcooked jerky...but done to perfection.  They did a great job on the Fish dishes as well.  We wanted to go for the platanos, but our server gently  insisted we were over-ordering for 2 people, so we layed off.  (She was right).

Definitely will be returning there.  This is a very good place in a nice location.
author: El K.

description: Tucked in a renovated house with a limited number of tables behind a curtained front door, Piqueos feels intimate and cozy. The tables are close together, so if you want privacy for your conversation, look elsewhere. But the tables are also dimly lit, so you do still have a feeling of "just us." if you're comfortable having a romantic dinner within a few feet of others having a romantic dinner, then this is the place. And why would you come here in particular when there are countless spots offering romantic dinners in this great city? The food is fantastic. Perfectly cooked, great flavors, and plated beautifully. The service is quick and attentive, but not intrusive. We enjoyed every dish that came out of the kitchen, including the ceviche (trust me, this is the appetizer you want), the ribs, the shrimp. I cannot stress enough how good the food is. And when you're done, take a walk up to Bernal Hill a few blocks away and gaze over the beautiful city of San Francisco.
author: Leaf T.

description:
It was about 8 pm on a Monday night and we decided to eat there, and we did not have any reservations. There were a few tables up front in the main dining room, but it appeared that the only table available was for 4-people. I felt they could've given us that table or the tables could've been separated and we could've sat in the main dining area; however, the server decided to put us in the back room, literally!!!!! The back room I believe was intended solely as a work station, but they decided to had a few tables to increase the capacity. Our table for 2 was right next to the wine station, in fact, I sat about a foot away from the wine refrigerator. I was really concerned if they wanted to get wine, it would be a bump and grind moment, and it would be quite disruptive and intrusive to our dining experience. However, when one of the wait staff got some wine and got closer to us than we wanted him to be, it wasn't too bad, but annoying none-the-less. In the small back room there were tables for 7 people: 2-doubles and 1 for four, we were the only ones there, after one patron left. We sat directly under the speakers, and the music was so loud we had to ask them to turn it down! I'm thinking maybe those speakers were meant for the whole restaurant.  Needless to say, this was not a good start nor was it a good first impression!

OK, for a start we got some wine, me a chardonnay and my companion a red, which he claimed was pretty good. We shared an appetizer of octopus. OMG, it was like chewing on rubber bands, and atop a starchy mushy concoction of potatoes. And, to top it off it was charred, I'm being polite, it was burnt!  Again, not a good start.

For our main course I got the pork in an adobo sauce and my companion got the lamb. OMG, I thought France has a heavy hand with the salt when it concerns pork, but this restaurant has them beat. It was SO salty, thank god for the mashed sweet potatoes to offset the saltiness. On the other hand the lamb was good, but nothing spectacular. I literally had to order a another glass of wine to eat the pork and extra water. If you guessed that I didn't finish it you'd be correct.

We opted not to have dessert for obvious reasons.

If I could give this restaurant a half point I would give it a half a point above poor. Two out of the 3 dishes were very poor. Saving grace was the wine, and they do pour a nice generous portion.

Service was excellent, except for banishing us to the back room in "never-never" land. For the two of us we paid $90 including the tip! I think I'll skip this restaurant when I'm next in town and head over to the more established eating areas such as Noe Valley, Valencia corridor, or even the Mission!
author: Randy D.

description:
I completely agree with JJ from Oakland (above):

"The food was pretty good but it was expensive and the portions were small. If I didn't have the Groupon, I'm not sure if I would've gone."

Actually, I thought the food was delicious. But the portions were really puny for the price, which was substantial. We paid $15 (before tax) for two average sized scallops with a drizzle of sauce. And $12 for some spicy mashed potatoes.

I just think $10-18 for a tapas plate - when you'll need at least 5-6 of them to feed two moderately hungry people - is too much.

Adorable place, expertly decorated. Nice location on Cortland. Great food, but limited vegetarian options, almost no vegan choices. 

I'll most definitely go back, as soon as I hit the lottery.
author: Laura G.

description:
Wow, been a long time since I had such a bust of a night in SF.

The notes are many, so here we go:

1. The menu has changed from their online version. They have their own website (not menupages.com) but haven't bothered to update it. Usually, this is not critical, but in this case, leads me to the next point...

2. There is almost nothing vegetarian on the menu now. (see above for the real problem here - had we known, we wouldn't have come)

3. What was vegetarian, was useless. The plantains were average. The mac & cheese came out like cheese soup with a few noodles.

4. Two couples dining together. They order 4 dishes and we find 3 things to order. One by one, each of their 4 dishes hits the table. We watch them eat. They feel bad, we tell them not to worry and go ahead and eat. Keep in mind the arrival of their dishes was spaced out over 45 minutes - as they finished something, something else showed up. While we got nothing.

Finally it occurs to our dingbat, absent-the-whole-time waitress to say something like "uh, your food is on its way". Really? That's all you have to say to us at this point?

Our food finally arrived. It was useless (see above) but we were starving by now so we wolfed it down while our friends watched us eat, seeing as how they were done a while ago while we were still waiting for food.

If you are vegetarian or dining with anyone who is, I cannot tell you strongly enough - do not go here.
author: Shal J.

description:
Ate here a couple weekends ago with a friend and was very impressed. I think the space used to be a sushi place? It's completely transformed and a nice combination of cozy/hip.

Food was delicious, my friend doesn't do shellfish so I'm planning to go back for the ceviche and the chickpeas which we somehow missed. The tables are close together but I used it to my advantage to ask our neighbors about their order, it's that kind of vibe.
author: Anna F.

description:
This place is a quaint, romantic, yet well-rounded restaurant. You walk into a tiny candle-lit place and begin with a plate of little Peruvian munchie things of roasted corn, onions, cilantro, and chickpeas. Highlighted with their passion fruit sangria before the small dishes come out, the experience is heavenly. 

The place is relatively dark, and small, and might be a perfect place for Valentines Day - although we had a group of four with us when we went. We started out with the Ceviche - fresh acidic lemon and lime juices marinate succulent pieces of octopus, scallops and calamari. Accents of onion, fresh cilantro and roasted corn sprinkled on top reminds you you're eating Peruvian - not Mexican. 

We had several dishes - the beef short ribs, the guy next to us recommended it ...and it melts in your mouth. Mac n' cheese - baked - with a crumbly topping and most memorably, the chunks of fatty maple bacon swam in the thick white cheese sauce. Potato croquet balls that were fried on the outside and starchy on the inside. 

We had a few other dishes, but it slips me at the moment bc likely I was too entrenched in conversation to remember. The dessert was a mousse-like fluffy chocolate cake dessert, and flirting with it on top was a tiny scoop of mango ice cream - an interesting pairing to say the least (but delicious). 

It was a great, chill and romantic atmosphere, good for small groups or a couple, and sits atop of a hill in Bernal Heights. If you try to go, be careful around Alemany Road, it's confusing and we got lost and looped twice back over. 

All in all - a sweet place. Fine San Francisco cuisine never disappoints.
author: Tian L.

description: The waiter was so helpful with our selections but not overly intrusive.  Crab cakes and Mac and cheese are a must try as well as the sangria.  Also save room for the dessert.  Well worth the drive to Bernal Heights.
author: Cathy C.

description:
'Off the beaten path' is really the only  way to describe Piqueo's. Trying to find it is just as fun as the ambiance this little restaurant packs inside its walls. Its like a pinata of food. To be honest, I try and avoid small plate places because I feel like I end up paying for a lot of plate, and nooooot much food. Total opposite here. While the food is not cheap, it is plentiful the menu features some dishes I havnt found many places. The staff here is SO friendly and will answer questions about any dish, and when we ordered the beef heart, went on to tell us how its served in Peru. Free cultural lesson! score!

Cebiche Plate trio is a must. It features all of their popular cebiches. If you are new to Peruvian foods...go for it! The seafood stew was delicious and the goat cheese and duck quesadillas were dangerous. Come on...shredded duck and cheese? Nothing better. Well, almost. For the adventurous, order the beef heart. ORDER IT! I promise you it is not metallic or chewy or anything like you would think. Perfectly charred with a spicy red sauce...mmmm. Id go just for that. Piqueo's has a huge selection of wines(all Peruvian or Spanish), so pick one, bask the candle lined red brick walls, and just experience the food. I never had a reason to come to Bernal, but this is well worth the trek.
author: Spencer N.

description:
This place never disappoints.  Yes it's way out in Bernal, but, it's always worth the trek.  Just go down Cortland until you wonder where you are and then you'll see the place.

The food is Peruvian Tapas, so small dishes, and not the small portions you get at most other tapas places.  the quality and taste is consistently good in both presentation and taste.  Goes great with wine, beer or what became a fav, from when I lived in Peru, Inca cola!  Total score!

The wait staff is always friendly, attentive, and very knowledgeable on Peruvian cuisine.  The ambiance is hella chill and the red brick decor cool as well.  A great place to go on a date or with friends and fam for a good time.   

There isn't anything on the menu that isn't a hit...of course that depends on your taste.  Beef hearts might not be for everyone, but damn these are good.  Cebiche, duck, beef, seafood, cheeses, chicken and yuccas stuffed with seafood.  I'm not usually that big on sauces, but if done right, like they are here, i'm impressed.

Solid 4 1/2 stars.  I'd give them  5, but sometimes, the service could be faster.  Of course it's likely due to the fact they are busy.

The desserts are great and the dulce de leche rocks!  Check out the place, it's a hidden little jem, that is worth the trip.
author: Bryan D.

description:
I had read about this place awhile ago and had wanted to try.  Had pretty high expectations about the food, but for some reason didn't think the setting or service would be anything special.  

The food met and exceeded expectations.  I've had other Peruvian food in the city, but non better and most more expensive.  Great combination's and interpretations of traditional dishes.  Very fresh fish.  Sangria was good and powerful, although a bit expensive for what it is.

The big surprise was the service and setting.  Very cozy warm place with friendly helpful service.   All in all made for a great experience.   Definitely becoming one of my favorites.
author: Robert G.

description:
It's always a special experience for me to venture into Bernal Heights. It's off the beaten track in terms of San Francisco proper. The neighborhood has a magical feeling with the curvy, winding streets. The big green park on top of the hill, the majestic views of the city.

I was here with a group of about 6 friends. It's a very tight restaurant. Not for those who suffer from claustrophobia. We sat by the window which was great because it was quite warm inside. The ambiance is set by the exposed kitchen, dark, candle lit room, and the chatter of happy diners. I had a few glasses of wine, so the room seemed dreamlike to me.

Since this was a small plates type of restaurants, we ordered about 12 small plates and shared.

Here's some review:
Choclo Peruano - This was a salad made with a variety of corn that is grown in Peru. It has very large kernels the size of a penny. It's tossed with cheese, tomatoes, onions, and lemon-oregano dressing.

Bolitas de Yuca Relenas con Queso - Fried stuffed yucca balls with mozzarella, served with our salsa chupe. This was one of my favorites. Nice and crispy outside with a tender finish inside.

Ceviche Mixto - Mix of seafood marinated in lime juice/aji limo and rocoto, served with yam/Peruvian corn and cancha. Yum!

Chuleta de Cordero con Locro - Lamb chops a la parrilla served with pumpkin stew and fried mint leaf. Very tender and delicious.

We also had a pork dish that was very tender and juicy. Wish I could remember the name because it was so good.

I was in Lima and Cusco in 2007 and was impressed with Peruvian cuisine. Seems like it's taking a grip of the SF food scene.
author: Robert C.

description:
A top of the Tapas list on Opentable, you can't go wrong... right? 

I had such high expectations for this place which just reinforces that I shouldn't have these expectations ALL the time. The atmosphere is great! I think the wait staff was just fine. The ambiance is great too. The food was just so-so. And the temperature in the main dining room was too warm for my liking. 

The free tomato, feta cheese appetizer thing they give you to start was AMAZING. Refreshing, tasty, yummy.  Then we had the Ceviche Mixto. It was fine, but WAY too spicy. Victoria C. and my mouth were on fire after that experience. The fried Yucca balls were too potato-y. Barely ANY seafood stuffing in the dish. And super bland unless you drench it in the sauce that it comes in.  The fried plantains were too sweet, too mushy, too bad. Lastly, the sweet pepper stuffed with some beef was the best way to end the night... esp. when our waitress brought us bread to soak up the sauce.  Why wasn't I offered bread to begin my meal?  

The best parts... the free tomato dish at the beginning and my white wine passionfruit sangria. SO delish. The rest, eh.
author: Lisa L.

description:
I'm a big fan of Piqueo's and prefer it by far over other peruvian restaurants in SF. Along with The Slanted Door, this is one of the restaurants we bring out of town visitors to try. No one is ever disappointed. Usually our visitors haven't ever tried peruvian food and dinner at Piqueo's starts them off on a largely futile quest to find something like it in their home cities. 

The menu changes, but we always start with one of the ceviche trios.  Standouts from our last dinner there were the perfectly fried chicharones and the duck confit quesadilla. Yum!
author: Lily T.

description:
First, I must start by saying, they have the best mac 'n cheese I have ever had in my life, but after making 3 visits here, my dining experiences were enough to say there won't be another attempt to give Piqueos another try.

The food is ridiculously overpriced for the portions and the quality.  I don't mind paying for good quality, but this place just doesn't meet my standards.  The price definitely does not match the quality of food items.  The steak was tough and burned, the service was horrible. It took an hour to receive my food. 1 unfulfilling crab cake that was lacking any taste was $15.  If you want a decent crab cake, go to Ruth's Chris's.  Gary Danko can get a away with its prices, because the food is outstanding, but this place is just a complete rip off.
author: Krista L.

description:
Mac N Cheese Mac N Cheese Mac N Cheese.

Ceviche Ceviche Ceviche.

Yay.
author: ML ..

description: I particularly liked the freebie mixed garbanzo beanish snack provided at the outset of the meal, the cute ambiance, the shrimp in sweet potatoes (weird combination that turned out great), and the empanada (using the most delicate crust that made it taste like it had a French spin). Five tapas between two people ended up being a $56 meal (pre-tip), though we did not have alcohol; and it was the perfect amount of food (though we really could have done with one less dish, as we do not have huge appetites). I was teetering on the border between 3 and 4 stars, mainly because I do not see myself going back any time soon, which means I liked it a lot, but didn't absolutely love it. Also, the place is pretty cramped, and so my experience of the meal was in part tainted by the fact that I had a very annoying couple practically sitting in my lap. I would not have invited them to eat in my bed, but there we were, practically sleeping together. I opted for three stars because that honestly feels like the correct rating: "A-OK" but not "Yay! I'm a fan."
author: Morris R.

description:
We were here with a group and we almost ordered the entire menu. Here's a list of (some of the things) we ordered:

Bolitas de Yuca Relenas con Queso 
Humita Dulce con Shrimp Curry Sauce 
Anticuchon 
Champiñones al Ajo 
Camarones al ajo 
Ceviche Mixto 
Ceviche de Pescado 
Ceviche Tibio de Camarones 
Ceviche de Rocoto 
Churrasco 
Seco de Lomo 
Camarones Andino 
Sol y Sombra 
Tres Leches

The food was great! Flavorful, great presentation, and fresh but... a tad on the small side for the price (Unless the food was crazy, ridiculously good would I not deduct half a star for small slightly expensive plates). The sangria pitcher was pretty small and expensive, but good 

Service was good. Friendly, helpful and attentive staff 

Minus another half star for how hot the room was. Their kitchen opens up to the dinning room - when you're at the bar, you're face to face with the chef. It was uncomfortably hot inside. 

Be prepared to be seated uncomfortably close to the people next to you. Otherwise, enjoy!!!
author: Juliet Z.

description: Yummm. Lomo saltado is delicious. Cebiche de pescado is good. We also had some kind of purple potatoes in goat cheese that was reminiscent of nacho cheese to me but it was OK. Make a reservation, the place gets packed!
author: Niah N.

description: Food is delicious, but portions are a bit on the small side. This is a "splurge" meal for me because it's pricier than preferred for the actual amount of food they serve. But good, real tasty. It's also a tight squeeze inside. Expect to hear the conversation of the people next to you.
author: Be C.

description: I've never been to Peru but I after dining at Piqueo's I feel like I have. Dining here was  like taking a trip and experiencing a completely different type of dining culture. Bread basket? Don't need it when they keep brining out deep-fried chickpeas (which had me thinking I need to buy a deep frier and make these myself, chickpeas are good for you right?). The waitress was super helpful in pointing out the best offerings on the menu, everything we tried was phenomenal. The service was excellent, in fact someone between our table has having a hard time deciding between two dishes. After going back and forth for a little bit and deciding on an option it all be irrelevant because they brought out the other dish on the house for us to try (seriously, where else do they do this?!?). The recommendation was to order 1 entree or two tapas per person and so I ended up splitting 4 tapas with one other but doing some general grazing among the other food at the table as well. 4 tapas was more than enough for 2 people so unless you're super hungry I'd say a 3 for 2 split would work out. It's hard to say what I'd recommend the most out of what I tried. The ahi tuna ceviche might just be the winner though, so good.
author: Stephen S.

description:
The best food on Cortland right now. A little pricey for the food, a little dicey on the service. That said, if you bring a date, you'll probably get laid. 

Oh, except if the thought of your waiter saying a special of the day is a lobster tamale with coconut curry doesn't make any sense. Then, this place might be a little too advanced for you.
author: seth c.

description: Expensive for what it is, the sangria is a bit watered down, but they do have the BEST MAC and CHEESE in town.  Service was attentive, food was good.  I'd go back there anytime just for their mac and cheese.
author: R X.

description: Love this place! It has such wonderful menu items! I've gotten the duck quesadilla and the quinoa-crusted prawns a few times and love them both! This is a great little neighborhood spot with excellent food!
author: M'famous O.

description:
More like 3.5 stars for me.  This is a quaint Peruvian restaurant on Cortland that you'd miss if you blinked.  The inside is charming but rather dark (one of those restaurants that try to create an intimate ambience with candles, but at times it annoying trying read the menu and wine list).

The food items are quite plentiful but since there were four of us, we went with multiple starters and tapas to share rather than individual entrees.

Both our starters were excellent, especially the ahi tuna tartare (sweet and served with guacamole and plantain chips).  The ceviche mixto (red snapper, clams and mussels nicely marinated in leche de tigre (lime juice and peppers) was also good and provided a nice sour contrast to the sweet tartare.

Among the tapas, the standouts were the fried yucca balls stuffed with ham & cheese with rich andouille sausage sauce and the mac & cheese, which had a generous pouring of bacon.

None of the dishes were bad but I would have preferred that the scallops (daily special) were not fried.  The duck quesadilla sounded better than it was and the beef short ribs stew, while tenderly cooked, tasted bland.

We brought a bottle of 2006 Shiraz which was excellent but the wine list here was interesting (heavily Iberian and South American) that we ordered a few additional bottles.  The Ardales 2007 "Organic" (Spain) Tempranillo was good but a bit light for some.  The 2008 Mas Malbec (Argentina) was bolder and rounder.

We ended with the Suspiro a la Limena with dulce de leche with pisco whipped cream.  It resembled a rich caramel pudding.  Delicious.
author: F. P.

description:
We were really excited to try Piqueo's but unfortunately were a bit disappointed. We arrived and the place was empty but were seated way in the back which on one hand gives a secluded romantic feel, but on the other hand is a bit disconnected.

The food:
The yucca croquettes were good. 
The pulpito was overcooked (read: tough) and over salted. 
The causa was good but it was topped with a breaded chicken breast which tasted like it could have come from KFC. It was just an odd combination that did not work.
My favorite menu item was my guava drink actually. 

The portions are good sized so they are definitely good for sharing. 
Service was good.
author: Romeo And Lola K.

description: I really enjoyed my meal at this Peruvian fusion place!  All the dishes were tastefully and carefully prepared.  What I loved the most about it is that the ingredients were of the highest quality.  Grass-fed meats and organic ingredients.  The wine was great, and the service was excellent!  The atmosphere was enjoyable and I love that you can see the cooks at work.  I highly recommend it.
author: Marisol K.

description:
Beware the sweet sweet jugs of liquor. Something they mix in the drinks makes fun come naturally, and can cause great giddiness. Fruity and delicious, whatever came in that pitcher was potent.

But I digress, the food. I was with my ex and another couple, and we were seated at the window by the front door which was an excellent spot. We ordered around six small plates and a couple appetizers that ended up filling us all up quite well. The atmosphere was pleasant,  the staff courteous... but that was all blown away by the various flavors provided. The sea food dishes were particularly good, and we ordered everything with avocado on the menu and were not disappointed.

The entire evening went by in a haze... I didn't drink much, but my memory is filled with marvelous phantom tastes and much delight and laughter. Go with good company, share some delicious food and a jug of fruity alochol, and you won't be disappointed!
author: Adam A.

description: Wow!!! I am going to taste these flavors in my sleep... If I am lucky!!
author: Spunky M.

description:
Latin American countries tend to use similar staples, like plantains. Personally, I have never tried Peruvian food, but I was pretty sure ahead of time i wouldn't be disappointed. 

I loved the garbanzo beans with fresh salsa versus bread. The waitress told me it was the chef's invention. I shared a plate of Duck Paella with a glass of Sangria. The food was incredibly delicious. The location and ambiance is great. The only downfall is that the plates are small, so you generally shouldn't share plates. I wouldn't recommend this for families, groups, or kids. However, I would recommend this place for intimate dining with a loved one.,
author: Ana S.

description: We order tapas which I think is the only way to go. This way we got to try a few different items. I must say I enjoyed the experience.  There are so many restaurants in the City and this one is a good solid average+.
author: Heather J.

description: Love this place. Consistently good food and service. The sebiche is fantastic. I like the small tapas options. Its great to sit at the bar and watch the chefs at work. in fact thats the best way to decide on your food!
author: Martin C.

description: the food was top notch and the service was fantastic.  I loved the fried grabanzo beans they put on the table before you even order!
author: Yvonne S.

description:
we shared a couple dishes:

cebiche mixto -okay, but very small in size considering the price.

anticucho de corzon - very generous in portion.  the fella enjoyed this and said it was better than what he had in peru

scallops - my favorite dish of the night, but steep: 2 pieces for $15

stuffed squid - given gratis because the server spilled the bf's beer as she was pouring it in his glass.

the service is great, and we enjoyed the corn/bean complimentary starter.  the flavors were bold and delicious, but i do think the food is overpriced.
author: Sheri N.

description: We had one of those coupons so we brought the family here.  Arrived about 20 minutes early and was seated right away.   My 5 year old was licking up the ribs and my 8 year old loved the baked mac n cheese with bacon.  We also ordered the Yucca balls, ceviche and paella.  All of their items were very delicious.  I don't think you can go wrong with any of their dishes as the menu was mouthwatering.  For dessert, we ordered dulce de leche panna cotta with spiced whipped cream.  My husband said he wasn't going to have any but ended up eating most of it!
author: Sharon D.

description:
This place is amazing! loved the food, loved the service (servers are pretty hot!) Carolina, our server was excellent, very professional!
Loved the Humita dulce. The Mac n cheese with a Peruvian twist is outstanding. I can't wait to go back to try more items from their so extent menu.
Peruvian cuisine is on vogue! You have to try this place.
author: jorge k.

description: First time there and first time in the bernal heights area and thought it was a cool area.Ordered family style and shared everything with my date. We started out with Cebiche de Pescado and definitely enjoyed every bite.I have a mixture of fish, mussels, and shrimp.  You definitely would have to enjoy sour to order this one.  We also had the Paella and short rib and both were terrific and I would have no problem order both again.
author: Jason G.

description:
Holy crap. 

I have lived in the neighborhood for a couple of months, and have been meaning to try Piqueo's, and finally got there tonight in honor of my mom being in town visiting.  It was ah-mazing.  All of the dishes were completely original and delicious.  We had the Yucca balls stuffed with seafood, pork sandwich, chicken in peanut sauce, and the quail.  As good as they all were, I will get totally new plates next time I do because my guess is that everything is great. 

Don't leave without having the dulce de leche.
author: Genevieve T.

description:
Piqueo's is a quaint and charming restaurant nestled in a quiet Bernal Heights neighborhood.  The restaurant is small, but the atmosphere is cozy yet modern; a perfect setting for sharing tapas with your loved ones.  

We got acquainted with this restaurant after purchasing an Open Table certificate for half off.  We ordered a variety of items from the menu to share: ceviche mixto, ahi ceviche, bolitas de yucca, and 2 specials of the evening: a "surf and turf" and the paella negra.  Everything was delicious, with a few caveats:  there was a lot of large raw onion chunks in many of the dishes we ordered.  I actually quite like the taste of raw onion, but even I felt it was overboard, particularly in the ceviches and the paella.  The ceviches were bright and flavorful, but lacked a bit of panache it terms of knife skills and presentation for the fish (compared to La Mar's ceviches).  The bolitas de yucca were these wonderful fried balls filled with love and came with a sauce that will make you lick the plate.  In other words, GET THESE!!!  The squid-ink based paella was generously packed with assorted seafood.  The steak and scallops of the surf and turf dish were grilled perfectly (so tender but with a nice char).  We ordered a cava cocktail with chicha morada to accompany our tapas, but unfortunately I found the cocktail to be too sweet.

We finished the meal with 2 heavenly desserts:  the chocolate lava cake with pisco ice cream and the "Suspiro a la Limeña" (Dulce de Leche with pisco whipped cream).  According to another Yelper, "Suspiro a la Limeña" means "sigh of a woman from Lima" and how can you not be absolutely tickled by that?  The custard was dense and rich and much like a (satisfied) sigh of woman (from Lima or any other place).  

Service was attentive, but a bit slow at times.  All in all, we had a good experience at Piqueo's and will return to try other items on the menu.
author: Beth K.

description: The wine list is great, especially their imported selection.  Ceviche mixto was great, SPICY, but I loved it.  Mussels in a ceviche is a little new to me, but not bad.  We had a grilled marinated chicken skewer small plate that was amazing!  Quinoa crusted shrimp were really good, not heavy at all.  The paella (traditional) was more risotto like than a paella, but tasty!  Chocolate cake dessert was great.  Our server was very attentive and knowledgable.  It was BUSY on a saturday night, and the restaurant is not huge so make a reservation.  The groupon deal is great.
author: Rebecca W.

description: Since finding this hidden gem, my husband and I have been back several times. The food here is wonderful and so is the service. we have never had a bad meal, everything we've tried on the menu is excellent. One of the waitresses recognizes us each time and is wonderful. I just wish the hostess would be as friendly as the rest of the staff and how about a smile once in a while.
author: Elzabeth G.

description: The food is very good but I think on the expensive side.  I've left hungry after spending close to $90 for two people.  They should cater to the local clientele and have a locals special or midweek special.  Vega down the block does a good job of that - 1/2 price bottles of wine on Wednesday.
author: Heather F.

description: Piqueo's is such a cute restaurant. I recommend the beef stir fry which is really juicy and tender. I also tried the classic paella which was enough for two and full of sea food. The tapas are really small for the price, so I would suggest getting straight to the main dishes. Overall it was a great atmosphere, food and quick service.
author: Barbie P.

description:
Such a cute restaurant with a great ambiance and fantastic service. The place is a dimly lit renovated little house. it's nice and small so you feel welcomed and taken care of. my server was attentive, knew the menu, and very friendly. The chef also sent out complimentary ceviche! what a dream. the ceviche was so fresh and had such a great zest to it. 

we also had the ahi which was amazing, and the macaroni and cheese with bacon which was sinful, but delicious. if you're in the neighborhood, this place is a must. if you're not in the neighborhood, this place is a must.
author: Joanna F.

description:
Delicious food, great ambiance.
Enjoyed the chickpeas, tequenos, tuna tartar and seafood empanada.  My friend got the chicken which took *forever* and was ok but not great.  The chocolate lava cake was yummy but we have had better.
Overall, would recommend it for one on one dinner / date or small group of 4 or under.
author: Cathy L.

description:
I have been to Piqueo's a few times with my husband and it is very yummy. The food is cooked very well, and I love the presentation of the food. BUT the BIG PROBLEM they have is that it takes for EVER for the food to be served as well as water or drinks. This has happened to us twice now out of the 3 times we have been there. The first time we went it was not very full and we got wonderful service, the second time we went, there was 3 of us and each person got the main course served 20 minutes apart. For such small plates in the end we ended up waiting one hour, that was not ok. And the last time we went (yesterday), it took a while for the waitress to come to our table, and for her to serve us our drinks and appetizer, we also waited about 25 minutes for our food.
 The desert by the way is delicious!  I love the lava cake with Lucuma ice cream ;) yummy !!!
author: Inna R.

description: Great Ceviche, Sangria, and Yucca Balls. Nice ambiance. Excellent service - accommodating and expedient.
author: Scott H.

description: Bustling, a bit squeezed at the table (I was sitting along the aisle and kept getting brushed).  But food was delicious, fried yucca balls, the lomo saltado, the giant corn and ceviche.
author: Vanessa H.

description:
Had a very bad experience here. 

My BF made us a reservation for Valentine's day. We showed up a good 15 minutes before our reservation time so I wasn't expecting to be seated right away.... but I also certainly wasn't expecting to have to wait an hour and 20 minutes!!!!!!! Why did we bother to make a reservation??

The most frustrating part was that they seated 3 tables before us that had arrived after us because they had given us seats at the "bar" (which isn't a bar, it's just a counter where you can watch the food being prepared) so they forgot about us since we weren't standing on top of them and kept giving away our table. 

Had it been any other night we would not have put up with it and would have left... but since it was Valentine's Day we knew we didn't have much other choice besides McDonald's.

In the end we were finally seated... starving and frustrated. They did bring us a free dish to try to make it up to us although we didn't get to choose it so we weren't very happy with it. If the food had been outstanding they could have redeemed themselves a little and received a 2-star. Unfortunately we were not all that excited about the food, not that it was bad or anything.

It's very cold and drafty in the back, so if you do go here, try to get a seat toward the front.

Overall a very very unpleasant experience. Unorganized staff and therefore bad service. We will not be returning ever again.
author: Sandra E.

description:
Our early reservation turned out perfect in that we had the restaurant practically all to ourselves.  It gave us the opportunity to savor every single dish of the four we ordered.  The fried elote & garbanzo nosh we got prior to our meal was a delectable start.  Could have easily eaten a whole bucket of it.  To our waiter's recommendation I ordered a glass of their Sangria.  Que ricura! I was hesitant based on my experience with sangrias at restaurants, but this was delightful.  I won't preference any specific dish from the four we ordered for the simple fact that, without exaggeration, all were equally delicious!  The bolitas de yuca, cebiche de pescado, lomo saltado, and adobo de chancho were not only very tasty but also had eye appeal.  As an observation, the cebiche I'm used to back home in Panama tends to have the seafood diced smaller and has had enough time for the acid in the citrus to cook it completely until it's opaque.  The cebiche at Piqueos was a big larger but just as equally delicious and flavorful.  
Something else to note, our waiter (didn't get his name) was not only friendly and professional but also showed knowledge in the food preparation. 
I now know why this is one of my partner's favorite spot!
author: Jose R.

description:
My brother, sister, and I used a groupon to eat here and the service was absolutely horrible. We were seated in a little corner next to the restroom where no one paid attention to us. After we ordered it took over 30 minutes for our appetizer to come out, then it took intervals of 15-20 minutes for each of our dishes to come out- and mind you we absolutely did not ask for our meal to be family style where one dish comes out and everyone shares it. My brother finished his meal about 40 minutes before I received mine, and by that time I was already asking for my meal to go because I had spent almost 2 hours waiting. Did I also mention about half the people who came into the restaurant after us, left before us. I assume this means, if your skin is not wrinkly and white, they don't care about you as much. 

The food at best was okay. It was tasty but I could probably find Peruvian food on mission street that is much tastier, cheaper, and more largely portioned.  It is clearly overrated and overpriced, but I guess you pay for mostly presentation. To be honest I'd be much happier going to a hole in the wall restaurant than ever coming here again. And trust me, I'm a tremendous foodie, and I'm also a cook.
author: Melissa F.

description:
Located in the old Moki's, Piqueo's is a great addition to Bernal Heights. I don't always get out that way, which is a shame, since their small plate menu (the name is a colloquial version of piqueno, translated small) is lengthy and varied, and worthy of repeat visits.

Our waiter Tomas was personable and offered up his favorite selections, steered us away from others, which I tend to like in my servers. It really bothers me when someone says everything on the menu is great, I don't care if it really is, but I digress. 

So anyway, we were a party of three so he recommended about four small plates, then splitting two entrees. Like I said, the menu offers menu options, easy to mix and match, so while we all loved the pobrecito and bolitas de yuca for instance, we were equally sad that we didn't get to try the tamalitos and the chicharroncitos. What am I talking about? Oh the cuisine is Peruvian, and from what I gather pretty authentic at that. Again, my advice, go experience and experiment with the menu, ask advice from Tomas or whomever is on your table that night.

For entrees, go with the lamb chops, or the classic lomito saltado dish. Next time I go, it'll be the baked and breaded stuffed halibut with shrimp and mushrooms for me.

The wine list consists mainly of SpaNish and South American wines. We went with an excellent Malbec from Argentina, which rounded out the meal quite nicely.
author: Nish N.

description: I dined solo here on a Fri night using a $50 bloomspot and sat at the bar. Drawing from my prior experience at one of their sister restaurants, La Costanera, I had a glass of sangria, yucca balls, cebiche de pescado, and to go, the classic paella. Everything was brought out very quickly, and for my to go paella, which I asked before ordering if it would still be tasty as breakfast in the morning, my server was really great and gave me some advice to heat it up in a skillet and not the microwave, to prevent the seafood from getting rubbery. I ate it the next morning and it was one of the best breakfasts!
author: SiliconValleyShoeGirl L.

description:
I have to say...  I was pleasantly surprised by Piqueo's.  I had it filed under the "mediocre overpriced meaty food" category in my brain based on the Yelp reviews I'd read, so wasn't in a hurry to visit.

My friend was eager to take us here, so off we went.  And what a treat it was!   We ordered a bazillion little plates to share and they were all extremely tasty and well-presented.  (Except for those battered yucca things -- pass.)  There were LOTS of veggie options!  Even the desserts were delicious.  The service was very attentive and professional, and this was one of the best meals out I've had in some time.

Note: I haven't been to Peru, but I recognized some of the ingredients from my time in Ecuador (choclos!, quinoa, queso, plantains) and they were fresh and well-prepared.
author: Andi T.

description: Great Peruvian food options, good portions.. large enough to share and sample a bit of everything between a group of 3-5.
author: Sofia R.

description:
Our first piqueo of the night was Pobrecito, which is a rice cake made with white beans and then covered with plantains and egg. Tasting a perfect bite, a bite consisting of just the right combination of all ingredients, I knew I was in for a treat. Did you like how I casually dropped the name of the restaurant in the first sentence like I knew what it meant?? I totally had to google it though. Is it cool to mention Google in a Yelp review? What if I said I had to Zagat it to find out what it meant? Can you use Zagat as a verb? I would feel like a dork if I used Yelp as a verb. I Yelped Piqueo's yesterday. What a tool... But I am off on a tangent again and getting ahead of myself. 

We popped in on a Saturday night and there was a small wait for a table. No biggie. Once seated, our waiter Tomas guided us through the menu. He was knowledgeable and incredibly enthusiastic. We ordered a pitcher of Sangria and were surprised to see that when it arrived the fruit was separated into the glass before hand and you had to pour the wine over it. I thought it would affect the sweetness (or lack thereof) of the drink but it did not. 

The Pobrecito arrived next and was delectable. We opted for individual main courses instead of a grouping of small plates as I have to be in the mood for them. Duck, chicken, and halibut was ordered and consumed. Not one misstep throughout. We finished off our Sangria with rice pudding and were happy we ordered it. 

This restaurant is a new and welcome addition to my neighbor hood. ZANZIBAR!!
author: Bucky K.

description:
I have to start this review with the end of the meal because the dessert was amazing. We had three desserts that were all delicious;  there was a caramel dessert that came in a glass and it was verging on orgasmic. 

We had a fairly big group and shared a bunch of dishes (tapas and entrees). Some of the dishes were incredibly odd on paper and didn't sound particularly Peruvian, like the mac-n-cheese, and I was a bit worried. I worried for nothing because most of them were pretty incredible. Some of the dishes were just very good but nothing bad in the bunch.

I had the sangria which I thought was very good although, admittedly, I am not an expert on sangria.

The service was decent but nothing spectacular. It is also very pricey. The food is great, but it still seems like a lot for what you get. Maybe I am just cheap, but that is why this is not a 5 star review.
author: Lilly O.

description:
lovely ambiance. good lighting. but wow, i couldn't help eavesdropping on the couple next to us. table placement in the back is a little too close. was it a date? awkward! also, the music was a little loud at times. maybe that's why i could be all up in their convo, because you had to speak up to be heard over the music. 8pm on sunday is not the time for dance music. but they switched it up to chill jazz later on.

okay, on to the food: mmm cebiche! and fried prawns with quinoa batter! bbq ribs! and chicharrones de pollo, aka fried chicken! sweet potato fries!

good size portions. and nice wines. attentive and unobtrusive service. more avocado in the cebiche please. 

pretty spendy for the hill, but i guess i was the dumdum who didn't get a coupon. next time!
author: Wanda D.

description:
This was my first experience not only of Piqueo's but of Peruvian cuisine in general. The restaurant has a nice ambiance and the service is quick, friendly and efficient. 

We ordered a cebiche plate, along with the fried yucca balls, avocado dish and pork shoulder adobo. The cebiche was excellent. The avocado and yucca balls were decent, but left us wanting more form the next dish. The pork was very tender but oversalted, the sauces were tasty but lacked any kind of kick to the flavour that made you savour every bite. 

Don't get me wrong, the food here is good, and you will have an enjoyable experience, but it is vastly overpriced for what you get - and what you get is not a lot. We left feeling a little hungry and a lot lighter in the wallet. I would try Peruvian cuisine again, but probably not here.
author: Chris M.

description: Again, left Piqueo's feeling super stuffed and super satisfied.  This is my new go-to place for everything delicious with a home-cooked feel. This place is tiny so make sure you have a reservation.
author: Cindy T.

description:
First off, I've eaten *real* Peruvian food: head-on guinea pig, Tastes like ropey, gamey leather. Don't bother. Schmancy SF-Peruvian food, however, tends to be hyper-edible saucy stuff that makes for rather nice dates.

I'd have gone four stars, but the plates were way expensive for what they were. I got excited at the chance to pay $10 for fried smelts, but I felt a touch weepy when it turned out that there were only six of them. Smelts, in case you need a frame of reference, are about the size of a child's pinkie, but they're more tender and are less socially taboo to snack on.

Also the sangria tasted like regret and canned peaches.
author: jason l.

description: Love love love this place.  We sat at the bar and watched the kitchen staff cook and prep our food while we enjoyed a glass of wine.  Great atmosphere. In Bernal.  Kinda small and eclectic but has good energy.  We love Peruvian and Piqueo's is a solid 4-start plus a 4 1/2 star atmosphere.  Loved the stuffed calamari ensalada!
author: Rob W.

description:
If I could find the source of that delicious appetizer they hand out I might die a happy woman--full to the brim of chickpea goodness. 

I thought it was a little silly to head out to Bernal Heights for dinner but I was quickly convinced it was well worth the trip. This place is small but it doesn't feel too crowded. The servers are very attentive and genuinely eager to please. Clearly, they're professionals. 

The menu is more expansive than you might expect when you realize how compact the food prep area is. I'm a vegetarian and that limits the fare somewhat but the options are still delicious. 

Food presentation is fantastic. The sauces are perfect. 

We were the last ones in the place and no one rushed us. In fact, they poured some of the leftover wine our way. Great experience. Try the yucca balls.
author: Marita M.

description:
I've probably walked by this restaurant about 90x and have never gone in. Mostly because it's kinda pricey.

But.. it was pay day! (and my sister who works for "the man" offered to treat my non-profit salary to dinner.)

pitcher of sangria. (pretty good, although we agreed that we both like the white sangria at specchio's better.)
trio of ceviche (really good, with a little kick.)
plantanitas (amazing.)
duck quesadilla (good, but not mind blowing.)
camarones (probably the best of the savory dishes.)
chocolate cake with mango ice cream (incredible and my sister isn't even huge on chocolate)
____
total bill: a hundred bucks
author: Sabrina M.

description:
This is a great restaurant. The food and cozy atmosphere justified the cost in my expereince. Love it. If you are adventurous, try the beef heart skewers, tender and tastful!! Also went to La Costanera earlier on but love Piqueo's more.

We called for reservation 2 hr ahead of dinner time on the same day and got the voice mail so we left our reservation request details on the voice mail as instructed. They didn't have our table when we arrived. Apparently, they called me back and did not get a hold of me so they didn't take the reservation voicemail as serious. I didn't get any vmail on my phone. Fortunately, someone did write down the phone messages and they did find a piece of paper with my name and phone number even though it's not on the reservation list. The hostess gracefully got us a table after a short 15 min wait because of the reservation vmail mishaps. Thanks for the accomodation. So, make sure you talk to a live person when you call for reservation!!
author: Angela C.

description: Just GREAT food.  It is so well presented, so fine.   Everything looks beautiful and tastes great.  Not cheap, but I brought in friends from out of town, and they were quite impressed.  If this place lowered their prices just a tad it would be the best deal in town.
author: Joe S.

description:
Lazy Sunday with my husband-to-be, dusk was setting in and our tummies were talking. We responded to its desire to have a lil latin flavor. We decided to go to Piqueo's.

It was quite a trek, as Bernal Heights pushed us with gusts of wind that gave us  a nice push to Piqueo's front door. There was a bite to the wind and we were chilled. As soon as we entered into the restaurant, it was as if the sun beamed on our bodies. The terra cotta walls transported us to the warm lands of Latin America.

Instantaneously I was warm and fuzzy inside - with the help of the scrum-dili-om-cious passion fruit sangria. The fried chick peas were a delight - a true symphony of flavors. The adobo pork shoulder paired nicely with the garlic spinach and the deep fried yucca balls.

Masterful....
author: April D.

description: Excellent food, TERRIBLE service.  One person's entree came with the apps and no one greeted us, it took 10 min for a someone to come to our table and our waiter was as friendly as a scared unhappy cat.  Go somewhere else is you want to feel welcome.
author: Christopher S.

description:
My GF took me to Picqueo's for my birthday dinner on Saturday night. We had a great meal and very helpful service. It's a gift to have another delicious restaurant on Cortland for the "foodies" of Bernal Heights to feast in. 

I loved this restaurant and can't wait to go again. At our request our waiter was quite helpful recommending his favorite items from the menu. We took his advice and only ordered dishes he suggested and we were very happy with everything we ate. I regret, however, that we didn't order his dessert recommendation because the 2 desserts we shared were both average. 

Tapas:
We started with a couple of items from the tapas menu: Camarones al ajo (Sauteed shrimp with sofrito garlic paste, soy sauce served with grilled bread ) & Pastelito de Choclo (Peruvian corn cake with potatoes, saffrito, queso blanco y salsa de maracuya). Both of these dishes were very good, especially the shrimp. I can't wait to sample other tapas items on future visits.

Entrees: 
We both shared an entree from the dinner menu: Chuleta de Cordero con Locro (Lamb chops a la parrilla served with pumpkin stew and fried mint leaf). This dish was fantastic, the kind of dish I could get cravings for. Very memorable.

Dessert:
For dessert we shared two items: Torta de Chocolate 
(Chocolate cake served with lucuma ice cream and caramel sauce) and some kind of pudding type thing (I can't remember the name). We didn' finish either desserts since they were average and unremarkable (unlike the rest of our meal). 

For the record, our waiter had recommended the Passion Fruit Mouse, which I will try next time. But if that is only average too, I might skip dessert at Piqueo's in the future. The desserts didn't suck they just didn't move us.

Corkage fee:
Piqueo's does have a $15.00 corkage fee, which was not advertized on their menu and even Yelp says they don't have a corkage fee. We had brought a bottle of 2004 Porter Creek Zinfandel (Dry Creek) and after the waiter had already opened it he said, "you know we have a $15.00 corkage fee." I said, "actually, I didn't know that, as it's not on your menu." He didn't waive the fee and we weren't in the mood to argue. I will change this mistake on Yelp to reflect that they do have a corkage fee. 

I can't wait to go back to Piqueo's again. I loved it. Delicious.
author: Yvette K.

description: We had a Bloomspot $50 voucher, so we ordered lots of different things family style.  Everything was great with clear flavors, fresh ingredients, interesting combinations.  The corn cake was really unusual and delicious.  We got the Ahi ceviche with a yummy almost Thai-style lime marinade.  The scallops were good too and everything was nicely plated without going overboard.  People seem to say the prices are high here, but I found them to be comparable to most popular restaurants. The food is 5 stars, but it's a bit too dark to appreciate the artful food and loud for comfortable conversation, so lose a star there.  But we'll request to be on the back patio next time, where it's brighter and less noisy.
author: raven n.

description:
For the record, my native SF booty never travels to Bernal Heights.  It's out in no man's land and I have visions of parking issues that resemble the mission.  Well, since I'm on a expand my restaurant kick, we headed out there and what a surprise.  Parking right away.  Cute neighborhood.  Restaurant is cozy, we sat in the back patio.

Waitress informed us that the kitchen was backed up so she gave us extra deep fried chickpea complimentary appetizers.  People, we could have just had that for dinner and been happy.  Those little guys were GREAT!  

Sangria - tasty, Paella - good (portion not as big as places like Esperpento, but still good), Chicken Tamale tapas was yummy, and the Scallop and beef (mar y tierra) was good, though the bean mix thing was just ok.

It was a pleasant surprise.  It's a little pricey, but for a new adventure, it's worth it.
author: Denice L.

description:
If you want to get away from the "Mission Hipsters" then come on over to Bernal Heights which has a far better feel of what sophisticated San Francisco has to offer. The neighborhood is up-and-coming with lots of new restaurants and quaint coffee shops and a pretty decent yoga studio not to mention some of the best views and off-leash dog parks the city has to offer.

As we live in the neighborhood, my boyfriend and I eat here on an average of once a week and it's a fantastic restaurant and a cozy venue with great people watching (if you are lucky enough to sit by the window to watch the folks pass by on Cortland).  

The plates are small which is lovely as I find that traditionally, restaurants put too much food on the table.  My boyfriend and I share two, maybe three plates of food and feel satiated and happy.

My favorite is the Choclo Peruano  and I wish they sold it in large to-go containers as I could live on this stuff!

My best girlfriend from Peru turned me onto this place telling me it was authentic and fabulous and she is RIGHT!

The wine list is quite good too!

bon appetit!
author: dianthe h.

description: This was my first visit to Piqueo's.  First of all, the service was outstanding!  The complimentary fried chickpea salad they serve you upon arrival is really yummy and very addicting.  We ordered a caraffe of Sangria - delish!  The Lomo Saltado was cooked to perfection and we also had the Ahi tuna ceviche.  Both dishes were great and were presented well.  Piqueo's is a great little neighborhood gem.  I will be back.
author: Roxanne E.

description:
Excellent food but a flawed experience.

We settled on the restaurant after noticing a good selection of vegetarian entrees on the menu posted on their website. I'm an omnivore, but my SO is not and very tired of pasta primavera and grilled portobello mushroom surprise. Unfortunately, most of the vegetarian dishes on their on-line menu did not appear on the real menu handed to us in the restaurant.

We arrived promptly for our OpenTable reservation. The front desk took one look at us and marched us to the back of the restaurant and sat us behind a partition to remain out of sight of the younger, hipper patrons.

In terms of life's little insults, this rates as a trifle. But I think I will make everyone happier by not going there again.
author: Martin C.

description:
Thus far, Piqueo's is home to my favorite tapas - anywhere.  My visit to Piqueo's marked my first visit to Bernal Heights -- and I'll definitely be back.  

On a Saturday night, the restaurant is busy, but not packed (probably a result of being located in such a sleepy neighborhood).  My bf and I had a reservation, but it's probably not absolutely necessary.  The lighting is dim and romantic, the music has a great Latin rhythm, and the decor is trendy and cool.

Upon being seated, you're welcomed with a bowl of fried garbanzo beans in a sort of pico-de-gallo mix. Delish.  The bf and I ordered sangria - which we both agreed was the best sangria we'd ever had.  (The bf hates that sangria so often tastes like cheap Merlot. Piqueo's sangria = a sip of heaven).

Between the two of us, we ordered 4 tapas dishes and 1 dessert.  This was definitely enough food for two starving people and probably too much for two moderately hungry people.  We had the tequenos (fried wantons stuffed with crap & shrimp, covered in powdered sugar w/drizzled raspberry sauce and guacamole) which were delicious, but  might be good to have last instead of dessert since they're so sweet.  Next we had a Peruvian corn puree dish in an avocado mousse. Tasty, but not my fav.  Third was the fried calamari.  Really the best calamari I've ever had (but after the tequenos was overkill on the fried food).  Last, we had the pork costillas (short ribs).  Definitely my favorite dish of the 4.  SOOO darned good.  

We were pretty full after our 4 tapas, but simply couldn't resist the dessert menu.  We asked our server to help us decide, and she recommended the quinoa flan.  A-M-A-Z-I-N-G.
author: Diane E.

description:
Mmmmmmmmmmmaaybe I'm gonna reveal my culinary ignorance or naivete here but I trust my my taste buds, which have traveled around the world and have good taste, and they told me that this is some of the best comida I've ever had in my 25 years of food awareness. Really, really, really effing good.

I don't think it's on their menu online but there was a mound of out of control, orgasmic, perfectly horseradishy potato with ahi tuna and a layer of something, by turns stupendous, wondrous, piquant and provocative New Zealand mussels lightly fried and served with ensalada de lechuga y crema de rocoto(?), mini white beans and rice cake served with platano & egg (damn) , and a sweet potato flan with orange-canela sauce and chifles(?) which was so obnoxiously good it was almost disturbing. Paired with an '03 Duero, this was an extravagant sojourn into original, inventive, delicious and beautifully presented tapas that consistently rocked, served with a smile. I have no doubt that everything on the menu is a further, scrumptious immersion into a world of flavorful corn, potato, shrimp and queso blanco eggstacia. Amazing sauces too, which are apparently a secret.

We went on the early side when the place was nearly empty, and after a brief moment of maitre'd-m.i.a., the service was impeccable. It was full or just about when we left.

The degree of "authenticity" is questionable/unknown by this eater, but who gives? This nicely painted, not cheap Latin American Bernal tapas gastro-treasure non-pareil is off-the-map bueno, and a tasty reminder to get  my coolo to Peru. Salut.

Edit - I suppose I should state that the only reason I had this amazing experience is because I went with my Dad's wife, who footed the bill. How nice it was, while stuffed and buzzed, to get an idea of the somewhat alarming bill, but not have to be involved with it.
author: Mark G.

description:
I'm really excited there is another restaurant in Bernal Heights. I thought the Sangria was great, the service was awesome but the food was disappointing. The seafood dishes, although I thought they were seasoned well, there lacked a freshness to the bite. The non-seafood dishes were pretty good. We ordered the Tamalito Criolo and Yuquita Fashion and I was very pleased.

It is a cozy atmosphere and its a fun place to hang out.
author: Cat B.

description:
What a great surprise! Went to the former location of Moki's to mostly see what the new owners did with the space and had an incredible and truly original meal. Never had plantains with cheese and other incredible pairings. Even the sangria was special.

Service was competent, portions small and a bit pricey, but it was well worth it and I have been back since.
author: Alice H.

description:
It takes a god-damn operatic display for me to drag my ass to the computer lately and write a yelp review.   This be now my fifth intention to write a rave review after five outstanding dinners.  

Without going on and on with tedious professions of adoration, suffice it to say that Piqueo's is my new favorite restaurant.  
I recommend it to everyone, along with their specialty dishes, the scallops, the tomatillo, the bistec churrasco, and so on and so forth until the menu has been listed.  Im not Peruvian but I know a great meal when it encounters me.
My four cents.
author: Jen L.

description:
We had a bottle of water, two glasses of wine and two entrees.  We had the lamb and the pork, both of which were super yummy.  The service was sweet and attentive.
The place was not packed on a Monday night.   My only complaint was that even with a groupon for $40, we still shelled out about  $24 each with tip. .   I do find that a bit steep; but for something blocks from my home, I would come back.  It was delicious!
author: Andrea S.

description: So cute!!! I love this place!!! The service is impeccable and the food is out of this world! Go and then go again!! Every time I go I have a new experience. Its really kinda amazing!
author: Bobbie M.

description:
I just came back from Peru, so I was pretty excited when this little place opened in Bernal a few weeks ago.  
You can order tapas style or there are larger dishes if you are more of an a la carte person.  I went with my friend who is preggers, so we didn't order any alcohol or ceviche, so I can't comment on that.
What I can say is that the food we got is really good, although a bit on the pricey side.  

My favorites: Corn cake--yummy!  And the plantains are quite lovely.  The sweet potato flan--awesome!

The cons: Plantains arrived with all of our entrees--it would've been better at the end of our meal since the sauce was very sweet and overpowering.  The fried yuca was dry.  And the bar seating near the aisle--really crowded.  Ok, I didn't make reservations, but why put two seats near the bar that should just function as an aisle for the wait staff.  
With that said--I'll go back again to try the ceviche!
author: Miranda S.

description:
So, in all fairness I was warned by my best friend that we shouldn't go to dinner at a place that had been open for only two days. But, we went anyways....

Seriously, you may not want to read this if you ever plan on eating here....

So , we decided to sit at the bar since the place was packed. This was the first of many bad ideas as we could see directly into the kitchen. 

Our first waitress came over (1 of 4 that we ended up having throughout the night) and we explain that S. is allergic to wheat and gluton.  She says ok and recommends the first 3 things on the menu. Now, I'm no  brainiac but I'm pretty sure that breaded and fried probably implies wheat... Ok, here comes waitress #2. We ask her the same thing and she says that she will ask the chef. After 15 minutes, along comes waitress #3, new explanation and still no clue.... Waitress #4 finally answers some questions so we order. I love ceviche so we order that as our appetizer.

When it arrived, it looked awesome, but looks can be really deceiving. The fish was some gigantic, odd cuts with tendons and really chewy. The flavor was good but the fish was completely raw. Isn't ceviche supposed to be marinated for sometime before being served? 

So, at this point, I notice the guy preparing the ceviche. He mixes it up, takes a little taste, and then, ew, puts the spoon back in the bowl. I stop eating the ceviche and tell S. Since the guy is right in front of us, we keep watching.... He does this over and over until he notices us watching... At this point, he tastes, then wipes off on the kitchen rag that I just saw him use to wipe off the counters, and back in the bowl it goes.... Appetite is fading fast....

2 more small plates arrive, but by now, nothing tastes good, except the wine which was awesome. Good thing I lilked it because we never got any water after asking twice...

The skewers were good and although I would love to tell you about the other thing we ordered, it never came. After waiting an hour for it, I went and found our waitress and cancelled it.  She was bummed and gave us a free dessert- hence the 2 stars.

Ok this place sucks, but they're trying....

Go and risk it if you want, but if that chef has the herps, you might be regretting that choice for years to come :)
author: Tasha R.

description:
**This review is of the staff and staff alone and not the food as I actually haven't had the food yet.** 

I had a personal issue and needed to use a bathroom to fix it, but the place I was coming from across the streets bathroom wasn't working. I asked and they let me use it and even at one point asked me if I was okay or needed help. That alone makes me want to go back to this place and try stuff, as they were willing to help without worrying about the profit OR anything else.
author: Valerie F.

description: What a wonderful recommendation by a friend.  A little hard to park around here, but probably true of any place around SF for a Friday night dinner.  It's a tiny restaurant, but the ambiance is warm and inviting. Sat at the bar where we can watch the action and were not disappointed.  Loved watching all the various dished coming out, which helped us decide what to order as we took the time to peruse the menu.  The little amuse bouche was so good that we shamelessly asked for seconds.  If I can order that for a main dish I would!  Our four tapas dishes proved to be too much food, though we couldn't help ourselves since there were so many interesting things to choose from.  The Pobrecito was great, along with the Arroz con Mariscos (Peruvian paela).  Can't wait for our next visit.
author: Stephanie L.

description:
Two word, SOOO GOOD!

My friend and I shared some sangria. So yummy. We then had several tapas; duck quesadillas, grilled octopus, and megilones... so good!!

The service was great and and the staff had great recommendations.
