The ambiance is nice and relaxed, even if its packed and a full house. You'll definitely score points here if its the first date or even an anniversary. 

After dinner take a nice walk outside and around the neighborhood. Great way to end the night :)
author: Amanda S.

description:
Right across the street from Sandbox Bakery, I had been watching this place for a while and decided to go when Bloomspot had a deal.  We loved it!  Candle-lit and warmly decorated its the perfect place for a cold winter night.  

My favorite dish was the Inca Cola ribs.  

My husband loved the papa rellena, it had that authentic raisin-meat flavor combo we remember from Peru.

The Cebiche de pescado was one of the best we've had in the City.  They even brought a big spoon to finish off all the juice, just like they do in Peru.

We weren't wild about the yucca balls that other reviewers liked, but we were looking for something authentic Peruvian- these were trendy SF.  

Be sure to ask for picante on the side and they bring you a small dish of rocoto, adds a great kick to every dish if you like that.

The chicha morada was large,thick and cinnamon flavored, a great deal at $3.

Go for a walk on Cortland Ave after dinner, its cute and has some great views of the City.
author: Brenda B.

description:
Opening today!!!!!!!! April 6, 2007...5:30pm

(Gates & Ellsworth) remember that MOKI's is over @615 Cortland if you want better prices for Japanese/Hawaiian...why'd they (Piqueo's) choose this location..for the different demographic mix to surrounding restaurants?

LOWER YOUR PRICES....Why are they charging sooo much?
Too expensive for its own good, but hey, they gotta pay off the loan on their $60,000 remodel job. 

Well, anyway, you can get your ice cream on at M. Mudd, then your DVD movie for the weekend at four star video and just hang out for the weekend saying...yes, another one for the yelpers.

I will stick with FRESCA's until they lower their prices because Mochica is their older sister with the ceviche sticking out for a nibble.
author: miriam b.

description:
SSSsshhhh... Maybe if Piqueo's continues to diminish the size of their portions, people won't figure it out and keep coming back! The Fools!

Having visited this place since literally the week it opened - it's been depressing to watch each plate with anything more substantive than potatoes get progressively more and more puny over time. Seriously - when i order STEAK saltado, I expect there to be some damn steak on the plate!

It all started so great. We would coo and bring friends and visiting family to the new neighborhood restaurant that served great, fresh tasting Peruvian food. How sad it is when the same dishes we ordered time and time again seemingly shrink from one visit to the next - while the prices stay the same or rise!

It's reached the 'painful' threshold that makes going here for an evening meal no longer reasonable for what is actually served. 

Hope they get a clue!
author: matt n.

description:
OMG!  Love this place!  Great atmosphere, amazing ceviche, just the right amount of citrus.  Three of us shared a ceviche, and 3 small dishes which was perfect.  Get the ribs.

I love Peru, was so happy to find this great restaurant that did Peruvian cuisine justice!
author: P G.

description:
Still flogging the "new restaurant" excuse?   OMG, this place is a disaster....but I can't assign culpability  to the wait staff, even though they're entirely unsuited for the work at hand.  Frankly, I wasn't sure if any of them had ever worked in a restaurant.  All that being said, the owner/management has to take responsibility for the debacle we experienced on Saturday.  

Where do I start?  8:45P reservations, 9:45P seating.  It took three requests for a glass of sangria (cloying sweet, several in my party refused to drink) while we waited before the second wait staff finally got a hint .

The food was just a joke.  Two 60 count shrimp, two mussels, frozen peas and two ice cream scoops of rice.  This is Peruvian paella, according to Piqueo's and I'm not exaggerating.  And I never got my appetizer, or my dessert.  Other than that, can't wait to drive all the way to Bernal Heights and knosh with the comfortable shoe crowd.

If you're set on risking your time and money on this place, I'd recommend waiting another two months to see if they can get their act together.  And don't waste your order on the "paella".
author: PeterDragon D.

description:
It's hard to find a neighborhood joint with easy parking, great food, wonderful service, and easy to snag reservations at a short notice (even for a big group), but Piqueo's fits the bill.  

Food - 4 stars.  The standouts are the tapas---delicious sauces, good variety, and fresh ingredients.  My favorites are the crabcakes, chicarrones de pollo (fancy chix nuggets), and the mac & cheese with bacon--oh my! The free fried garbanzo beans are downright addictive so don't be afraid to ask for extras :)

Service - 5 stars.  The people here are top-notch.  They are very attentive, friendly, and recognize you only after a few visits!

Prices/portions - 3 stars. This is probably my only gripe.  The prices for the portions are a little hard to swallow but the quality of the food is worth it.  Plan to have 1.5 to 2 tapas per person which adds up.  Also, ask for bread so you can soak up all the great sauces.  We paid about $50 per person with sangria so it's not as bad as most SF restaurants but you don't walk away really full either.

If you have a big group, ask for the private back patio area--it's covered and there's a heater.
author: Marissa D.

description:
New place that that just opened up this week on Cortland in the old Moki's spot. The space is nicely remodeled from the old Moki's days: deep red walls, paper lanterns, nice tableware, photo realistic paintings? or just giant photos? hung on the walls. It was already crowded when we got there on a Wednesday night at 7pm. We waited about 10 mins for a table. 

We ordered the following: 
1) Ensalada del Huerto -salad with goat cheese
2) Causita Tradicional - mashed potatoes layered with chicken -- this was the favorite dish of the meat eaters
3)Pastelito de Choclo- corn cakes -- pretty good, a giant fried corn cake 
4) Championes al Ajo  - this never showed up...  : (
5) Platanito Maduro Frito -fried plantains served with a mustardy sauce--yum! 
6) Yuquita Fashion - fried yuca, looked like fried bananas -- a little on the sweet side
7)Pobrecito --white beans, rice cake and egg--tasted like home cooking! 
8) Ceviche de Pescado --halibut ceviche--the meat eaters loved it, and asked for bread to soak up all the juices.

Dessert: 
1) Sol y Sombra --Rice pudding with purple pudding corn--not a big fan of this one
2) a Caramel dessert with a meringue topping--that was SO good. It tasted like eating a cloud! But definitely VERY sweet, one of these could feed 3-4 people. 

So, everything overall tasted great, not too greasy or oily, even though mostly all the veggie dishes were fried. It actually all tasted kinda healthy! And I didn't feel grossly full afterwards! Sangria was so good and nicely alcoholic with plenty of fruit to soak up the alcohol. 

I think this is a great start to a new restaurant. However, I have to knock one star off because of a few things: 
1) They forgot the mushroom tapas we ordered
2) The waiting area is non-existent, so you're awkwardly waiting in the middle of the restaurant or outside in the cold. Heat lamps, perhaps?
3) It got kinda loud in the restaurant, so much so, that it was hard to hear each other talk at times. 

Other than that, I will definitely be back. 
Good food +  good sangria + good service = good combination!
author: Caroline C.

description:
What a delightful new addition to Bernal Heights! And oh, what balls of goodness! (read on to see I'm not being dirty, here!)

You MUST order the Bolitas de Yuca Relenas con Queso (Fried stuffed yucca balls with mozzarella, served with salsa chupe) as one of your starters - YUUUUMMMM-EEEEE! I probably could have had 3 orders of these and nothing else, and would have been completely satisfied. 

But it only got better with the rest of the stuff we tried. Between the 2 of us, we shared 4 plates, and one of the other stars was the Pastelito de Choclo (Peruvian corn cake with potatoes, saffrito, queso blanco y salsa de maracuya). Mmm, mmm, good. The Pobrecito (Mini white beans, rice cake served with platano & egg) was also kind of interesting, but personally, I found it a bit boring (though my friend really seemed to enjoy it). Oh, and the scallops - those had a fantastic sauce, though i must admit, the scallops weren't the best I had ever had. Still, quite good. 

We also shared 2 desserts. We both really enjoyed the Sol y Sombra (Rice pudding and Peruvian purple pudding corn with cinnamon and fresh fruit). The other one (name escapes me) was way too heavy on clove, though - it was overpowering, unfortunately. But hey, if you like clove, you might really love it. 

Our waitress was really nice and appeared when we needed her. Also poured us healthy tastes of the port and dessert wine which we inquired about, which was nice and helpful. Both were very good, but we both opted for the port. Again - YUUU-UUUM.
author: beth l.

description: Outstanding, ceviche is to die for, prawns and scallops are orgasmic. Sangria was perfect, not to sweet.
author: Linda W.

description: Solid food with a great cozy atmosphere - neighborhood gem, but would also be a destination i think for non neighborhood locals.  Paella with squid ink was nice, ceviche was very tasty.  We ate mostly veggie/seafood for 1st time b/c of company, would try some meat dishes next time.  Definitely would recommend trying - all dishes were fresh, flavorful and well balanced!
author: hary n.

description:
Service was slow.
Food was OK.
Small plates.
Very few veggie options that aren't starch only.
author: Jennifer C.

description: I absolutely love Piqueo's! I enjoy visiting with my friends and sharing appetizers over a few pitchers of sangria.  This is a place where you want to arrive and have a reservation--trust me, it will be busy. The service is fast and their staff, friendly.  I believe Piqueo's is a sister restaurant to Mochica (Harrison & 5th).  I trust their flavor is just as in tact as Mochica's if not better.  If you're looking for tasty and traditional Peruvian food, Piqueo's is a must.
author: Joan B.

description: Absolutely fantastic food, authentic with a modern flare. Loved the ceviche, and the sangria was "on point." can't wait to return!
author: Lorena O.

description: great tasting peruvian foods, great sause on all there dishes. reomend cebiche mixto. THEY WOULD GET 5 STAR IF THEY HAD PISCO SOUR
author: dee s.

description:
Cortland's offering of food and drink has never been mediocre. Which is to say, it's either great or it sucks. For every Jekyll, there's a Hyde: Valentina vs. Palatino, Wild Side West vs. Skip's, new Moki's vs. old Moki's.

Piqueo's is a Jekyll, for those keeping score. It's sort of a date place, which I didn't know when I took my buddy there, but we're enlightened men so we sat down anyway. The space feels more open, and thus more relaxed, than it did when Moki's was the tenant.

Our waitress was eager to suggest personal favorites from the menu, and even translate where necessary. If asked to choose, she was decisive; like Nish N. intuited, anyone who claims they like everything on the menu is either lying or selling something. She set us up with two great red wines (a Syrah and a Malbec) to accompany our entrees. I don't remember what my buddy ate (like I said, it wasn't a date), but I had the steak covered in linguine with sauteed mint. Could the meat have spent a little less time in the pan? Yeah. But the flavor was great -- not to mention unique -- and the portion was just the right size.

There was room left over for some kind of lime meringue concoction -- one dessert, two spoons (maybe it was a date?). It was really rich, I mean one notch below pucker-and-wince rich, but again, very tasty. Enough to put the kibosh on our Mitchell's-and-Front-Porch routine for at least a weekend.

Overall -- great menu, fair prices, very subdued vibe. Cortland keeps getting better. I'd go back (with someone else).
author: andy d.

description:
Excellent, outstanding food. Everything here is quality over quantity, and even the presentation of each dish is a delight to admire.

Most of the food is meat-based, but there is a handful of vegetarian options, which I enjoyed immensely. 

The service is extremely attentive but not annoying. The food is cooked right before your eyes, and there's like 5 chefs who you can see work their asses off. The chocolate cake is another delight.

It is, you must know, a little bit expensive, but I find the ambiance  romantic, and with those exotic dishes that are exquisite but won't make you feel bloated, there is no reason why Piqueo shouldn't leave you and your partner/date satisfied.
author: Jorge C.

description: i wanted to try this place as it's closer to my place than Fresca or Limon (until Limon finally opens its doors at 3rd st...) The food is as good as Mochica, with a more relaxed atmosphere. Their cancha (spiced popcorn and corn) is really tasty. I had the ceviche mixto to start, good size, better flavor than same dish at Limon. Then the Causa tasting, one made with chicken and the other with octopus, which was a bit crunchy (a bit too much for my brother). We also had stuffed calamari, and a beef empanada that was the highlight of the night. We finished it off with a suspiro limeno, a dessert that's getting harder to find in SF, don't know why as it's really good. Service was quick but attentive, probably we were lucky as it was sunday after thanksgiving and not so busy. All in all, i'm planning to go back with my peruvian friends and see what they think.
author: Willy L.

description: Great place to eat. A lot of flavor, a good selection of young wines (some wines you can only order by the bottle, really loved the 2009 casajus). The service was outstanding as well, servers are knowledgeable and courteous.
author: Christian C.

description: This restaurant is clean, pretty and the food is great.  I like that they have different offerings than the other Peruvian restaurants such as adobo, arroz con pato, and aguadito.  They say it's fusion, but to me it's just good, basic food.
author: Susan B.

description: Food here was very delicious. Party if 15 so I tried a lot of food. Full of flavor. I had the adobe chancho. Soft meat. Great spice sauce. Mash was sweat. Loved it. Portions was more on the lesser but content.
author: Francisco R.

description:
Excellent food and service.  A sweet looking place as well.
Though you may need to spend more than you think or want to get enough food.  Don't go really hungry.
author: Edna A.

description: AWESOME tapas place, never had a bad meal here! That is an insanely huge compliment by the way because this is right by my house so I take everyone who comes to town here - the last couple months I have been averaging a visit once a week! Love the empanadas, that is a must have, but really everything on the menu is good! This is a great little neighborhood spot, friendly staff, usually easy to get a table. The back porch is great in the warmer months too :)
author: ray r.

description: Can't speak for the food. We arrived at 9:30 (half an hour before advertised closing) on a Thursday only to find the restaurant completely empty, lights dimmed, a waitress cleaning up, and some light bustle from the kitchen as things were being wrapped for the night. Our excitement mutated rapidly to confusion, disappointment, resentment, light indignation...but a quick negotiation was all it took to get a couple sangrias, sparkling water, plus some roasted corn and taro out to the bar. After trekking all the way to the other side of Bernal Hill, our refusal to leave empty handed served us decently well, as our consolation prize was pretty delicious. I suppose they got the last laugh by charging for the water (which was never really "ordered," per se), but as muddled victories go I'm pretty glad to settle for this one.
author: Peter B.

description:
Went on a Monday night with a friend using a groupon.  This place is somewhat expensive but the food is AMAZING.

A warning though - to those light eaters out there, this is heavy food.

I got the small plate of scallops and then shared a main plate of the adobo.  It was delicious!  I recommend this place for a night out with someone special or friends, as its somewhat pricey, AND has a dark romantic but trendy feel.

It is also kind of small and although i went there on a monday and seating was open, I can see it getting crowded on weekends.  So make a reservation :)
author: Melanie S.

description:
Date night tonight and it was perfecttt!!! The food is AMAZING! We got the paella, empanadas, tequenos, and one other tapa, forget the name. They were all equally tasty. Definitely took me down memory lane when i lived in Spain.. this place hit it with every dish including the vino. 

The ambiance was nice too, dim lights, manu chao playing, can't ask for more. Perfect for any occasion but def a spot to check out if you want to impress that special someone!
author: Ava K.

description:
I was craving plantains and Peruvian last Friday night and Piqueo came to my mind. It recently just opened at Bernal Heights, so we decided to give it a shot. The space is very small and intimate, but not too crowded. The menu offers a large selection of tapas, cerviche and entrees.

We decided to order 3 tapas, 1 cerviche and 1 entree. The perfect amount of food since the tapas portions were just right for tasting. First we had the seafood wontons. They were small little wonton deep fried and stuffed with a mixture of "seafood." It didn't really taste like seafood to me, but they were okay. The weird thing about the dish was that it was topped with sugar. The sweet and savory combination didn't seem right. Then we had the plantain. I was very disappointed. It was a whole plantain sliced in half (through the middle) and it sandwiched a piece of cheese. YES, a piece of cheese. This was the first time I ever ate plantains that way. Honestly, I didn't enjoy it that much. I took the cheese out and just ate the plantain by itself. Then we had the Chicharroncito chicken. It was deep fried chicken with a rich creamy sauce. It was delicious. 

Then we had the mixto cerviche. Marinated raw shrimp, fish and mussels served with yams and corn. It was pretty good, not too tart from the lime and the seafood was very fresh. For our entree, we had the baked breaded halibut stuffed with shrimp and mushrooms. This dish was excellent. The fish was crisp and flaky and the sauce was very flavorful. I definitely thought the entree tasted better than the tapas.

Dessert didn't seem that tempting, so we skipped. Overall, I thought this place was just average. I still prefer Limon or Fresca for my Peruvian cravings.
author: Denise L.

description: Excellent atmosphere, great service, nice selection of dishes, yummy food at reasonable prices. 'Nuff said.
author: L S.

description:
My family and I went here yesterday and we all enjoyed ourselves.

Piqueo's is from the same owner and chef of Mochica so you can expect the same atmosphere- modern flair with red walls, etc. 

For appetizers we ordered the Pastelito de choclo, papa ala huacaina, camarones al ajo and ceviche de rocoto... all dishes were delicious. The camarones and ceviche in particular stood out with their incredible sauces and delicate fire. Not terribly crazy about the papas, I thought it could have been cooked a little longer. 

For entrees we had the arroz con mariscos (this was AWESOME.. I was hesitant to order this because I had ordered it from another Peruvian restaurant not 2 weeks ago and was very disappointed because of the dry consistency and lack of overall flavour... not so at Piqueo! Their dish had just the right amount of "moist" texture and the seasoning was perfect, highly recommended!), lomo saltado (maybe it's just me but I am SO picky about lomo saltado and I wasn't crazy about the beef they used... my brother ate the whole dish, though!) and a halibut dish (shoot, I forgot the name!) that was fresh but on the verge of being overpowered by the spicy sauce.

Finally for dessert we ordered the flan de camote (let me tell you I am NOT a flan fan but this was different... it wasn't quite as mushy and overly sweet. I loved it as did the rest of my family) and torta de chocolate (I wasn't crazy about this dessert as I thought the chocolate cake was somewhat stiff, the lucuma ice cream it came with made up for it, though)

Service started off very well- our waitress was very attentive while we were there. However I think the kitchen is still working out some of their kinks- our waitress came out 10 min. after we had ordered to inform us that they ran out of the stuffed halibut we had originally ordered. We also received another table's appetizers... three times.

Oops.

Finally, we were seated in the back room which was on the cramped side and got LOUD as the evening progressed, hope they can do something about  that. It was also a warm evening so it was quite toasty in the back, not very comfortable when you're eating spicy foods. 

But overall I LURVED it and will definitely return... I've got at least 5 more tapas I want to try.. and the arroz con mariscos... and the stuffed halibut... YUM YUM.
author: Nenette Y.

description:
Finally, a real contender against Limon.  

I've been here a couple of times - once for a casual weeknight dinner, and once for a special birthday dinner.  

Piqueos has one of the best ceviche dishes I've had so far.  I'd even dare to say it's better than Limon.  I was literally sopping up the plate of citrus juice with bread to get all of the spicy, limey ceviche julce!

Yes, it's small plates.  Yes, I'm over small plates and cringe when I see new tapas-style non-Spanish places opening.  

However, the small plates at Piqueos work.  

Memorables: fried yucca balls, mussels w/ lime juice, and chicharrones.
author: kim n.

description:
Sad for me to give anyone a 2 star review, but I have to due to the poor service (took them 15 minutes to seat us, when we were the only ones waiting, they knew we were standing there - it's a tiny place.  Then upon seating us - we had to flag down someone to give us service!) and mediocre food.  Plus, we got seated next to a man who must have modular voice syndrome a la Will Ferrell on SNL.  They had tons to offer on their menu, but since it's super dark in there - the font size they used on the menu was barely readable.  

The food itself wasn't horrible, but it also wasn't as great as I imagined it would be (especially after reading all the rave reviews in local papers).

Sorry Piqueo's - wish you could have given us better service and impressed us more with your food.  Honestly, if the service was stellar, I would have added an extra star.
author: Freckles D.

description:
When I moved to Bernal people ranted and raved that Piqueo was fantastic.  After moving day a few of us went out to eat at Piqueo.  Everything sounded great, things looked beautiful but taste, that must have been what they forgot the night I was there.  We ordered 7 or 8 dishes and nothing was particularly outstanding in taste.  The descriptions on the menu made the choices seem amazing but sadly menu descriptions and how the kitchen translated them were not in sync.  Even with the mediocre food I could have been happy giving the place 3 stars but between the inattentive wait staff and the stuffy and overly warm corner in the very back it wasn't an experience I'm wanting to repeat.

At some point I'll give Piqueo aother shot.  I've tried every other restaurant on Cortland at least a few times since I moved in but Piqueo despite only being a block from my house I've been happy to skip.
author: steve a.

description:
MMMMMMMMMMMMM. I love tha ambiance of this place. Beautiful red walls, awesome light fixtures...it just feels inviting to me. Most of the staff is really nice too, although my waiter last night was on a little short in the friendly department. 

All the food I've ordered here has been great. It's NOT a great place for vegetarians, but if you eat fish its more than alright. I ordered the seafood soup last night and for $9 got like $20 worth of seafood. It has a cilantro beer base that's pretty amazing. The best tapa I've tasted here is the sweet corn tamale topped with curry sauce. I'm telling you dawg, its amazing!!!!! I'd actually get it for dessert.

Oh yeah, and their Sangria is really really good.!!!
author: Jennifer C.

description:
Wonderful restaraunt!  Great food, decor, and service!  Perfect for a romantic date or just a more elegant place to go have dinner with your friends! 

The clasico paella was chock full of seafood perfectly cooked...the shrimp, clams, and mussels were like butter!  And the cebiches were delicious too!  The beef stew was tasty and so tender, that it just fell apart!
author: Richard M.

description:
went in with our opentable certificate and felt like winners. 
ceviche, tamarind chicken, stuffed peppers...all with fantastic and complex sauces and great textures. 

i would like to ask that they not hold back on the tamarind though! im a tamarind addict and i coulda used a bit more of it in my drink and my sauce but that is a personal taste thing. 

dulce de leche and pisco ice cream were killer as a finish...

will be back...love the neighborhood too. 

service was great and i appreciated that they didnt rush us even though we came in kinda late. felt bad cuz there was an error on our check that the server had to jump hoops to fix...she was fantastic though and was timed our dinner perfectly.
author: Mohammad G.

description:
solid 5
interesting food prepared in unusual ways
all delicious
great service
author: S K.

description:
Deep menu, good service*, and tasty food.

The chef/owner has another restaurant, and is only here on Tuesdays at present.  While the food is still decent on other days, there is a noticable difference, so try to come on a Tuesday.

The tapas here are large, and average about $13.  3 or 4 should be enough for two people depending on what you order.  I felt like I was getting very solid value for the money.

The star of our meal was the grilled baby octopus - grilled perfectly - meaty texture, with that essential hint of char.  The octopus is wholly responsible for the 4th star here.

I was a bit surprised that most dishes came with the same two go-to sauces smeared on the plate - a guacamole-cream, and a spicy chipotle cream.  I did like both sauces though, and taste-wise, I didn't feel they got in the way of the individuality of each dish.

I also liked that this small restaurant had separate spaces - the front of the house, a bar facing the open kitchen, and a quieter rear 'room.'

*I've had two servers there - the one with the ponytail was great, while the other server was almost comically horrible.  If at all possible, try to be seated in the former server's section.
author: Daniel M.

description: Mostly hits, a few misses. A couple dishes  appeared to have different ingredients but came dressed in the exact same sauce. Some dishes were wonderfully original, even if they didn't totally come together.
author: Aiko S.

description: Mmmm good. I had two of the Cebiche Mixto -- it was quite spicy. And, I love the location in Bernal, so quaint and cozy :)
author: Michelle S.

description: Wow...sooooo good. A very nice surprise. We used a groupon deal but I would have paid in full and then some without any hesitation.
author: Juliann B.

description: Their Sangria alone gets 5 stars.  Let's just say it is tasty & it will creep up on you like no ones business.  Every time I leave this place I am a happy girl.  We usually end up getting tapas and everything foodwise has been very flavorful & tasty.  You will not leave disappointed.
author: Natacha M.

description: I'm here more times that I can count. Each meal is wonderful and it friends are always eager to join me for dinner here. Good wines and deserts.
author: Steve S.

description: I have been to this restaurant only once so far but cannot wait to go back. The inside is very chic and comfortable, the staff is pleasant and the food was wonderful with beautiful presentation. Our overall experience was thumbs up and up again. I look forward to going back.
author: Jana C.

description:
So we decided to check out this place in Bernal Heights since parking is easier and quite close to our place.  We were seated in the back enclosed patio that had a tiki bar feel to it.  We started the meal off with complimentary fried chickpeas.  We ordered a bottle of white wine and a few tapas to start (beef empenada, bolitas de yucca, sanguchon (pull pork on a brioche) and quinoa salad.  The salad was quite refreshing with the Aji Amarillo vinagrette dressing.  I think we could have passed on the pull pork sandwich (it was ok, but nothing amazing).  We also ordered Clasico Paella, which we could have passed on as well.  

Overall, the food was decent and the next time we would probably just order more tapas and skip the main entree.
author: Eva Y.

description:
I ate here with my Fiance last night and we both really really loved it.  And that's no small feat; me being a meat and potatoes ranch hand and she being a true bay area vegitarian.  I know many of us guys are in the exact same situation too, so places that can truly cater to both tastes are rare and highly valued jewels.

The menu is pretty sizable with both small plates and entrees.  We tried probably 5 small plates - not a bad on in the bunch.  The Mac-and-chesse was literally one of the best dishes I've had in any neighborhood place.  I almost ordered a second helping.  I had the steak and scallop - loved it.  

Being new to Bernal the lady and I are very happy to have a place this good, this close.
author: Travis L.

description: love this place. I live close by, and have always enjoyed my meal. If I don't have a reservation, they very much try to accommodate me. I've eaten at other peruvian restaurants and this by far has the best menu, and great wine selection. This has become my go to place in Bernal Heights
author: E L.

description: All the food was delicious and the service was good, but I'm going to agree with a.a. and say the prices just don't fit the place or the times  (especially the paella). I mean this is a neighborhood joint with tables staked on top of each other in Bernal Heights, and we are in the middle of a recession. I had a really nice time, but won't be making a habit of of Piqueo's.
author: Jerry M.

description: A very unique resteraunt with amazing dishes! Want to go back and try more of their food. I am a big fan of tapas style food and this place is simply one of my favorites.
author: Alexander K.

description:
3 of us delightfully dined here and shared a few tapas plates. We enjoyed every dish, and our server was attentive, friendly, and helpful. Most of the plates were brought out one at a time, which we enjoyed since we were able to appreciate the tastes one by one. I had their California Zinfandel, instead of one of the Spanish wines, and it was very good.  Lovely ceviche de pescado- ($14) a nice sized portion, delicious and light, just right! The ribs ($10) were falling off the bone, so tender and tasty! Ooh, yummy sweet potato fries- they were thicker than most that I have seen. The scallops were amazing (very small portion, 2 for $15). We also had a pepper that was stuffed with cheese and meat. This had an interesting taste- kind of sweet. Definitely good, but not necessarily my favorite. The chicken we had was with a peanut sauce, and I just felt like I should be having curry and noodles with the chicken dish. It seemed out of place, but it was tasty. 

Finally, for dessert, they were out of the lava cake so we had a very traditional dessert: Suspiro a la Limena which means "Sigh of the Lima Woman." This is a milky, thick pudding with caramel. Dulche de Leche. Very sweet, high in calories~ definitely something you would share; I think it has too much sugar for one person!

We'll be back!
author: Amy J.

description:
What a disappointment, after my previous 4-star visit. This time out we were let down by elements of the service as well as the food.

The lad appointed to distribute the garbonzo amuse-bouche managed to ignore us for 15 minutes, whilst those who came in after us got theirs. When I finally pointed it out, he still started to walk in the direction of other tables, and I had to *insist* he give us one of the dishes in his hand. Later on, this same fellow cleared my plate whilst my wife was still halfway through her dish. Rookie error, excusable if he hadn't already shown his incompetence.

And then there's the food. First dish was a yucca chip dish. I was expecting deep fried yucca like I had before, only to find what we got was something like large potato chips with some parmesan cheese sprinkled over the top,  tiny bowls containing 3 sides: some bland poorly-seasoned guacamole, a miniscule amount of queso fresco and some other bland sauce. The chicken in peanut sauce was a special, but for $12 I expected a bit more than two microscopic pieces of thigh, each of which contained some nasty bits. My duck quesadilla tasted and felt like a cheap carnitas quesadilla except it was $14.

We love to support local businesses - we've lived in Bernal for a number of years and consider a vital local economy to be important. That's what makes it doubly disappointing that we won't be going back.
author: Neil S.

description:
Took a friend for his birthday last night and was amazed at the excellent quality of their food! The service was great.
Tapas were superb and the sangria was fabulous.
We were seated in the back (as they call it the "party room" which is a no frills part of the restaurant) due to the size of our party.  
The main dining room had a funky, yet cool decor. 
The vibe of the place was rockin'...
author: Pres L.

description: A gem. I had excellent fish ceviche, sangria, corn cake and duck quesadilla. The dulce de leche dessert was mind blowing!
author: Thomas K.

description: Good food, nice atmosphere, recommend highly. went for romatic dinner with my girlfriend, we ordered two tapas and a main to share and we were stuffed at the end, not cheap, but was good overall.
author: Gonzalo M.

description:
Love this place!!
Quite a find in this interesting old neighborhood of Bernal Heights.    Next to an ethnic small grocery store ,  the olive green exterior of Piqueos makes this place stand out in this otherwise drab mix of a neighborhood. 

Inside,  brick red-painted walls in an intimate seating gives out a warm and cozy welcome;  clear glass pendant chandeliers adorn  the ceiling.  The hostess and waitstaff were very gracious and helped us with our menu selection.  Our orders arrived timely, and staff were attentive to our needs.  For starters,  they served us a chickpea appetizer with giant and small peruvian corn and cilantro,  very refreshing.
I enjoyed the lightly fried yucca sticks and the cebiche mixto with my sangria.  Not a sangria drinker but Piqueos' own blend is really good!!  Their tapas selection all looked wonderful. 
Their small wine list,  are mostly of Spanish and latin origins.  I enjoyed a glass of tempranillo from Spain which paired nicely with most of the tapas that we sampled. 
The chocolate torta was super moist,  with nuts around it and caramel sauce;  so was my friend's dulce con leche.

Parking is skimpy on very narrow streets so expect to drive around for a while to find one.
author: nenette d.

description:
I have been to Peru three times and didn't see any similarity between the food at this restaurant and anything I ate there.  Way too expensive and pretensious, they missed out on the beauty of Peruvian food, I had Aji de Gallina, my favorite in Peru, very bland and too heavy.  They gave us about 20 grains of rice in a little ball about the size of ping pong ball instead of the tennis ball or ther softball they give you  in Peru, you need to accompany this dish.  I understand rice is expesnive now but for the rpice they could be a little more generous.  Papas a la Huancaina?  Too bland and rubbery.  Missing the aji de rocoto that makes Peruvian food sing.
The wait staff has no clue about the food and couldn't pronounce the names of the dishes.  Again, way too expensive for what you get.  Try Mi Lindo Pero or Incas on Mission for the real deal Peruvian food.
author: Gregory L.

description:
Great ceviches !!!
The viño verde was great and good price 
Good for family 
I will be back to try some more of there menu 
I was going to la mar and it was closed so we came to piqueos and im glad great bernal restaurant
author: Jorge M.

description:
My old friend took my here this past weekend and I was pretty impressed :)
The place is pretty small, but wasn't isn't in SF? We were seated pretty fast (only 2)

Service A+
Sangria C+ (i've had MUCH better, but yummy.)
Food B They were out of the dish my friend kept on talking about, the shrimp curry. The rest of the dishes were yummy and nicely displayed. I got the CHICKEN tamale (which I could have sworn it was beef) and some battered chicken which tasted like high class chicken tenders but the sauce was GOOD!

Good place to go for a casual date (it's a bit noisy)

A bit pricey for just GOOD food.

But I would definitely go again.
author: Jorge D.

description:
The best Peruvian food I've ever try in the city! The food was great; the peanut chicken is amazing, the ceviche is spicy like the real ones and the service was very good too.
Why I'm giving only two stars? Well, I made a reservation for a party of 4 for 8:00pm, when we arrived there the restaurant was full. More people with reservations keep coming and no free tables yet. After 15 minutes waiting they started giving us free sangrias (that was nice), but after 45 minutes waiting I didn't really care about free drinks.
What's the point on doing reservations if you have to wait 45 minutes? I'm still wondering. They should just have a list like many other restaurants, at least you are prepared to wait.
I'll think twice before going back.
author: Javier E.

description:
The flowers in the unisex, single toilet restroom were dead. But the mac and cheese was to die for. 

I often think that if the restroom at a restaurant is unkempt, I'd hate to see the kitchen. So, yes, I was disappointed when I used the restroom. 

HOWEVER, the menu is impressive. There are 29 different tapas offered. We ordered 6 tapas plus the seafood paella. The only dish I didn't like was the crab stuffed portabello mushroom--the crab didn't taste fresh. The lamb was great; scallops were good as well. The paella was a rather small portion but yummy. 

You have to order the mac and cheese. We left nothing in the bowl. 

The sangria is good--sweet. Desserts--I loved the chocolate cake with orange ice cream. 

There were 6 of us so 18% gratuity was added in. We each paid $50.
author: Joyce L.

description: The menu looks great.  The food however was super greasy, heavy, and too expensive for what it is.  I really wanted to like it!  I left totally underwhelmed as did the rest of my party.
author: Sakura F.

description:
This is a warm and friendly place.  I joined a friend and four others I didn't know.  The small tables made it easy to have a great conversation, not louder-than-bombs noisy like some trendy places.

I love platano so I ordered a side just for myself; it's a bit sweeter here than the Caribbean style I'm used to - but good.  The ceviche combo, ordered as an appetizer for the table, was excellent.  Fish ceviche isn't much of a stretch for a sushi lover like me, but the tentacles and rings of the octopus and squid seemed like an adventure.  Strange-looking, but surprisingly excellent.

The flan looked excellent, but I was too full to try.  Maybe next time.
author: Kristina P.

description:
Great addition to the Cortland dining scene!  We wandered in a few months back after it had just opened.  The experience was good enough to get us back there at least another 3-4 times since and tell friends.  

I recommend sitting at the bar or in the front of the restaurant.  There you can see the action going on in the kitchen, sometimes watching your next dish being prepared.  There's a very lively vibe too and the people watching is good.  

The decor is a little overwhelming with all the red, but it's nicely done.  The natural light helps.  

We have found the wait staff to be pleasant and reasonably efficient.  Service is a little slow sometimes, but I always found them friendly and accomodating.  They are good at recommending choices from the large menu.  

Oh how is the food you ask?  Pretty darn tasty.  The ceviches are good as are most of the other dishes we have had.  The wine list has a decent selection.  The value for money is OK.  I would give five stars if this place was a little cheaper.  Kind of Noe Valley prices in Bernal.  

But I'm not complaining (much).  I love this addition to Bernal.
author: Michael E.

description:
Really small, gets HOT when it's full.  

PROS:  Sangria, mac & cheese
CONS:  my entree of battered fried halibut surrounding something else.  

Maybe I'd be back to try just the tapas, but I wasn't all that impressed with my first visit.
author: Riza A.

description: Wonderful delicious food. Just went this past Tuesday for a pre-birthday dinner, decided to go to the other one in Montara, along Hwy 1 for my real birthday! So many other dishes I want to try. Tapas plate portions are more than the average. Very quaint neighborhood place, a must on your to go list.  Such variety, can't wait to go to the other location called La Costanera.
author: Keana N.

description: A small, intimate peruvian / latin restaurant tucked in the heart of Bernal Heights. Delicious tapas style meals. Try the yuca balls and crab cakes. The perfect crisp to each bite with great flavor and heat. The sangria is fresh and sweet. The dulce de leche dessert has a one-of-a-kind taste that is rich and delightful. A great place to take a date. Make reservations. Worth the trip out.
author: Alex H.

description: Superb Peruvian Tapas. I'm a vegetarian. This place has enough of a selection and the tastes were so subtle and flavorful. Combine that with thoughtful service and pleasing presentation and you've a place one could go back to again and again. For people from South Bay, it is a little pricey, but well worth the money.
author: Dinesh D.

description: Great for groups (easily fit our group of 10), good selection of tapas (every one I tried tasted great), terrific wine (especially the Mendoza Valley Malbec), and nice calming atmosphere. Great place to unwind.
author: Chihee K.

description:
This is a really solid place and I will definitely be back.

Pros:
Almost everything that we tried was delicious!  The portion sizes were significantly larger than most SF tapas restaurants and the flavors were wonderful.  
The empanadas are a winner. They're not the type tiny little ones that you might think; instead, they're huge - inside a puff pastry.  The choclo (corn and cheese) was fantastic.
We also loved the shrimp encrusted with quinoa.
The ahi tuna ceviche with avocado was absolutely to die for!  It's a bit pricer than the others but worth it.
The service was cheerful and prompt.  I loved that they cleared our plates in between tapas courses and that they served the tapas one at a time instead of all together, which means that something ends up getting cold and they all compete for space on a small table.  Nice job!
Finally, parking was super easy - a huge plus in SF!

Cons:
A bit small so there may be a wait, even with a reservation.
They were out of two wines by the glass and a few of the others weren't so good (avoid the red blend from Lodi).
The only dish that we didn't love was the cheese-filled wontons.  They tasted good but weren't oh-my-god amazing.
author: Maggie L.

description:
My boyfriend and I have been wanting to eat here ever since we moved to Bernal and since we got back from our trip to Peru.  We finally made plans last Friday and here is our tale...

We walked in the door and the waiter (somewhat frantically) says, "2 for dinner?" We said, "yes" and he pointed to a empty table near by.  We noticed that the table next to us was also empty but there were menus on the table and filled water glasses.  I just assumed that the people ran to the restroom as it definitely looked like someone had already sat down.

The food looked and smelled AWESOME and we were so excited but we continued to sit at the empty table without even a "hey, we're really busy, I'll be with you in a moment."  Then we noticed other people had to get up to reorder wine, etc. and soon it became apparent that the people who had been sitting at the empty table next to us, probably gave up and left. We gave them about 15 minute to acknowledge our existence and finally left.  I got a faint smile from one of the waiters as we walked out but no apology.  So we headed down the street for tasty chicken pot pie at Liberty Cafe!

I realized that they were swamped and I've waited tables before so I know how it feels, but it would have been nice if they would just have come to our table to at least drop menus or water. We would have stayed.  

We'll try again but maybe on a Monday...
author: Jen C.

description: We loved Piqueo's! From the ambiance to the food to the lovely service, it was the perfect experience.
author: Maris M.

description:
Very impressive. Like most people outside of Bernal Heights, we found this place on a coupon deal. But, the gimmick worked. This place is excellent- in food quality, service, and ambience. Its a smallish date night kind of space that serves spicy and truly novel Peruvian cuisine.  We tried the empanadas, atun ceviche, bolitas and the gambas de ajillo, all of which were impeccable (especially the ceviche. The fish was fresh, plentiful with the perfect acidity).

Although the regular prices may be a tad pricey for Bernal, its still definitely worth a trip or two.
author: Deuce B.

description: I love this place! The staff and the food are top notch. The little bowls of deep fried chick peas that appear on the table are to die for. I can't really tell you what my favorite meal is because the 4 times I've eaten there I ordered completely different meals and all were amazing.
author: Jacqueline T.

description: I went to Piqueo's again a few weeks ago and the food was lackluster in comparison to my first experience.  Even the fried chickpea relish was mediocre.  Hopefully just an off night.
author: seema s.

description: I have now been forced back here twice!  Both times the service and the food were pretty good.  My New Years Eve experience was so upsetting that it'll never be my favorite place, however it seems only fair to write a new review.
author: Emma C.

description:
Usually, I feel like I'm getting jacked when I eat Tapas. Let me just say I feel like I'm starving and irate when wait staff bring me a plate that has a little more than two bites on it priced at $14. 

Not the case here! The quinoa salad is a must. After that, order anything and everything. 

I would give them one more star, but I could not help but wish that their music was just a tad quieter, just a tad, and we were right under the speakers, so maybe it was more bearable at other tables.
author: Maggie Baggie H.

description:
I'd say I was over tapas.  Like, dunzo.  When sitting around with a group of people trying to decide where to eat and someone suggests tapas, I usually get a little sinking feeling.  Always seems like you end up spending too much money on mediocre food and simply make yourself something at home later anyway.

Piqueos was different.

It was three of us -- we made the trek -- and had a great time.  The dishes were interesting enough to keep me going and weren't simply the same note over and over.  Granted, by the end I was bored of that same sauce/tomato/onion that appeared on every plate -- but the rest of the food shone through anyway.  Only exception might be the fried yucca, which ended up more along the line of fried cottonballs.

Overall a nice night -- and not horrendously expensive.  And a good reason for me to get my ass to Bernal Hts...
author: Chris L.

description:
Although the food here is somewhat uneven, the room is poorly ventilated and can be stifling when crowded, and the service is only OK, I still really like this place. The dishes that are good are great, the flavors are strong and distinctive, all of the meat and seafood is high quality (if not always perfectly prepared), and the sangria is perfect. Plus, the room is very warm-feeling, with rich red walls and wooden tables, which I love; it's just a fun, casual-feeling place to hang out and eat.

Recommendations: There are four different ceviches on the menu and both of the ones I've tried were very good: strong, flavorful marinade, but you can still taste the fish. Deep-fried stuffed yucca balls with salsa are a specialty and a must.: crispy on the outside, soft on the inside, yet light and not at all greasy, with a pleasant, subtle flavor. They do a pretty good job simply preparing a lean piece of steak. And, again, the sangria. Always get the sangria if you go. I mean it. As some others have said, this isn't authentic Peruvian food, but authentic Peruvian food sucks (i.e., Mi Lindo Peru down on Mission, yuck). This Cal-Peruvian fusion is much better.

For mains, I generally would prefer the small plates to the large plates, and for the large plates, the seafood and red meat to the poultry. The Pollo Pachamanquero is one dish I have been underwhelemed by, with slightly dry chicken and, frankly, a bland recipe. Avoid it. Dessert selection is a bit fruit-heavy, chocolate light for me, but above average quality in general.

If you're going on a weekend night, you must make a reservation. They take walk-ins, but they get crowded. Fortunately, it's the type of place where you can make a reservation earlier the same day with no problem.
author: Mark G.

description:
I HEART PERUVIAN FOOD.

I spent V-Day weekend here with a friend. The bright red interior matched the occasion, as well as the uniform seating.

I ordered Yuquitas Rellenas for our appetizer. That's yucca balls, stuffed with cheese, served on a spicy sauce plate. (Yucca is a potato- like vegetable that has more texture and taste than the average potato.)

My friend modestly claimed that she wasn't that hungry and promptly finished her HUGE baked- chicken- with- Peruvian- mashed- potatoes- and- vegetables- meal. The chicken was mostly boneless! (I should know because I helped her eat it.)

I ordered a chorizo- stuffed calamari. It's essentially a grilled squid that is hollowed out and filled to the brim with wonderful chorizo meat.
However, the flavors don't contradict each other in any foul way. It tasted like one, big sausage. A good one, to boot.

So yeah, I finished my food quickly, both because of hunger and to observe my friend's "eating- face." As soon as she realized it, she became self- conscious, which only improved her "eating- face!"

The waitress went out of her way to help us out and hook us up with fried garbanzo beans, which they offer in place of bread.

We had unanimously decided that we were pleasantly surprised by how good the place was and how nice it looked. 

Thanks to Piqueo's, I have more credibility- points as a would- be classy dude.
author: Alexander D.

description: Food and service great.  $120 for 4 persons with a 20% tip.  We had 8 dishes and beer.. Everything on the menu is great.  Beef Heart, short-ribs and lomo are a few of our favorites but everything is very good.
author: David B.

description:
Before going to Piqueo's,  I would double-check and ask what time they feel like closing that night.  I called at 8:00 PM and made a same night reservation for 9:15 PM.  We were 10 minutes late because of our cab--we were sure to call and give them a heads up.  When we got there at 9:25, they had the closed sign on their door and almost didn't let us in, even though there were two other tables there.  

A couple of good notes.  This place seems extremely charming and romantic.   Some of the food was pretty good--scallops and short ribs were nice, as well as their amuse-buche of fried chick peas and corn.  However, the Seafood Paella was extremely bland. 

The service was very poor.  We were very rushed and was made to feel really uncomfortable.  Three different people tried to clear entree plates when there was clearly a lot of food still left to be eaten and we told each one we were not through.  Lastly, we were told we couldn't order the dessert we wanted--not because it was out--but because the oven was turned off.  We brought up the fact that we didn't appreciate feeling rushed and if they didn't want us there, they shouldn't have accepted our reservation.   The criticism didn't seem to phase our server.  She stated that they close when business dies down and Yelp shouldn't be relied on as far as the hours of operation go.  It is listed on Yelp for 10:30 PM (and the same in our hotel info guide).  She took six dollars off of our check and put down a piece of Flan, which wasn't very good.  Not a great start to our culinary trip in San Francisco.
author: Chuck L.

description: Excellent food, service atmosphere, very modern yet cozy design. Some of the food was a bit too authentic,with an odd spice to it, but generally everything was really good. Tuna tartar appetizer is expensive ($18) but so worth it.
author: Andrew S.

description: Loved the atmosphere and the service. But the menu was huge and quite confusing - we never figured out any reason or rhyme to how things were organized. We had sangria, the deviled shrimp, the beef-stuffed potatoes, the crab cake and the paella classico. And for dessert, the chocolate tart with ice-cream, and the dulce de leche. The food was really quite lovely, but nothing quite stood out. Except the chocolate tart with ice-cream - that, I can still taste in my mouth ;-)
author: Izzy C.

description:
I love the food at Piqueos, and love the atmosphere - dark red walks, a centerpiece of lemons on the branches. The only reason why it gets 4 stars is because 2 of the 3 times I have been there, the service has been memorably bad. I won't go into details but I mean really bad. But the food made up for it.

Last night I tried the lamb chops, the stuffed portobello mushroom, the tuna tartar, the quinoa flan - all were absolutely delish. I also tried the pork tamales and the caramel dessert which were good, but nothing compared to the other dishes. I wouldn't order them again. 

A previous time I tried the tamale with shrimp curry sauce and the paella, both of which were amazing. But I would steer clear of the plantains where weren't that good. 

Defintely get reservations, this place is small, cramped and crowded most of the time. 

I would say this place is not kid friendly because  it is usually so crowded and small but we were able to go on a Mon night with our little one and it wasn't a problem.
author: Lynn G.

description: Piqueos offered one of the best dining experiences I've had in a very long time. I took my friend there for her birthday and was flat out impressed with the food quality from start to finish. The fried chickpea appetizer was phenomenal. The executive chef/owner gave us a complementary Ceviche that was outstanding. Each of the tapas we ordered were seasoned perfectly and just the right portion size for our appetite. To close out a great evening, the server brought out a delicious fudge cake with a candle for my friend. I don't usually take the time to write restaurant reviews, but decided to leave one for Piqueos based on the great experience we had there. Outstanding food and good service to boot. I will be back.
author: Joe B.

description: Piqueo's was on point! Best sangria EVER and excellent service. Everything we had was perfect - and we tried at least six things between the two of us...ya we were really hungry...
author: Christina G.

description:
I found this spot on Zagat's new restaurant list. It had a 24 rating for food. For once, Zagat's got this right. I was visiting SF and this was a perfect place to take my date. The ambience was charming and romantic and the service was not disappointing. Granted the menu was a tad long but it was well worth it. You always want a variety of dishes when it comes to ordering tapas. For 2 people, you can probably order 4 to 5 different items. We had the scallops which was my favourite and also the quail and the corn on the cob. We also tried a couple others but those three were my choices for the night. 
Their caramel desert was the perfect ending to a great night eating Peruvian food.
author: Alex I.

description:
Most dishes were excellent but the service was not worth the 20% tips that the restaurant automatically add on to the bill for party of 6.

The ceviche is must-have among a few other things.  I couldn't believe that each of us used one bread plate from start to end.   Our plates with ceviche juice should have been changed out before they were filled with mussel, shrimp and clam shells.   We won't offered any fresh plates nor serving spoons for the dessert that we were so obviously sharing.  I don't mind the typical 18% but 20% of over-rating its own service.
author: Cassandra L.

description:
I can't agree with the rave reviews about the food. My wife and I had 5 dishes, and the best one was the lamb chops. The ceviche was needlessly extremely spicy and not a lot of fish for the price. The soup was OK, as was the "pastelito de choclo". Red onions (and giant corn) are put on almost every dish.

Service was friendly but sluggish. Another mishap: My wife ordered vegetarian dishes, but the waitress chose to bring all the meat dishes first, leaving her hungry till way into the meal.

We found that we did not get enough value for this expensive dinner.
author: germ i.

description:
So last night after Rehearsal we were starved and decided to check out the hood Rest. in Bernal. We walked in to a warm super cozy peruvian place. We sat at the counter to watch them cook and chill. We started with wine.. (If you have not had a portugal red wine you must. It is awesomeeeee.) Our waitress was real easy and we just had tapas.  So Tapas the crab with mushroom was off the charts and the Rellano wow. The sauces are dazzling so tasty and full. The desert flan that was okay.. next time I am going back for the rice pudding. I felt the chief really had worked out his creations and this is a diamond in the ruff.
Just go and see for yourself.... ps. I went on a Monday so it was nice and quiet. Be well
author: Bidalia A.

description:
The tapas here are deelicious. I've gone twice and both times I really enjoyed the food. 

I seriously considered giving this place five stars, but I didn't for a couple of reasons. The service was really good the first time I went here. The second time, we were sat in the back which would have been fine except for the air conditioner which made it very chilly, and the very loud wall speaker right next to the table. They did turn down the air conditioner when we asked, which was nice. Also, we ordered 5 tapas all together. The first three came out one after the other, which was perfect for us since the whole group was sharing. Then we waited a long time for the last two, which just seemed weird and kind of broke the flow of the meal. Still it was really good, and I'll go again.
author: Jen R.

description:
If you're in Bernal Heights (or near Bernal Heights), this is a great restaurant to try out. Bit on the pricey side compared to some of the other Peruvian places nearby, but I suppose you have to pay for ambiance, "Fusion", and pretty sauces on top of your food.. Tried the sushi criolla (special of the day), bolita de yucca (yucca croquettes), arroz con pato (rice with duck), and fried plaintains. Everything tasted delicious - although I was a bit thrown off by the fried plaintains - I swear it was more of a dessert than anything - it was fried with batter drizzled with some type of caramel sauce and sprinkled with powdered sugar. Still good, but just ate it for dessert instead. Overall prices are bit steep but if you're in the area looking for a fun restaurant, I'd recommend Piqueo's.

Sangria is delicious as well as is the Fried Chickpeas (free app).
author: Jeannette L.

description: After returning from Peru, I can say with confidence Piqueo's is both empirically good, creative food and authentic.
author: Ana D.

description: Went here with friends a couple of weeks ago and what a surprise to find in Bernal Heights.  Their sangria was very tasty but we wish they had made a white variety as well.  We ordered a bunch of small plates (including the scallops and chicken in peanut sauce, yummy) and entrées and they were all very good.  The highlights were the fish dishes.  We ordered each of the three fish entrées (salmon, tuna and halibut) and each was fantastic!  Dessert was a mixed bag: the chocolate cake was delicious but the rice pudding was very disappointing.  The service was excellent and the atmosphere is very chill.
author: Carly P.

description:
I think Piqueos needs to readjust the prices. The portions are very small and the prices ridiculos for what we get.  I'm not agaist the creativity in their dishes, but they need to remember that peruvian cusine is well recongnized  for being plenty and satisfactory.

Bad Bad, for you guys, we are not coming again.
author: Melissa W.

description: I have been here four times and each visit was the same...fabulous. The ambience is warm and romantic-red walls and ceilings plus great lighting. The food is fresh and unique and the wine list is superb.
author: Amy L.

description: Yum! We went here again just for a regular date night. The food was awesome again. The ceviche...I don't recall really noticing ceviche before. It's always nice, right? Well, Piqueo's ceviche is something else entirely. Our server was tres adorable and was actually from Peru which was cool. For dinner, I had...hmm...ah yes, I had the duck paella. Um, yes please! They don't skimp on portions and I still ate the entire thing, stuffed as I felt at the end of it. Anyway, another great meal at Piqueo's. I highly recommend it.
author: Brian B.

description: Great place for a date!  Get the Cebiche de Pescado (great combination of spice and citrus with fresh fish) and the Costilita de Chancho (the BBQ sauce was better than 99% of BBQ restaurants I've been to).  Also had the Quesadilla de Pato, which was great and very different.
author: Jessica J.

description:
Food was OK. Service disorganized. Staff tried hard. 
Definitely don't get the crab taquitos. Garbanzo bean freebie was very good. Cevchie was just ok. Sort of pricey though. 
When we were sat I think they forgot we were there and then we needed to be moved to accommodate a large party, they tried to make it up to us though. 

For the price I would probably make the trip to Limon if you are craving Peruvian food.
author: Phill and Molly O.

description:
This restaurant has forced me to write my first yelp review.

The food at Piqueo's was so full of flavor, so fresh, and so surprising, it was genuinely a delight to eat there.

We started with - and stuck to - the small plates as they were so tasty.  1 ceviche and 4 small plates were plenty for 2, and we had a hard time finishing dessert.

We had:
Ceviche trio taster: AMAZING.  To be fair, I've never had ceviche before.  But, this just blew me away for the different flavors the 3 tasters had.  Honestly, I could have just eaten ceviche and been so satisfied.  My taste-buds were exploding.
Baby octopus small plate: I'm a fan of octopus, but that also makes me picky.  It was fresh, not at all chewy, and the sauce just made it so different to any other style I've had.  Delicious.
Quinoa encrusted shrimp: AMAZING.  Comfort food with mash and a sweet sauce.  Delicious.
Duck quesedilla: Decadent.  It will fill you up - save it for the end.
Mac and Cheese: I'm not a fan of mac and cheese, but my man is, and his eyes were rolling back in his head.  This mac and cheese is no joke, just because it's a "small plate" don't think it won't fill you up.
Dulce de leche dessert: RICH.  Share with a friend.  Delicious.

I really felt like the price was fair - small plates were around $15 but you really got what you paid for.  

This restaurant would be great for a date, ambience is very romantic and cosy.  But don't just go there to get lucky, go there to enjoy food with amazing flavors.
author: Fiona R.

description:
San Francisco is awash in Peruvian restaurants (don't ask me why) and some of them, such as Lemon in the Mission, are widely known and respected. But I have to say that none matches the offerings of Piqueo's in Bernal Heights. Due to it's "remote" location in otherwise picturesque Cortland Avenue, this little gem may have escaped your  
radar until now, but please, do correct this mistake and visit them for a real treat to your senses. From the moment the friendly staff brings you a free aperitif, to the moment you went through several courses (tapas style) and all the way to dessert, their menu of light, honest and surprising combinations will leave you wanting for more. I have been there numerous times (visiting Bernal Heights is equal to making a stop at Piqueo's), and all my experiences have been flawless, unlike other places where you go to get stuffed and feel regretful afterward, at Piqueo's you go to feeling good about yourself and leave with a "wanting more" aftertaste. I cannot recommend any single dish as I have tried most and all of them are my favorite, you just can't go wrong. No doubt, one of my  top-three favorite restaurants in San Francisco (And no, nobody is paying me to give them five stars, and I don't know any of their owners... Just their food and that is enough).
author: David G.

description: We ordered 5 tapas with Sangria and all of the them were superb. The waiter was not overbearing yet still prompt. There is a lovely back patio, if the weather is nice, check it out!
author: Natalie V.

description: Wow! Had a great meal here Saturday night. The sangria was a little too sweet for my taste but the food was unbelievably awesome. I enjoyed every single dish we ordered. We had the ceviche chino - so fresh and flavorful with the right amount of heat. Then the calamari, the yucca balls, and the short rib - all were outstanding. We had the classic paella again a winner. I've had plenty of paellas and this one was off the chart. For dessert the chocolate lava cake with pisco ice cream. Oh so good. The service was also extremely attentive. Come here, it's so good!
author: Nancy A.

description: Came in here on a Groupon deal and was pleasantly surprised.  It was PACKED but perhaps that was because the Groupon expired that week.  Despite what may have been the slowest service in the history of restaurants, it was a fun, quaint place.
author: Greg F.

description: The atmosphere was nice a cozy, and the food was all very good.  The portions could have been slightly bigger to share with more people, but if you like Peruvian food, then its a must try!
author: Brad T.

description:
This is one of our favorite restaurants in San Francisco.  The food is interesting, elegant, and well-presented, the atmosphere is cozy and the staff is friendly.

I especially like the Ahi Tuna Tiradito, the ceviche, and the yucca balls.  Even the roasted hominy mixture they put on the table is pretty good.

Go with a group and plan for a tapas-style meal.  It can be a bit on the pricey side, so we save this place for special occasions.
author: Jimmy C.

description:
First, let me start by saying that I'm Peruvian so I have extensive background with Peruvian food from simple to refined. After a long day we stumbled onto this place with the intention of just exploring the Bernal area because not having a car, we never get up to that area. Much to my surprise what used to be Moki's was now a Peruvian restaurant. Of course, my curiosity lead me to read the menu outside and giving my stamp of authenticity approval after reading the descriptions...we decided to give it a try despite the inflated prices for what really was Peruvian home cooking. 

We didn't have a reservation but the hostess who looked confused offered us bar seats right in front of the cooks. Perfect for me since I love to cook and was curious to see what the cooks were doing. The ambiance was nice. The reds on the walls are a very Peruvian touch and the art was quasi Peruvian enough to work. It had a nice colonial touch to it - very much what you would see in Lima. Why did I have so much time to explore my surroundings? Because the waitress didn't even attend to us, meaning not even offering a drink, for at least 25-30 minutes and that was only after I flagged her over and told her in my best Peruvian Spanish that we would appreciate at least a drink. We felt a little bad for her because she looked overwhelmed. We even saw her give the wrong dish to the wrong table. We could only assume that the restaurant had just opened because of the lack of organization...we later found out that it just had - so we'll let the lack of structure slide in this case. 

So we finally got to order and went with the causa (layered mashed potatoes with chicken in a aji cream sauces), the humita (a Peruvian tamale of sorts) and the mixed seafood ceviche - all Peruvian classics and items that are very familiar on my grandmas table. The causa was a little sloppy. The potatoes should have been mashed/pureed more and the olive and egg were missing. Howerve, the flavor was good and the sauces were fantastic. Grade: B. The humita...not so much. It was way too sweet and could have even been served as an experimental desert. Tasted like it was made with that masa powder you buy at mexican stores to make tortillas. My grandma would not approve. In fact, she would have taken it off the table. C-. The ceviche was...horrible. Ok, that might be a little strong....but it was bad. First of all, "where's the beef?". Barely a childs handful of mixed seafood on the plate. How about a little more sweet potato too? That wasn't the killer. The killer was the fact that the halibut was of poor quality, was cut in too large of chunks and was NOT MARINATED PROPERLY - in other words deathly raw - ok if it's high grade - not ok if it's not - it wasn't. My girlfriend literally gagged after putting it in her mouth and almost went to the bathroom to finish the job. I, again keep in mind I have probably had more than a 100 ceviches in and out of Peru in my time, was also completely totally infinitely turned off by it as well. The chef was right in front of us and I couldn't help but let him know that this is not what ceviche anywhere in the world, and especially Peru, is supposed to be like. He told me that this is the way it was always served at his restaurants - maybe nobody has ever had the knowledge to tell him that this is not the way ceviche is supposed to be. I was tempted to have him try it and I'm pretty sure he would have agreed. He did kindly offer to replace it. What I did instead is cut the halibut in peices and marinate it in the juice myself for the next 20 mins - only then was it palatable. The ceviches only saving grace is that the marinade was very good. To salvage the chefs feelings...I felt I had to share that with him. Needless to say the eye contact with the chef that was strong at the beginning of the meal faded fast after my ceviche comments. Why did I just write so much about the ceviche? Because it is practically the national dish of Peru - you have to make this properly to call yourself a Peruvian restaurant. Grade: F. 

All this being said, I hope hope hope hope hope that this is not the way they usually serve it and that the restaurant is going through it's first month growing pains. In the meantime, I would go to El Perol's little cafeteria style Peruvian joint in the Mission any day over this and spend 1/10th the amount and get my self homey Peruvian food made the right way - just like grandma used to make. Perdoname mis Cebolleros...pero Piqueo le hace falta.
author: Steve H.

description:
I simply adore this place! The food. The service. Everything about it just rubs me the right way (except maybe the price, but that's likely just due to the fact that I keep loading up on tapas- shame on me.) Parking here has been easy for me the past couple times coming here- I was able to park within a block of the restaurant both times. The place is rather small, but clean and doesn't feel too crowded, which is good. 

I've already been here twice so let's try to throw out the things I've ordered: cebiche pescado, bolitas de yucca, tequefios, quesadilla de pato... looking at the online menu, it doesn't seem to list everything that's on the in-store menu... although there's some things on the online menu that doesn't seem to be on the in-store menu... perhaps it needs to be updated or I'm going crazy...

In any case, there were some dishes that I would pass on (due to preference, not due to quality), but there were some things that I really enjoyed while coming here. The quesadilla de pato (duck confit quesadilla) for one, which was wayyy better than I had expected. A generous amount of duck inside, and the flavors just work. Really great dish. The meals always come with some free fried chickpeas at the beginning of the meal, which are really really good, and I don't even like chickpeas. In fact, I don't like any peas at all, because I own a rabbit, and peas remind me of rabbit poo... 

The service there is good. We've always made reservations and were always seated promptly and quickly greeted by a waiter and offered water. One thing that I really liked about the service here is that after each dish, if our plates were dirty, the waiter would offer us new plates for our next course, which is awesome, because it's NOT awesome having sour/tangy cebiche/ceviche juice mixing with my curry yucca balls. In addition to that, they pass my "don't let me go thirsty" rule and always fill my water. Also, the last time I went there, my bolitas de yucca (yucca balls stuff with cheese and ham) were still cold inside. I told the waiter and he quickly took it back and had the kitchen cook us some new ones. A couple minutes later, he came back to check to see if it was hot enough this time around (which it was.) Very attentive waiter. Great guy. I never caught his name, but it's the guy with the green tattoo on his right forearm. If you're reading this, you're awesome! Thumbs up to everyone at Piqueo's!

I've always left this place full and happy with the service. I will definitely come back.
author: Eugene C.

description: Great neighborhood place.  Best sangria around.  We have been here several times and love the ceviches, tuna tartar and mac-n-cheese
author: Deborah S.

description: I ate here a couple of weekends ago after not having been there for several months. I was totally satisfied with the food and the service. Everything we ordered - it's Peruvian tapas - had unique flavors and presentation and stood out from other tapas experiences, for sure. It has been a little noisy for my taste, in the past, but that wasn't the case this time, perhaps a result of some re-designing that had gone on since my last visit. If I had one complaint, it would be that at the prices jumped up since my previous visits. With a bottle of wine, we walked out for about $90 per couple - not terrible, but not a spur of the moment amount of money to spend, speaking personally of course. Otherwise, I could easily recommend this restaurant.
author: peter R.

description: My review is only partial, as I went for a snack and a drink.  The sangria was delicious and tasted much like wine and less like fruit punch, which made me happy.  We had the mac & cheese and fried plantains, and as random as these dishes were I really enjoyed both of them.  We sat at the bar and I really enjoyed watching the chefs prepare the dishes while eating mine.  Based upon my initial experience, I cant wait to return here for a full meal.
author: Morgen N.

description: Had dinner here last night on a bit of a whim and were so happy we did. The free starter is delicious and a great preview to everything else coming your way. We had the cerviche, scallop tapas and the paella. Everything was tasty tasty tasty.  We wanted to try the quinoa prawns & salad as we saw them served to other tables we know we will next time. We wished there was more than 2 of us so we could try more of the tapas plates. We will be back for sure.
author: Bree H.

description: I can't tell you how surprised I was to see Piqueo's rating average at 3 and a 1/2 stars. We were there last night on a quiet Monday evening, and it was not busy at all. Yes service was a tiny bit slow, but that's because they had only one waiter, and in a way I'm glad it was a little slow cause it gave us time to digest between the different piqueos. We ordered 5 piqueos, 1 ceviche, 1 main dish, 3 glasses of wine, 2 desserts, 2 coffees and one tea, averaging about 50-55 per person. Not bad for a meal I would have before I died. Each and every dish was a culinary adventure and explosion in the mouth. Between the different spices, textures, flavors, aromas, food combinations, and god company, I was trying to milk every second of it. This place deserves Michelin recognition, and I would love to see the chef on Iron Chef.
author: Sanaz E.

description: A little on the pricier end but worth every penny. I went to dinner with a group of 6 girlfriends on my first try. We ordered a little of everything and every plate hit that spot. That spot that makes you want to rock in your chair and say Mmmmmmmm. I'd go back in an instance and order the mac and cheese, halibut cebiche, chorizo stuffed calamari. Can't wait to go back
author: Lorena M.

description: We were here with a party of 11 and they put us in a private "room" in the back.  It was a nice area and it was away from the main  dining room so it wasn't noisy and we were able to have a conversation with people down the table.  It was great!  They gave us a couple of dishes on the house, which was very nice of them.  We ordered a bunch of tapas and entrees to share and everything was delicious.  We tried both the regular sangria and passion fruit sangria and liked the original one better.  The passion fruit one tasted a bit watered down.  There were lots of dishes we haven't tried and would definitely go back again.
author: Irene C.

description:
i am hard to please (even when drinking) and i loved this new restaurant across the street from maggie mudd's and little nepal. it's exactly the kind of place our neighborhood needs, but the prices are steep and i'm hoping for some happy hour deals to spring up. drink beer with dinner (the peruvian options are good), because sangria is too expensive at 8 bucks a pop (if you're ordering at least two glasses, go ahead and get the pitcher).
