my favorite tapas dish was a tamale of sorts with a shrimp curry sauce - incredibly soft and buttery with a mysteriously familiar taste - basically the baby blanket of appetizers. i'd also recommend the bolitas de yuca. perhaps the most remarkable dish was the bread-and-butter-free-side: a sort of veggie salad of salsa (?) with fried garbanzo beans and caritos (fried giant corn kernels?). 

yes, i'll be back. this is either the best or worst to happen to a person living within walking distance. but honestly, you'd pay this much at limon, and if you live around here, you might as well come to piqueo's instead.
author: Kris P.

description: The food is awesome and pretty fast.... A bit pricy but delicious food.... And they have Inca Cola!!!
author: Lee B.

description:
Piqueo's is a great addition to Cortland's restaurant row.  I always love tapas places (I can try everything on the menu without shame!) and it is nice to have a tapas place with a different flavor.  If you're looking for traditional Peruvian, this is not the place for you.  The food is Peruvian-inspired and made with ingredients found in traditional Peruvian cuisine.  I spent a couple months in Peru, and frankly, the food at Piqueo's is much tastier.  We loved everything we ordered and could've chosen 10 more things to try.  A very creative menu and nice presentation.   

At first we thought the service was bad but then realized they were letting us take our time with our meal. No rushing, no pushiness--just letting us enjoy our meal at our own pace.  Being a new place, I don't think they've quite found their groove yet.  There's something slightly formal about it yet laid back that doesn't quite flow, but I think they'll settle in before long. In the meantime, just enjoy the food.
author: Kim C.

description: Another fantastic place I had to write about. Probably, no, it IS my favorite restaurant in SF. You really can't go wrong. I've never had anything bad here. Love the papas a la huacaina (probably spelled wrong), mac'n cheese is AMAZING. Love the sangria. Last time we had a fish stuffed with crab, forget which kind of fish it was. Anyway, just terrific. I will miss you Piqueo!
author: Susan O.

description: I bought a Groupon for this place and was very pleasantly surprised. Food is delicious, service is superb! Recommoned Lomo Soltado, meat was very tender, juicy, flavorful. My son loved Mac+Cheese. Will definately go back!
author: Nozima T.

description: Since this place is a Tapas style restaurant I assumed we would have to order a bunch of plates just to be full. I was wrong. The plates are relatively large for a Tapas place and I was soooo full we had to take our last dish to go. Definitely want to go here again.
author: Crystal P.

description: Fantastic food, especially liked the fried yucca balls and the mushrooms. Some in our group tried a shimp dish (Camarones al ajo) that was said to be amazing (I'm veggie, so I can't fully vouch for this option). Drawbacks include the mediocre service and conversation-killing noise level inside. Entrees seem a little overpriced, but sharing several small plates worked out great for our group. All in all, the yummy food makes it one of my favorite local eateries.
author: Jennifer W.

description: The secret to this place is -- tapas.  I went with two friends from out of town and we had 6 tapas - portabello mushroom with crab (a little rich but scrumptious), mac & cheese (just plain awesome), mixed green salad, bbq squid, plantains & smoked mozzarela, and a FANTASTIC misto ceviche,  the ceviche was REALLY good.  Though I didn't get a chance to try it, my friend said the sangria was just so so.  It was the perfect place to take out of town guests for something quaint, bistro-ey, enthic, and (for me) local.  I will absolutely be going back.  One note on the service...it may seem illogical in the assignment of servers (we had 3 of them), but honestly each one was friendly and helpful. Just don't become attached to any one of them!
author: Norman P.

description: This place is a hidden gem and one of my favorite Latin food experiences so far (I'm an avid eater of Latin food). It's rare to eat at a restaurant where everything, down to the appetizer, tastes wonderful - I'm used to only having that experience at 5-star restaurants. I love their creative use of various peppers in their sauces and the fact that they are able and willing to accommodate a gluten-free diet. I haven't had anything less than a great meal there yet. Love 'em!
author: Rachel R.

description:
Delicious tapas and sangria!  We especially liked the tuna cebiche and the duck breast with roasted plantain. Really creative, warm, and complex flavors.  (The flavor of the adobo pork was great, but we got an unpleasantly fatty piece of meat.)

Save room for dessert - the chocolate cake with mango ice cream and caramel and tamarind sauces is original and fantastic!!

 Friendly, attentive servers. Space is small and a bit crowded but very elegant.
author: heather h.

description: Having lived as a volunteer in the Andes, I stupidly thought the food would look like the gruel I ate for 6 mos. Anyway, this is probably the food eaten only by 5% of the population but hell it's good. Highlights were the very warm and friendly staff - nice change from the annoying hipsters in the mission, absolutely delicious fried yucca - this is one of most sensual tastes I've had in the city, superbly fresh scallop ceviche, tantalizingly exotic beefhearts - just go there - they are slightly chewy but way flavorful... then we ate a cheap and fun dessert across the street at Maggie Mudd's - great SF evening. Parking is easy in Bernal Heights...
author: Steve B.

description:
Went a few months ago, so I don't remember the details.

The food was outstanding !  Great flavor profile.. amazing play on textures.. nice fusion techniques.

Great starter thingy with chick-peas. Awesome hand-roll sushi combo. For main course, I had the fish and my friend had the pork.. The sides were amazing too - purple mashed potatoes !

I left out one star because the servers did not understand what they were serving too well and could not answer the questions about the menu.
author: Rooibos T.

description:
For the food, it was pretty good.  The fact they took over the old Moki Sushi place and remodeled it is very nice as well.   For the rest of the experience, it went from bad to worse.  We ordered wine by the glass and they were out of one of them.  Oh well, I can see this happening in a rare occasion, so no big deal.  We ordered our meal and when it came out she told us that even though She explained that the chicken was suppose to be stuffed with asparagus, they were out, so it was just a plain chicken breast.  How do you not run up the street to Good Life and buy some more asparagus?  Or how do you not tell us this before you cook it?  So then after tasting it and realizing it was no better then Good Frickin Chicken, but 4 times the price, we ordered something else and had to stagger our meals for a weird dining out experience.  As I was finishing my meal, my wife was sipping on her wine when the waitress came over and topped it off with water and then took off!    It was getting comical at this point, but we were sure they would comp us for the wine, one of the dinners or offer free dessert to apologize right?  Nope, the check came and everything was on there.  Then they tell me that I can't use American Express to top it off.   

If they had made some kind of effort to apologize for their mistakes, I would go back, but for the prices they charge and on principal, we can not take the chance of going back in there and suggest you spend your time elsewhere as well.
author: Pele N.

description: Some of the dishes were a bit salty, but I'd come here again because it was still good food.  The best thing is that the staff were SO NICE, even though we had a young toddler with us!  Aaaah, exhale!
author: Ani M.

description:
Piqueo's was quite good, we were pleasantly surprised. We're mainly after vegetarian dishes, and they were excellent. The ceviche wasn't as good as I've had in Peru or  at Limon, which has the best in the city.  The Sangria is quite tasty. 

Service was hit or miss, the staff seems like they are still learning the menu, the POS system, and still getting the lay of the land. I think that with some more experience the wait staff will smooth out and relax and be more efficient.

The place was crowded and there isn't much room. Go early or late.  Bring a coat since you will probably wait outside if there isn't an available table. Call for  reservations.

Overall I'm glad this restaurant has opened in Bernal. We'll be back to try more dishes. Now if Bernal can get a movie theater, we'll be all set.
author: John W.

description: Updated since my earlier review.   They key is to order small plates and share otherwise its like getting too much of one sauce.  Their empanadas and crab cake is fantastic.  I've been back a handful of times and love it.  Though the service can be spotty
author: May M.

description: My friends have started an informal eating club and we try to meet weekly or every two weeks and try a different restaurant. I love it! On Sunday night we chose to eat at Piqueos. This place is GREAT for groups! The restaurant has a really cool ambiance with its deep red walls and Peruvian art. We got a ton of plates to share and I don't even remember the names of everything I got but the highlights for me were the seafood paella which was different from Spanish paella, much more tomatoey which I like, the plantain stuffed with cheese and the ceviche which had notes of fish sauce and maybe basil oil? Yummy!! I also loved the fried chickpeas they give you when you sit down, so addictive! I could eat a huge bowl of those!
author: Cathy T.

description: Got a voucher from bloomspot, the reason my bf and I decided to check it out. The service was great! The area is quiet so we found parking right in front. However, there was nothing special about the food. It was good but not great.
author: Ana Maria A.

description: My wife and I visited Piqueo's and it was great. The food was so fresh that it was too hot too eat. This place cooks food, they don't manufacture food like most restaurants. We sat at the bar and watched as our food was made. We are impressed. The food was to die for.
author: dro r.

description: I really wanted to like this restaurant.   The menu has a lot of stuff on it, and is very difficult to read.  Not sure what font the menu is in, but the writing is very very small.  Fortunately, we waited 20 minutes before we even got a hello from a waiter.   Then it was another 15 minutes before our order was taken.  The first dish came over an hour after we had been seated.  If the restaurant was crazy packed, I would probably understand, but it was half empty/full.  The food itself was average, not bad, but not really ground breaking or great tasting traditional fair.  Just average.  Also, don't sit in the back room if you want to have a conversation, it has a super loud echo.  Don't think I'll being going back anytime.
author: Antichris E.

description: I love this gem in Bernal Heights. The menu is refreshing and exciting. Yes, they have the the traditional Peruvian ceviche but so much more. It's great for groups so everyone can get a taste of everything. Nice wine selection and ambiance. Relatively easy parking.
author: Mike A.

description: great cebiche....and wine (Rioja) was top notch too....recommend the place for sure....
author: Sanj G.

description: Fantastic take on Peruvian food.  Not as typical as we might expect, exciting takes on the traditional items.  Definitely a place to go in Bernal.
author: Mike N.

description: I highly recommend the ceviche and the quinoa flan - actually I recommend a lot of stuff. This place is solid and there are a lot of choices.
author: Will W.

description:
I have been here twice now and both times had a wonderful experience.  The food was fabulous and our waitress was helpful, nice, and didn't hover which is always nice.  
My only complaint is how cramped it was.  I was with a friend and her baby and we ended up having to go back to the car and dropping off the stroller because there was no room in the restaurant.  But, that doesn't change my review because it is not really a big deal.  
But really the food was lovely.
author: samantha D.

description:
oh my yum! very tasty. and affordable! i wish i had leftovers to eat.

big, fat lost star for seating us out on the covered back patio without a working heater in the winter.
author: Clover Dan ..

description: This place was amazing! I just had dinner there tonight, and my friend and I both left with smiles on our faces, and our bellies full! This was a first time first us at this place, and we definitely see ourselves going back! Great job!!!
author: Dana M.

description:
My husband surprised me with a Friday night Open Table reservation  at the end of my long hard work week.
 It certainly looks like a place that should be serving good food! Instead, we had a whole bunch of misses. Plus the previously mentioned inattentive (or new? or incompetent?) waitstaff. Plus cold cold wind blowing in through the mostly open door, where people congregate while waiting for a table. We asked to move and were turned down, and my husband spent his entire dinner asking patrons to please close the door.
-- "ahi" ceviche, absolutely covered in too many red onions. Big slices of kind of tuna. Just because it's tuna, it doesn't mean it's ahi. Not ocean-y at all, but closer to meat. Maybe it's how Peruvian cebiche is suposed to taste?-- but then, if so, I don't like it.
-- the empanada. We ordered the spinach empanada, the waiter said "cheese"? and I pointed to the spinach one on the menu, and he brought us -- get this -- a meat and cheese flaky pastry object. Really very much like a hot pocket, but flakier, and the meat was scarey and neither of us liked the sauce it was sitting in. We should have sent it back. My mistake.  
-- baked corn-cake embedded with white beans and floating in paprika flavored cream. It was great. How bad can something get if it's floating in cream?
-- then the waiter brought us our plate of cooked spinach. OK, but it's weird to have a plate of cooked spinach sitting there by itself after you've eaten three other things. It tasted strongly of burned garlic.
-- then we were asked if we wanted anything else, and we replied that yes, we wanted the octopus that we had ordered at the beginning of the meal. The plate arrived eventually. Little baby octopi, tender enough, on an enormous pile of those white beans. 
We gave up and went home.  75 bucks.
author: Margaret G.

description: Great sangria, yummy ceviche and a cool, but easy going, vibe!  A fun find tucked away on Cortland Street....
author: Katherine N.

description: Yes the food was delicious, however I thought the portions were a bit small and I was still hungry when I left, despite the fact that I had already spent 40 (drink included). On the positive side, the staff was very friendly and the ambiance is great for a date or if you're looking for something intimate.
author: mary s.

description: By far my most favorite tapas restaurant.  They have an extensive variety of wines and fabulous fresh and tasty menu.  The ambiance is great and the service is fabulous.  They had the windows open on a cool evening making it chilly but per our request closed the windows, no questions asked. I will be taking my family here and returning for special occasions.
author: J J.

description: I give this place 3 stars because the food is amazing but the service is the worst I have ever had since moving here. I have given this place 3 chances yet every time its the same thing . getting your food before your drink isnt cool or forgetting the mac and cheese that i waited 27  minutes for! seriously i timed it and she had forgotten it, and the worst part is, it always the saaaaaame waitress who does'nt know the menu or at least try to bullshit about it . Go if you have the time and the patience
author: L V.

description: What a great little treat to have in the neighborhood! We came here when it just opened because we know that it will get crowded quickly.  We are seated nicely tuck in the back.  The waiter, Tomas,  is very nice and helpful and asks if we have any questions.  There are a lot of things to choose from--salad, small plates, and seafood.  When we get our food it is nicely presented and colorful.  It is moderately priced and because these are small plates, a great portion for those who don't want to eat too much but enjoy some good food/flavors.  Definitely coming back.
author: Mel P.

description: We had a horrible time last night!  Service was so slow.  Paid our bill before entree even delivered an hour after arriving.  Chips $9.00, ?  what?  about ten "chips" and three "sauces".  About a tablespoon of goat cheese, a syrup berry sauce and a pesto type sauce.  Scallops.  Three medium scallops for 15 bucks!  really?  One cup of ceviche (mixed seafood) for 18 bucks?  literally, a cup of food.  Too expensive.  Two glasses of wine each and our bill was 80 bucks.  Before our entrees even got to the table, we just left.  The tables are so close together people are literally listening to each other and it's such a drag.  Loud.  Slow.  They cram as many people into such a small space and they can't even serve them.  Our server was nice enough but that didn't make up for waiting an hour for our entrees.  It makes me sad that this place thinks it can fleece the neighborhood like this.  The food was tasty - but too expensive and I give them one star for the balls they have to cram so many of us into a little space and make us wait so long.  Go across the street to Moki's already.
author: Kristen S.

description: Food was excellent, and a nice change from the usual "New California French Bistro" which is sort of what everyone does these days.  The ordering of our meal was messed up, for which they were very apologetic and provided free wine (which was fantastic) and a free dessert.  The staff were friendly and knowledgable.  The bar up front and lack of waiting area mean that it's a little too crowded at times and very loud, but overall worth the investment for the more unique and very high quality foods and wines.
author: Fiid W.

description:
I was recently whisked away for a surprise late evening repast at Piqueo's. Upon discovering our destination, I was excited b/c it's in the neighborhood and it's been on the to try list for a while. I love ceviche and creamy aji amarillo sauces and don't have the opportunity to eat Peruvian cuisine enough these days.

We were told there would be a short wait when we walked in the door. There wasn't much space to loiter b/c the place was totally packed; this really surprised me as Bernal isn't really a late night dining neighborhood. After we were seated I became worried about what was in store for us since it took 25-30 minutes to place our order. If we had been given drinks, the wait would have been more bearable, but our drink order was not placed until we ordered our dinner. The menu was far more expansive than either of us expected with numerous small plates, ceviches, specials, entrees, and house specialties. It was a bit overwhelming b/c even with our experience with Peruvian cuisine, we were unfamiliar with certain ingredients and items. 

They were out of the scallops (one of my selections) so we chose a tuna ceviche, the camerones al ajo, bolitas de yuca relenas con queso, and a duo of taquetos made with dungeness crab and cheese. The pacing of the meal was appropriate for the small two top and we shared everything. The service was clearly still harried as we had to ask for bread to help sop up the delicious sauces that accompanied each dish. The camerones were slightly overcooked and a few were entirely unpeeled. The mahogany colored sofrito garlic sauce was worth the hassle of flagging down a server for more bread. I also loved the cheese-stuffed fried yucca balls and their dipping sauce. The taquetos were slender fried dough cigars, some filled with cheese and others with crab. The sweet tamarind sauce didn't really do it for me but the manfriend liked it. I thought that the ceviche was very well prepared, the cubes of tuna were uniformly cut and properly marinated.

I enjoyed each of our dishes, found them to be well prepared and fresh, and enjoyed the bright and exciting flavors of rocoto and aji chiles, lime juice, and garlic. Everything managed to have an interesting flavor profile without being overwhelming. I will say that I found the prices to be higher than I expected for a neighborhood establishment. With ceviches hovering around $14 and entrees in the 20s, it's verging into more of the nice dinner date range, especially b/c their small plates are so interesting and we seldom can resist ordering a bottle of wine. With prices that high, I expect to have bread brought without attempting to flag someone down for 5 minutes while our dishes cooled. I would also hope that the establishment wouldn't seat more people than they were capable of attending to, which was clearly the case when we were there. I did appreciate our server bring a chilled ice bucket for our bottle of white wine. It's clear that the service and chef have potential but that they need to smooth out a few issues still. 3.5 stars.
author: Candice L.

description: Food is okay, but not as good as the raves the place seems to get elsewhere. Our major reasons  for downgrading it by one star are a) it's too crowded - with wait staff bumping into the back of anyone exposed to a walkway and b) the uncoordinated timing of the kitchen. There's not excuse for one meal being delivered five minutes later than the first. When we complained about this we were told it was "the Peruvian way. ". It just seems to be an unacceptable way to us.
author: Tom B.

description:
Great tapas place.  I especially like the ahi ceviche and the crab cakes, and their accompanying tasty sauces.
The service has been great every time I have been here.  Very attentive and friendly staff.
author: David G.

description:
if food could be love- here you have it. 
often hard to narrow down my tapas selection so i don't fill up on that before my large plate. also great to order just tapas with a group of friends- always fighting over the last bites! the sangria is a must, as is the lomito.
author: c k.

description: Everything everyone said about Piqueo's was spot on. Simply elegant yet homey decor. Many, many wonderful items to choose from. Crab Cake, yucca balls, duck quesadilla, adobo and sadly I can't remember everything else we ordered.  Our favorite was the Adobo, but I'd be hard pressed to not rave about everything. Dessert's were equally as mouth exploding.  Rice pudding, Stuffed cookies and a chocolate moose type cake.  Only a couple minus's (for me).  Lighting so dim I could not read the menu and had to use the candle on the table and it was an extremely cold night so most entrees were not hot enough.  Service extremely fast and almost too efficient.  One suggestion, serve some kind of bread or something to sop up all the wonderful sauces that flavored almost every dish.  I will be back and if my food is not hot enough I will tell them next time.  Though the place is small and could be quite noisy, the lay out makes it very comfortable.
author: Marla B.

description: Wow!  I am absolutely stunned that this is not more highly rated by folks.  I was there last week and I am still dreaming about it.  In fact, I am imagining the delicious tapas-style Peruvian right now.  I love Limon, but I like Piqueo's better for atmosphere (it's smaller and more neighborhood-y), the service (very friendly and prompt) and, of course, the food.  That was my first visit and I'll be back!
author: Tom F.

description: this place is soooo good - I LOVE it. Pricey, I'll give you that, but some of the most awesomest food I've had in a while.
author: Fred A.

description: Thanks to our friends who recently moved to Bernal Heights, we got to try this awesome restaurant. We went on a Monday evening, which was not a busy night. The service was cordial and the food was superb. We shared a few dishes and everything was delicious. The Seafood Ceviche was very fresh but I found it a bit too spicy. The panko-crusted shrimp were yummy. The Causitas Mahi was the favorite, a nice twist on something would expect at a sushi bar. I enjoyed the artful presentation of every dish, but the flavors won me over. We had the sangria, which was also quite nice. I can't wait to eat here again!
author: José C.

description:
I cannot recommend this restaurant highly enough.  We went there when it first opened and enjoyed it, but came back last week and genuinely loved it.   Their prices are excellent, the ambiance is delightful and the food was truly exquisite.   The sauces are incredible and the presentation couldn't be prettier.  

I had the halibut and was nervous when ordering it because I had ordered it elsewhere recently and it was not good.   Piqueno's halibut was incredible.   There was not a morsel left on the plate.  

In addition, their desserts were wonderful!   I highly, highly recommend this restaurant.
author: Kathy W.

description: This place is a great little secret!  wonderful service, warm ambiance and delicious food.  the sauces were wonderful and the sangira was perhaps the best i've had in SF.  looking forward to coming back with a group.
author: Matt E.

description: The food these folks are cooking is really well done.  We went with a friend who is a chef, and he agreed that the meals were imaginative and delicious...The service was friendly, but a bit slow, however this food was really some of the best flavors I have tasted this year.  I enjoyed the atmosphere, too, it was comfortable to sit and talk with friends.  The cooking would be 5 stars but my 3 are for the overall experience.
author: Akire L.

description: I really liked the food here.  The mixed seafood ceviche and corn fritters were good.  I tend to not like sangria, however, this is one of the few places that I throughly enjoy the sangria.  I had the salmon and it was remarkably good.  The wait staff was quite helpful and the surroundings were inviting.  It was around $90 for three courses (two of them were shared) and one glass of wine.  Overall, strong dishes and a good experience, but minus one star for the for being a bit overpriced.
author: Chris W J.

description: Great, attentive service.  Menu is tapas, with approx. 50% of selections coming from fried foods.  Ceviche presentation was not on par with Fresca, which I would highly recommend.  Variety on the tapas menu was excellent, and all of the bites we tried were very satisfying!  Will give them another go in a couple of months ;)
author: Don N.

description:
DELICIOUS! The chickpea appetizer might have been my favorite thing.
But then there was the empanada...that was my favorite thing. Or the rice and beans....and then dessert was a cinnamon-y caramel and whipped cream dish that was mind-blowing.

The food was pretty amazing. My only possible complaints are due to personal taste, not anything they did wrong. I don't much like cilantro and prefer white meat chicken. (But why am I eating at a Latin American restaurant if I don't like cilantro, right???)
The portions look small on the plates, but we arrived very hungry, split three tapas, a side of plantains, and one dessert between two people, and I left feeling so full I was ready to vow to never ever eat again.

More expensive than I usually eat at (about $40 a person after tax and tip), but I felt the food was worth the cost. Sangria was tasty but they could have offered larger glasses for the price. Don't be stingy with the sangria, Restaurants!
author: Carrie H.

description: Wow, this place is great!  We stumbled upon it after working up a good appetite walking around Bernal Heights Park.  What a treat!  The sangria was good, and each plate was better than the last.  I will be wistfully thinking of the empanada for weeks to come!
author: Kate C.

description: I love this restaurant. I love the ambiance, and the food is amazing and unique. I had the best salmon I have ever ever eaten here, as well as multiple delicious tapas dishes. And much better prices than somewhere more central. And not pretentious at all. There are plenty of options for vegetarians, and great sangria- all in all a wonderful experience!
author: Tanya W.

description: This place had excellent Peruvian food! Loved the cebiche and tapas - can't wait to go back for more!
author: Andie Q.

description: i go here alot, always interestign peruvian fare, maybe not authetic like in peru, but who cares. go for the ceviche, the pastel de choclo, the tuna tartare, soem of the main entrees in fish are great too. stay away from dessers, better make a 15 walk to mitchels !
author: Jef C.

description: The food here was delicious.  My friend and I ordered the potato balls with beef raise, the plantains, a salad, and the halibut.  It was all so tasty.  The Sangria was also very good.  We also had the rice pudding for dessert but I was not thrilled with it.  The service was excellent as well.  The only reason why I gave it only four stars was because I did not like the atmosphere.  But the food definitely made up for it.
author: Toni C.

description: The food at this place is purely delightful.  You can choose from tapa's to full entrees.  This Peruvian restaurant would get a full 5 stars IF the service was better.  I've been here twice now and both times, the wait time to get our food was over an hour, sometimes we would see other patrons (who were seated way past us) being served before us.  Other times, the waiters would forget to come by to refill our water glasses, or to see how we were doing.  Both times I have been here, the average time at the restaurant was at least two hours, with a wait time of about 30 to 45 minutes just to get our salads, then another 20 plus minutes to get the waiter's attention to get us our bill.  I don't know if the food is worth going back a third time.
author: Kris G.

description: Last year 4 of us went to Piqueo's knowing only that it was Peruvian, and we were looking for something new. We could hardly have done better - the neighborhood is interesting, the restaurant has good ambiance, the food and wine are great. We ate by sharing all dishes - and everything, from a duck quesadilla appetizer to the paella was very flavorful. I will definitely go to Piqueo's again.
author: richard s.

description:
PRICES ON WEBSITE ARE NOT TRUE:
I got some take out from Piqueo's today and had a mixed experience. I looked to the menu online and ordered a few items. When I got to the restaurant to pick the food, I was surprised at the check's amount. As it turns out, the prices on the online menu have NOTHING to do with the prices at the restaurant! The peruvian paella was advertised online as $17 dish and they ended up charging me $22! The corn cake was $10 online and $12 at the restaurant. Not cool! When I mentioned the difference in prices to the hostess, her answer was that they cannot keep on changing the prices all the time online, that it is too time consuming, and that prices change because the prices of groceries change! What a BS answer!! 
I was planning to give them a 1 star review as I walked home, but the corn cake was really delicious, so 2 stars because of that. The peruvian paella was just blah.
author: carmen c.

description: Its my first time here. Service is good. We ordered the Fried Oyster, stuffed halibut very yummy. Favors are very complex with lots of different layers of species.  reasonable price, I will certainly come back.
author: Wendy C.

description: Just got back from a very nice dinner here, late on a sunday night. Food was excellent. Service was very good. Were seated promptly. Asked for sauce on the side and got it. Busser offered to burn us a CD after we commented on the background music. Yes, it's moderately expensive, and the portions aren't very large, but the two of us had 4 small plates and 2 glasses of wine and the bill was a reasonable $65, and we were very satisfied with the quantity and quality. The garlic shrimp, steak skewers, shrimp wontons and potato balls were all very good. Would recommend to friends in a heartbeat.
author: Jen S.

description:
Huh. Not sure why but this place was only so so to me. I did love the fact that you don't have to make reservations or wait. Come on in!

It's basically Peruvian tapas and they were professional enough to time it well so your table doesn't start to look like dinnertimeatthecrazycatlady's house. A few of my dishes were super sour. It just seems like something was just a little off with their food.

I'm glad they got rid of seating people on the outside deck like Moki's used to do in the space previously. That really sucked to sit in plastic chairs in somebody's backyard eating in the dark and cold. Brrr!
author: Tracy Y.

description:
Not very impressed... but maybe it was our selection of foods : 

The garbanzo sampler - they just serve this at every table. This was the yummiest.  We could have just had bowls and bowls of that (toasted/fried garbanzo, onions, tomatoes, lime, salt, a bit of chilly.. umm that hit the spot!). Staff was nice enough to bring us an extra one.

Sangria - very nice... quite potent.. however were shocked with the pitcher price of $26 on our menu

Chicken Empandas - too sweet for our taste. And there was just one large empanada.. v/s say 3 smaller ones.. (so harder to share)

Quinuoa soup - simple, a bit salty. good overall. But not worth $9

Yucca balls filled with cheese - the balls themselves didn't have much flavor. Sauce was nice.. maybe they should have been filled with the sauce

Mac n Cheese  (minus bacon) - Liked the crusted top, but other wise lives up to its name : macaroni and cheese!

Baby Octopus : Ordered based on the waitress recommendation as something spicy and that definitely did not meet our expectation. The octopus itself was well done but the sauce left a lot more to desire.
author: Nilofer M.

description: Great ambience and fancy! 4 stars for the place itself. The food was good, but they took too much time to serve. Its a great place for drinks and small plate snacks but not for elaborate meals as the portion sizes are really small. Sangrias are good.
author: Deepti P.

description:
this is going to sound weird - for a peruvian restaurant - their mac n cheese was the BEST ever!  loved their shrimp-mozzerella won tons (i think thats what it's called) as well. 


cons: lots of meat dishes (i dont like red meat)
pros; great place to sample appetizers with friends
author: Juno R.

description: Quaint resto in an old residential neighborhood; never would've tried this if not for the Groupon deal.....nice ambience...very tiny resto.  Food and service were great!   Had the pork and chicken tamals, lamb shank, ceviche, and others that I can't remember, but all deelish dishes.  Highly recommend this place!  A gem!
author: M C.

description:
This is one of my favorite restaurants in SF and my favorite place to take out of town visitors. It's probably more Peruvian-Californian fusion food than authentic food from Peru (no cuy, alas).  They have lots of unusual but tasty tapas with potatoes, yucca,  and plantains  and delicious ceviche.   The suspiro (caramel desert) is amazing.  The menu seems to change a lot, but I have loved pretty much everything I've tried.  

It is a bit small, so make a reservation before you go (I've always been able to make same day reservations).  Staff seems fairly friendly and our food has always been served promptly.

Yum.
author: anne s.

description:
Amuse bouche rico
preps mouth tickling veggie soup.
La fin? Limena.
author: Schauleh S.

description: We had dinner here (large party) - and we had no problems with the service or food....AND it was Saturday night and the place was packed! I think it is a great addition to the hood and wish them all the best!
author: Andrea P.

description:
Great expectations but disappointed.

We had great expectations about this small "fusion" restaurant in South San Francisco especially since we have visited t Astrid Gaston, La Mar in Peru and Limon in San Francisco and read about it on AAA magazine this month. First impressions are important; unfortunately Piqueos didn't live to the expectations.  
We wanted to try humitas and aji de gallina, unfortunately not available that night; we would have liked to try their aji de gallina.
Their list of wines was nothing to write home about it, most of them middle of the road unknown wines.
Among the tapas (small plates) we tried a dish made out of Andean potato chips, the chips were saggy so we had to return the dish
Then tried their Arroz con Mariscos, but had to return it since it was gritty due to poor cleaning of the shellfish. Not a good idea eating sand for dinner and a second dish returned for the night.
Peruvian cooking flag dish, Lomo Saltado, is a dish to try in any so called Peruvian fusion restaurant. It was a total disappointment. Piqueos claims in their menu that this dish is a Sauted marinated New York Strip but what you get is a stew of cheaper meat. Interesting that when we talked about this faux pas with Piqueo's chef he said that it was the owner's recipe, that it was cheaper to prepare it that way and that their food was not for Peruvians.
About the service, it was mediocre and dishes took a long time to arrive to the table.
author: Jeffrey R.

description:
By far my favorite restaurant in the city.  They feature a delicious assortment of sauces and perfectly cooked food.  The pork is as good as I've had and they always have a nice duck breast tapa.  We have been here around 6 times now and tried just about everything on the menu and the only item I didn't care for was a potato dish with raisins.  The sangria here is terrific too.
The prices are pretty reasonable too, generally it costs us about $30/person with a pitcher of sangria for every 2 people.  The tapas are fairly large so you don't need to order many.
author: James S.

description: This is one of our favorite restaurants in the city.  We have tried ordering pretty much every tapa on the menu and have liked or loved every single one.  Also, their ceviche is really good.  This place is sort of like Peruvian fusion, so there is a great combination of different flavors and options which truly makes this place unique.  They have a back room that is great for parties (which is especially helpful if your hard-of-hearing parents are visiting).  Haven't been in a while, but in the past, the tapas that didn't disappoint include the mustard lamb chops, the empanadas (a MUST), and the white bean cake (doesn't sound all that good on the menu but my brother ordered it and I tried it and yum!).
author: Christina P.

description: i honestly don't like being un-generous with my stars, but last night's experience was irritating in the most respectful way to describe it. the servers seemed stunned and uneducated as to what they were serving. there seemed to be only 2 servers for a packed house and 1 seemed primarily dedicated to preparing the bills. it was about a half an hour to get a glass of wine.  the food was good. we had several of the tapas dishes. the flavors, presentations and flavors were good, but man good service is essential especially at those price points!
author: debora s.

description: Wow, talk about selection.  I don't think we even made it to the back side of the menu.  My friend Rebecca (Miss Boston if you're nasty) had recommended this place from way back so I decided to go with her out to the rarely frequented Bernal Heights for some Peruvian.  She grew up in Peru and Paraguay so I trusted her taste more than most.  We got there and she ordered a drink called a chicha morada which is popular fermented purple corn drink from Peru.  I had a taste and it was really sweet but good.  We shared 4 dishes: yuquitas (yucca fritters), grilled baby  octopus, mar y tierra (steak and scallops), and the mixed ceviche.  All the dishes were really good.  Some might say too salty, but Rebecca said food in Peru is all really salty, so it was relatively authentic.  I really liked the baby octopus because it was really tender and had a nice chargrilled flavor.  The yuquitas were soft and tasted great with the melted cheese inside and the tasty sauce outside.  The steak and scallops were also perfectly cooked, medium rare steak and huge tender scallops.  The ceviche was also delicious and all the seafood was so fresh (clams, mussels, shrimp, calamari, snapper).  If you like Fresca and Limon, you really should try Piqueo's...even if it's way the heck out there.
author: Dave L.

description: I had a friend visiting this weekend and we decided to try this place out. We just went for a few tapas plates to share and it was definitely a good call. First of all they have fried plantains! Can you ever go wrong with those? No. The food was wonderful, flavorful, and not the average fare. The duck and goat cheese quesadilla -- incredible!
author: Tyler W.

description: We must have been sitting next to Sandra on this same evening.  It was Valentine's Day and my husband and I were also celebrating our wedding anniversary. We live in Bernal Heights and wanted to try this restaurant.   I got childcare for our son.  I got dressed-up.  It was raining, and VERY DRAFTY and cold in the back.  The waiter couldn't pronounce the dishes, in fact, he didn't know what was on the menu.  Disturbing!  The meal was just ok.  Nothing spectacular like the dishes we had in great restaurants in Lima and Cuscu, Peru.  I wasn't even allowed to have dessert and coffee after!  I didn't ask for my left-overs to be boxed, but it was and promptly dumped in front of me, as a message to scram, get out of here.  I was so upset!  It took me awhile to type up this review, because I was just so angry thinking about Piqueo, I would have typed up something with more bitter emotions earlier.  I think others tipsy on sangria probably would not have notice the bad service.  I don't drink.
author: Christina V.

description: VERY DISAPPOINTING!! As a native Peruvian I have ventured into many Peruvian restaurants in the Bay Area; and Piqueo's has made it to the bottom of my list.   To start it was over priced for the amount of food you get - we ordered 3 appetizers, 7 entres, and a pitcher of chicha morada (filled only 4 glasses) - the bill was $260 if you include the tip the total was $300.  Way too much for a casual dinner out.  I wouldn't mind paying that much if the food justified the prices, the appetizers were a JOKE; the "chifles" were just potato (they gave us plain potatoes even when the menu said purple potato), yucca, and sweet potato chips served with guacamole and a tamarind sauce...the chips were not fresh, especially the yucca was stale and no longer crisp. The "yuquitas fritas" were tasty and the sauce it came with was yummy, but you only got 5 gumball size stuffed yuccas for $10 - I felt robbed! To make the long bad experience short: the steak was over cooked, the salmon did not have a quinoa crust (as described in the menu), what seemed to be Lomo Saltado was nothing more than tasteless tough pieces of meat in a red sauce.  The rest of our plates were average.  I read the reviews before going to Piqueo's especially the bad ones, and still decided to try it out...bad, bad idea.  Every one of my friends was disappointed that night and swears never to go back again.
author: Grace K.

description:
Bad attitude...

So, I wrapped up work late in the afternoon, and since it was so darn nice and warm out, I thought I'd take a walk over the Hill to Cortland for some dinner.  I walked past Liberty Cafe, but there was a decent wait (hardly surprising, it's a neighborhood favorite).  I continued down the street, and noticed that someone had finally moved into the old Moki's space (which I wish they hadn't left.  I understand they wanted something larger, but the old Moki's had a much better vibe).  I perused the menu;  it looked interesting, so I stepped inside.  

The hostess approached me, and asked how many.  I replied, "just me".  She motioned to the bar.  I'd noticed the bar, but it was appealing to me at the moment -- it was completely unoccupied and practically on top of the cooks (read loud and hot).  Now, that might have been fun and interesting under some circumstances, but sometimes when you're dining alone you'd rather just sit down at a quiet table and read.  I said, "I'd prefer a table this evening if that's all right.".  She shook her head, almost sadly.  "Looks like there's one back there", I said, eyeing a two-person table.  "Oh, it's reserved", she replied, but it was pretty clear that it wasn't by her tone.  What she really meant was "we're not about to waste our precious table on a lone diner".    I said, "Oh, maybe another time then".  I left, walked down the street to Little Nepal -- a great neighborhood spot that has
an inviting, cozy atmosphere, great food, and staff that don't make you feel bad on that odd night when you're dining alone.

Now, I understand that restaurants want to maximize their revenue, and it's a tough business.  I get it, really.  I'd be a bit more sympathetic if I hadn't gotten the "it's reserved" line from the hostness and had instead been told the truth.  Still, it's a pretty short-sighted business strategy -- especially as a neighborhood restaurant  -- to give a customer the brush-off because he happens to be dining alone that night.  It stands to reason that he might bring friends next time, spread the good word, etc.  

I'm willing to revise my one-star review if I try it again sometime, but I'll deliberately go solo first;  I won't take my people there until I see if the bad attitude was a fluke or standard practice.  I *really* want to support new neighborhood restaurants in Bernal, but those that discriminate against lone diners don't deserve a spot in my hood.   Remember, we all eat alone sometimes...
author: Mark K.

description: Sister restaurant to the Peruvian place Mochica in SOMA, I expected this restaurant to be similar. As far as ambiance, it has a very different feel...much more intimate a dining space....packed and active with an open kitchen. It was packed when we arrived there, but since we had a reservation, we were seated immediately. The menu is similar to Mochica, with the requisite Peruvian staples, but I remember the portions at Mochica being significantly larger. Our meal included the ceviche mixto, which as another reviewer also described, had halibut served in cube form. I wasn't as enthusiastic about that either, so I let the halibut cubes marinate a little longer. However, the shrimp and calamari were excellent and overall the flavor of the ceviche absolutely wonderful. The lomo saltado was also melt in your mouth yummy. And the flan for dessert was scrumptious. Both of our wine selections (he with the Argentinian Malbec and I with a gorgeous Argentinian Chard) were also right on. We found the staff to be quite helpful and friendly...but busy so we had to grab their attention a couple of times. However, for a newly opened restaurant the experience was quite good and I will definitely return.
author: Suepattra M.

description: this place is DELICIOUS.  went there with a group of 7 last night and could not have asked for a better meal.  we turned the ordering over to the server upon his recommendation and we didn't regret our decision.  his choices and the amount of food for the table left us all amazingly pleased with a perfect belly full of food. this was the kind of meal i want to tell people about!!  if you go on a tuesday - stop by the stray bar for 2 for 1 drinks :)
author: B H.

description: Piqueos offered one of the best dining experiences I've had in a very long time. I took my friend there for her birthday and was flat out impressed with the food quality from start to finish. The fried chickpea appetizer was phenomenal. The executive chef/owner gave us a complementary Ceviche that was outstanding. Each of the tapas we ordered were seasoned perfectly and just the right portion size for our appetite. To close out a great evening, the server brought out a delicious fudge cake with a candle for my friend. I don't usually take the time to write restaurant reviews, but decided to leave one for Piqueos based on the great experience we had there. Outstanding food and good service to boot. I will be back.
author: Hans O.

description: Went with a group of friends yesterday to this restaurant.  Overall, it was a great experience, food was good, they seated us right of way.  We had to get the waitress over a couple of times, but after that it was very smooth.  Will definitely go back.
author: Ina S.

description: I have to write about this because we had a horrible experience Saturday night. OVER 50% of the dishes we ordered, whether it was tapas, an entree, or even a bottle of wine, were "not available". We had to reorder 3 times and this was for a birthday party for a table of 9. They knew we were coming and the service was very spotty. Desserts were also not good (extremely sweet) and we had to ask them NOT to charge a "cake fee" but luckily my friend baked a cake, it was far better than anything on the menu. I can't even give this place one star, because even the basics tasted bad. Lomo saltado was tough, the pork inside the tamale was rock hard, and the baked halibut was SO salty. There are far better peruvian restaurants to eat at in the city.
author: Gigi H.

description: This place is great. I help Carlos re-write/make his menus every week because he likes to add new items to keep things fresh and interesting. Only thing i dont like is that he comes before lunch and has me write the new names of the dishes and the discriptions of them. The Yucca balls are godly. I will return.
author: Kevin L.

description: I loved the food here.  The Yucca balls were awesome.  We ordered 6 different tapas and not one was underwhelming.  In fact, I can't wait to go back for more....I am hooked.  Get me to Peru, quickly!
author: K J.

description: Glad to have another restuarant choice and a place with an extensive menu.  The food tonight on opening day was quite good; Very fresh and flavorful.
author: Ed T.

description: Food was good and sauces were as well, however when asked to have more bread to actually enjoy the sauces the server seemed put out? The food itself was good, but I have to say the server was less than attentive and at times even rude. I would have hoped a simple, "thank you have a good night" when dropping off the bill would have been sufficient. Service definately lacked that night, I only wish I had asked for the servers name.
author: christine m.

description: okay, i was a bit concerned when my friend suggested this restaurant, as the other restaurant owned by this chef, mochica, totally gave me diarrhea when i went there a few years back.  i automatically took off one-half a star for that...yup, life isn't fair, buti i don't take those episodes too lightly.  nevertheless, i was in the mood for some south american food, so i decided to go with the flow.  the food was very good.  my favorites were the tamale...very nice sauce that went with it....the duck quesadilla...kinda like latin peking duck?  okay, maybe not, but it was pretty tasty, and caused me to give one-half star back to the restaurant.  the calamari was okay.  the pobrecito was okay, if a bit bland.  the empanada was pretty tasty...kinda liked the powdered sugar dusted on top and the tamarind/caramel sauce...interesting combination.  the halibut was okay, but was not particularly flavorful and maybe a bit overdone.  we had some sort of caramel pudding for dessert which was pretty good.  overall a good meal.  portions were a bit substantial, so even though our server told us about 3 plates (tapas) per person....i think 2 plates per person probably works a bit better unless you have a serious case of the munchies or something, in which case, go at it!  no "gastrointestinal issues" either...woohoo!
author: Miss P.

description: pretty high end peruvian restaurant. food is very good but my pocketbook will only allow me to come here once in a blue moon. my girlfirend swears by this place and she's a full blooded peruvian.  check it out if you got some money to blow and feel like living the good life.
author: Wats C.

description: Being a fan small plates, my friend and I went to Piqueo a couple weeks ago.  When we first sat down, we asked the couple next to us what they thought.  The woman's face paused in hesitation, debating whether or not to tell us bad news.  She spilled and said that she thought the food was bland and unoriginal.  Loving Peruvian food, I couldn't help but discredit her comments.....smart move.  The food was delicious, and nothing short of flavorful.   We asked for some recommendations from the waiter.   We ended up getting the small plates: Camarones al ajo, Humita Dulce con Shrimp Curry Sauce, Platanito Maduro Frito, and Chicharroncito.    Everything was delicious.  A nice addition to the meal was the pitcher of Sangria we ordered.  If you've gotten Sangria from ChaChaCha, I cant' think of a better word to describe the difference other than classier.  I don't mean that in a pretentious way, it's just has a nice smooth, less chunky taste to it.  The soft lighting and red walls completed the experience.   Definitely a gem of Bernal.
author: Beth S.

description: A friend of ours recently moved ot the area and he's been there 3 or 4 times and loved it.  And he's a very discriminating customer.  He wanted to introduce the place to friends so he made a reservation and we went.  The menu offers many choices - tapas and entree's.  We had a hard time deciding because everything looked so good.   We settled on a mixed green salad, quail, and crab stuffed wontons as our appetizers.  They were all delicious.  For our entrees, I had the lamb with a wonderful risotto; my boyfriend had the New York Strip steak, and our friend had the Duck.  All were amazing - so flavorful!  Our friend also recommended the Rabbit but they had already sold the last order before we got there.  I can't wait to go back - you could even just order several tapas and skip the entree depending on how hungry you are.  I would not have expected this restaurant in this neighborhood but you won't be dissppointed if you like flavorful and creative food.  Good Sangria too.  Prices were average for a San Francisco restaurant.
author: Sharon A.
